webTitle: Press reaction from Spain, Chile and Argentina

fields.headline: Press reaction from Spain, Chile and Argentina
fields.trailText:
Any opposition to Straw's decision will be blind opposition
The problem is that the doctors' report is secret. This means it is not possible, for instance, for Spanish forensic doctors to examine these findings and reach their own conclusions. It seems that the British home office realised how hard it would be [for the Spanish prosecutors] to make a representation without the details of the diagnosis. This is why the home office sought authorisation to hand a copy of the report to the Spanish authorities. But Pinochet rejected the proposal.
fields.byline: Compiled and translated by Sean Clarke
fields.body:
Any opposition to Straw's decision will be blind opposition
The problem is that the doctors' report is secret. This means it is not possible, for instance, for Spanish forensic doctors to examine these findings and reach their own conclusions. It seems that the British home office realised how hard it would be [for the Spanish prosecutors] to make a representation without the details of the diagnosis. This is why the home office sought authorisation to hand a copy of the report to the Spanish authorities. But Pinochet rejected the proposal.

As such, the representations invited by the home office will be of a somewhat metaphysical nature. Any opposition to Straw's decision will be blind opposition, necessarily, and as such thoroughly unsound.
El Pais, Spain

A landmark in the defence of human rights
The Pinochet case is a landmark in the defence of human rights. The progress made has not been simply rhetorical or notional. Even if the ex-dictator does now return to his country, some incontrovertible principles have been established. First, that treaties and conventions into which nations enter lightly are nonetheless binding; and second, that the protection of [human] rights requires a framework which is better defined than the individual actions of a Spanish magistrate. ABC, Spain

'Purely humanitarian grounds'
By announcing its decision before the results of the Chilean election are known, the British government wants to give the impression that it has no political motive, and is acting on purely humanitarian grounds. [] Carlos Slepoy, the prosecuting lawyer in the Spanish case against General Augusto Pinochet, said last night that the British government's decision was "a very grave error, and one that that does great harm to the cause of human rights". La Vanguardia, Spain

Humanitarian considerations
Quoting Ricardo Lagos, the presidential candidate: "The British government's decision was made in favour of a sick man. All of us who have humanitarian values must feel compassionately about that There's a lot of work to be done in Chile. The humanitarian considerations that have been sketched out in this case must lead us to thoughts of other humanitarian considerations." El Mercurio de Santiago, Chile

Pinochet will walk directly on to Chile's judicial stage
As the principal suspect in the criminal investigation led by the [Chilean] justice minister Juan Guzman, in which seven high-ranking retired military officers have been tried and more than 80 members of the armed forces of varying ranks questioned, and with 55 criminal charges against him, life senator Augusto Pinochet will walk directly on to the judicial stage when he returns to Chile.
La Tercera, Chile

The humanitarian treatment none of his victims received
If Pinochet goes free, [Britain] will have granted the wish repeatedly expressed by a human rights campaigner in London: "We want [Pinochet] to receive the humanitarian treatment which none of his victims enjoyed".
Clarin, Argentina

All very paradoxical
Straw's decision, whether or not Pinochet now returns, ruffles the sheets of bygone phantoms. It's the past returning. And it leaves Lagos [the leftwing candidate in the Chilean presidential elections], Frei's heir apparent, in a better light than Lavín [the rightwing candidate] all very paradoxical.
La Nacion, Argentina

fields.headline: Blair defends flu-battered NHS
fields.trailText: The health service is under "serious" pressure, Tony Blair told the Commons today, in a prime minister's question time dominated by the flu crisis.
fields.body:
The health service is under "serious" pressure, Tony Blair told the Commons today, in a prime minister's question time dominated by the flu crisis.

In the first question time clash of the new millennium, Mr Blair said that half of all intensive care beds were taken up by flu patients and the government acknowledged there were "capacity constraints".

The prime minister got in a dig at the opposition, saying: "The difference between this government and the previous government is that we recognise the constraints and we are tackling them."

Tory leader William Hague said it was time for the government to "wake up and recognise" that the NHS was not coping because of ministers' failure to prepare for the crisis.

"Now you are another Labour prime minister who says: 'Crisis what crisis?'" he told Mr Blair.

Mr Hague said the number of people waiting to see a hospital consultant has risen sharply at the same time as the government had increased the number of political advisers.

They were "more interested in spin doctors than real doctors," he said.

The prime minister accused the opposition leader of "opportunistically" trying to make political capital out of the problem.

Tory MP Tim Loughton asked why the government's health service promises were not being felt in his constituency of East Worthing and Shoreham, an area of southern England with a higher than average number of pensioners.

Mr Blair said that there were more beds this year than last and that waiting lists were 80,000 below the level they were under the last administration.

However, he added that it took time to train doctors and nurses and that it would take time for the government reforms to filter through to the hospital wards.

Liberal Democrat leader Charles Kennedy rounded on the government and asked whether in the light of the flu crisis Mr Blair's promises to save the NHS now looked "very threadbare indeed".

Mr Blair said: "We are putting in extra investment... it has to be done stage by stage, consistent with the running of a sound economy."

In other questions, Mr Blair attacked English nationalism and told the Commons that he was sure that the thoughts of the whole house were with the families of the seven fishermen missing off the Isle of Man.

"Our profound sympathy is with them all," he said.

fields.headline: Straw's a law unto himself
fields.standfirst: Francis Wheen on: Trials and errors at the home office | The South Bank bubble bursts
fields.trailText: Francis Wheen on: Trials and errors at the home office | The South Bank bubble bursts
fields.body:
Who are these woolly minded lawyers and Hampstead liberals that oppose Jack Straw's splendid plan to save time and money by abolishing a defendant's right to jury trial on such piffling charges as theft and burglary? It's time to name and shame the guilty wimps.

Here's one. The Times of July 7 1993 carried a feature by Gareth Williams QC, a former chairman of the bar, reviewing the report of the royal commission on criminal justice. "The serious blemish in an otherwise admirable report," he wrote, "is the proposal that in those cases where the accused can now opt for trial by jury, this right should be removed ... This would be madness. There are delays and inefficiencies at the moment, but the way to deal with them is to improve the mechanics, not to erode a fundamental liberty... I hope that parliament will refuse to countenance legislation of this kind." In an interview at the time, he added that there were "no circumstances" under which he could agree to such a proposal. "I am adamantly opposed."

Gareth Williams QC, otherwise known as Lord Williams of Mostyn, is now the government's attorney general, and adamantly in favour of what he once called "madness".

Williams was not the only lawyer to criticise the royal commission. The then shadow home secretary, a promising young barrister, said it was "totally unsatisfactory" to prevent defendants from choosing trial by jury. "Fundamental rights to justice cannot be driven by administrative convenience."

Tony Blair (for it was he) is now, I believe, some sort of minister, and apparently no longer cares two hoots about fundamental rights to justice.

But why go all the way back to 1993? Here's what another Labour lawyer told MPs as recently as February 27 1997: "Let me now refer to [Michael Howard's] proposal to end the right of many defendants to elect for trial by jury, even though they may face charges of dishonesty, and their reputation and their whole future may be at stake. Surely, cutting down the right to jury trial, making the system less fair, is not only wrong but short-sighted and likely to prove ineffective. Is it not the case that that is not only the view of the opposition and many practitioners and jurists but was the view of the home secretary, at least until today?"

The speaker was, as you may have guessed, Jack Straw, who now sneers at "practitioners and jurists" who still believe what he believed three years ago. But did he really believe it, even then? According to the old right-wing joke, a neo-conservative is a liberal who has been mugged. In Straw's case, however, there was no need for a mugging: he never had a liberal bone in his body.

Even as a student in the 60s he was a grim authoritarian, calling for crackdowns on cannabis users. When he became an Islington councillor in the early 70s, he had an ingenious idea for dealing with violence on local housing estates: set up impromptu "tenants' courts" which could run troublesome neighbours out of town. Even some of the most grizzled reactionaries in the Labour group were gobsmacked, and gently informed Straw - supposedly a qualified lawyer - that there might be a few legal problems with his lynch-mob scheme. "I don't think he's moved on at all," one old Islingtonian told me this week. "Kangaroo courts are still all right by Jack."

There have been some pretty ghastly home secretaries in the past 50 years or so - David Maxwell Fyfe, Henry Brooke, David Waddington, Michael Howard - but none, I think, quite so proudly contemptuous of liberty. What makes Straw's behaviour all the more odd is that there's no need for it, since his reasons for curbing jury trial are manifestly bogus.

Even if Straw's justifications were true, they would be outweighed by the need to preserve the right to be tried by one's peers. He may think that charges of theft, burglary or handling stolen goods are trivial, but for those in the dock they can be career-shattering and life-wrecking. As he said in February 1997: "If a police officer, an MP or even a secretary of state were charged with an offence of dishonesty, would they not insist upon being tried by a jury? If that is the case, why should others be denied that right of election?"

But his justifications are not true, and he should certainly be hauled up on a charge of dishonesty if he persists with them. The claim that his "reform" will save £100m a year has been thoroughly exploded, not least in a Guardian article last November by Professor Lee Bridges of Warwick university.

Straw's suggestion that more and more defendants are "abusing the system" by insisting on their right to jury trial is equally false. As David Wolchover and Anthony Heaton-Armstrong have pointed out in the New Law Journal, the proportion of cases committed to crown courts because the defendants elect for jury trial - rather than because magistrates decline jurisdiction - actually fell from 53% to 28% over the past decade.

If Straw wants to deal with "inefficiencies" in the justice system he should turn his attention to the real culprits. Only last month, the national audit office revealed that delay and incompetence at magistrates' courts wasted more than £40m a year, of which half "resulted from failures within, or in liaison between, the police, the crown prosecution service and the courts or other public bodies".

Why, then, is Straw so determined to curtail trial by jury instead? Because he can, I guess; and because he gets a kick out of annoying Hampstead liberals. When two journalists from the Observer interviewed the home secretary last autumn, they pointed out that sacrificing liberty and justice in the name of efficiency was the argument of the tyrant: Mussolini made the trains run on time. Most Labour politicians would be deeply offended by the comparison with a fascist dictator, but not our Jack. He merely smiled, apparently happy to take it as a compliment. "Well," he said, "I am trying to make the courts run on time."

Like Mussolini, however, Straw won't stop there. As he said last year: "It must be possible to change one's mind." He has already abandoned his commitment to a full-blooded freedom of information bill, his opposition to "three strikes and you're out", his promise that asylum-seekers would not have their benefits withdrawn, his conviction that privatised prisons are "morally repugnant", his distaste for "Draconian" prevention of terrorism acts - and, of course, his belief that people "whose whole future may be at stake" should be able to choose trial by jury.

Is anything sacred? I assume that he won't change his mind on capital punishment. Looking at his record so far, however, I wouldn't bet on it.

Forever blowing bubbles

Congratulations to the Guardian for alerting us to a "malevolent and unscrupulous" plot by right-wingers who are spreading the message that the dome is not just a fiasco but also "somehow emblematic of the whole New Labour approach".

But, er, surely the dome is emblematic of New Labour: elegant and photogenic on the outside (it reminds me of the flying island of Laputa) but filled with random, weird and makeshift projects, more like the Academy of Lagado.

Monday's editorial was particularly severe on a Daily Mail hack who had mentioned the South Sea Bubble: again, however, I can see certain similarities. It is more than five years since Tony Blair started building his new party, but he still hasn't found anything really eye-catching to put in it.

Although the finest policy-designers in the land have been hired to fill the wow-shaped hole in New Labour's heart, none of their Big Ideas has pulled in the punters - the Stakeholding Zone, the Young Country, Connexity, Communitarianism. These airy schemes and scams remind me of the prospectuses issued at the time of the South Sea Bubble by entrepreneurs who promised to make "air pumps for the brain" or "a wheel of perpetual motion".

My favourite is the company formed "for carrying on an undertaking of great advantage but no one to know what it is". Has there ever been a better description of the Third Way?

fields.headline: The big picture
fields.standfirst: Small isn't always beautiful when it comes to conservation. Jonathan Theobald reports on an ambitious plan to expand Britain's oldest national nature reserve.
fields.trailText: Small isn't always beautiful when it comes to conservation. Jonathan Theobald reports on an ambitious plan to expand Britain's oldest national nature reserve.
fields.body:
The National Trust is considering buying and flooding some of the costliest farming land in Britain. It is a move that signals a radical shift in ecological thinking which argues that our existing nature reserves are failing to protect nature.

The plan is the brainchild of Adrian Colston, manager of the trust's national nature reserve at Wicken Fen. He wants to buy 22 square miles of adjoining Cambridgeshire farmland and flood it. If it is approved, the new reserve would be nearly four times the size of the trust's recent Snowdon purchase.

Colston argues: "Small is no longer beautiful. Big is better. Conservationists are used to dealing with reserves of 35 acres, but they are too fragile. If a cow dungs in the wrong place or someone treads on the wrong spot, a rare animal or plant can be wiped out."

Wicken is hardly small now. It is a glorious, 800-acre remnant of one of the first UK habitats to be almost completely destroyed - the great primeval fen that once extended 100 miles from Cambridge to beyond Lincoln.

It was established a century ago and is celebrated as Britain's oldest nature reserve - and one of the best protected. Blessed with one of the largest species lists of any UK reserve - 212 different spiders, 1,000 moths and 1,700 flies - it is biodiversity writ large. Fauna and flora are so profuse that much remains unnamed, even though scientists have been studying the area since the early 19th century, when a young Charles Darwin was drawn there by a passion for beetles.

Yet all is not well. Despite maximum legal protection and the best efforts of the trust, species are steadily disappearing. A bleak catalogue of losses includes five out of 19 dragonflies, four of Darwin's beetles, water vole, Montagu's harrier, marsh warbler, short-eared owl and 35 flowering plants. A fifth beetle is in jeopardy, and the list grows longer year by the year.

The problem is that it is an island in a sea of hostile farmland - a difficulty faced by many other reserves. The spectacular swallowtail butterfly, for which Wicken was once famous, is a case in point. Now the only UK population survives on the Norfolk Broads, 60 miles away. With Wicken's surrounding fields producing five crops of lettuce a year and each crop typically sprayed five times with insecticide, the chances of the swallowtail re-establishing itself are remote.

One of the paradoxes of British nature reserves is their dependence on unnatural human intervention. Centuries of farming and land drainage have left Wicken 12 feet higher than adjoining land. The reserve is only saved from drying out by a plastic membrane buried 12 feet deep, the length of a mile-long boundary.

The membrane may be unique to Wicken, but hugely laborious tasks, such as clearing scrub and preventing sedge fen being overrun by woodland, are typical of work on other reserves.

Colston believes that bigger reserves will make wildlife much more sustainable, and the reserves themselves much more natural. He aims to leave the control of vegetation to wild cattle and horses. The process of wildlife management will be reduced, and natural processes will be allowed to let rip.

"At present we manage Wicken for a very specific set of objectives," he says. "But, having frozen everything in aspic, we're now being told climate change could cause all the interest to be lost. With a big area, things can change and we can be much less rigid."

He is inspired by the Netherlands' Oostvardersplassen, a vast and fantastic landscape of reedbeds, marsh and open water that has drawn exceptional populations of rarities since its 22 square miles were flooded in the 1960s. "What strikes you there is the sheer abundance of everything," Colston says. "Things that were hanging on by their fingertips have become well established and sustainable."

Wicken is not the only place where conservationists want to create wetlands. The World Wide Fund for Nature has funded a £20,000 feasibility study to help the wildlife trusts create a second Cambridgeshire super-reserve at Whittlesey Mere, the last of the big fens. Peterborough museum keeps a sea eagle shot there in 1848. But drainage three years later left no place either for sea eagles or their once abundant prey, and is seen by one leading ecologist as one of the greatest environmental calamities ever to hit Britain.

The wildlife trusts are also working with the Environment Agency and the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds to restore five square miles of arable desert at Longden Marsh, Worcestershire.

"If a country like the Netherlands, which is about the size of East Anglia, can do this, then so can we," says Derek Moore, the wildlife trusts' conservation director. "You have to have a vision, and if we're really going to be serious about biodiversity and the recovery of vanishing species then we need to stop mucking around with little patches.

"We'll be able to bring back some of the species that have disappeared. Some, such as spoonbills and bitterns, could return naturally, but it also gives us the chance to reintroduce creatures like the beaver."

Neither Colston nor Moore expects quick success: Colston is thinking in terms of 100 years; Moore reckons on 30-50 years for Whittlesey Mere. But they believe that circumstances are on their side. The value of fenland is un-likely to stay high because the peat which makes the fens so productive is vanishing, steadily destroyed by farming.

Over the next 50 to 100 years, internationally protected nature reserves along the east coast are expected to be lost to rising seas, and government will be under pressure to find land to compensate. With increasing pressure on flood defences, which cost up to £3m a mile, cost benefit analyses are unlikely to justify in perpetuity the use of taxpayers' money to protect land below sea level, such as that at Wicken and Whittlesey.

Restoring fenland by letting water on to the land is the easy part, because wetlands develop remarkably fast. The challenge is to win over landowners whose families have prospered since the time of Charles I, when government handouts enabled the first massive arrow-straight channels to be carved through East Anglia.

"There are a lot of practicalities to sort out and it will take a lot of money," Colston says. "But we only need one farmer coming to the end of his career to say 'I fancy that', and we're on our way."

fields.headline: Serious fun
fields.standfirst: The success of Britain's only children's museum has inspired a plan to spread the joy of curiosity into the community, reports Betty Jerman
fields.trailText: The success of Britain's only children's museum has inspired a plan to spread the joy of curiosity into the community, reports Betty Jerman.
fields.body:
There are, around the world, about 400 children's museums - not to be confused with museums of childhood and their toy collections - yet Britain has only one. In the 1980s, the Children's Experience Centre, a consortium of individuals and organisations inspired by child-dedicated museums in the US, campaigned for 12 years - backed by the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation and a government grant - to find money and a site.

Eventually, Eureka! the Museum for Children was purpose-built in Halifax and opened in 1992 through the generosity of Vivien Duffield. Wherever you go in it - among Me and My Body, Living and Working Together, Things and Invent, Create, Communicate, or the Under-5s' Jungle - you can touch, work, listen and smell, as well as look.

Now the Kids' Clubs Network is building on the museum's innovation and success by launching the concept of community-based Centres for Curiosity and Imagination, where families and children can learn about the world through fun and first-hand experiences. It envisages that these would "foster curiosity, imagination and creativity, new ways of thinking and learning, positive social interaction, self-esteem and motivation . . . crucial if a child is to fulfil his or her full potential."

The Gulbenkian Foundation has funded a project manager, while Marks & Spencer and the department for education and employment are supporting the publication of a guide and also a series of seminars.

The first seminar, in London, was attended by people involved with children in various ways - in child-orientated museums, local council education, child care, early years and culture officers, representatives from regeneration and community projects, government departments and major institutions.

A clear consensus emerged that such centres should not be rushed into but require careful planning. Important points raised included: that working across class and culture requires considerable skills; that dedicated staff and volunteers would need to be able to relate with the public; and that the range of activities might be expanded to bring in teenagers. There were also discussions about tapping funding and expertise, about involving the private sector, schools and community groups, and about the possible location of the centres - such as in schools, libraries and even in specially-fitted buses.

A further seminar will be held today in Sheffield, followed by Birmingham (February 2) and Newcastle (March 14). Another London event is likely, since the first was over-subscribed, and seminars will be organised in other locations, depending on demand - with contacts being welcomed from Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland as the project is extended. Training sessions will be organised as needed, and a website is to be set up, drawing on children's museums around the world.

Further information from Alison Coles, project manager, Centres for Curiosity and Imagination, Kids' Clubs Network, Bellerive House, 3 Muirfield Crescent, London E14 9SZ (tel: 0171-522 6919).

fields.headline: The twilight zones
fields.standfirst: Can the government really trace the route out of poverty on a map, or is money the root of inequality? Charlotte Denny reports
fields.trailText: Can the government really trace the route out of poverty on a map, or is money the root of inequality? Charlotte Denny reports.
fields.body:
So much for joined up government. Since the general election, Labour has established so many new community based anti-poverty schemes - 26 health action zones, 15 employment zones and 25 education action zones, not to mention the new deal for communities - that last year the department for the environment, transport and the regions was forced to ask the Ordnance Survey to map where they all are so it can check how much the zones overlap.

Labour has taken the fight against deprivation back to communities, in a return to 1960s style area-based anti-poverty programmes. Inside the zones, health, education and employment policy makers have freedom to design local solutions to local problems. So, for instance, in the employment zones, Job Centre advisers, in consultation with their clients, can devise individ ual packages of training, community work or job subsidies.

The money involved so far is trivial compared with the government's main income support and social services programmes, but policy makers are starting to question whether it is being well spent.

In the latest issue of New Economy, the journal of the left- leaning think tank, the Institute for Public Policy Research, Mark Kleinman, a social policy lecturer at the London School of Economics, concludes that, at best, area- based initiatives can support a nationwide anti-poverty strategy. They are no substitute for a national approach.

One of the problems with an area-based approach is that it assumes the poor all live together. But as critics pointed out the last time a government tried to target poverty on a map, unless the net is cast extremely widely more deprived people will live outside the target zones than within them. When Harold Wilson's government introduced Educational Priority Areas in the 1960s, it was noted that for every two children who were at EPA schools, five were outside them.

The same is true today. While concentrated pockets of deprivation do exist, more poor people live outside these areas than live within them.

The government's own figures back this conclusion. In 1997, two-thirds of all unemployed people lived outside the 44 most deprived districts, as identified by the Social Exclusion Unit.

Area-based approaches could still be an effective weapon for the government if there was any evidence to suggest that living alongaside other poor people intensifies poverty. But when economists have examined whether where people live is an important determinant of whether or not they are poor, they have failed to find any connection. Family characteristics - such as parents' income and education - are much more important in determining whether children grow up poor.

Some policymakers suggest that concentrated deprivation cuts people off from mainstream society - in the government's jargon, they are the "socially excluded" - the job, health, housing and income poor. To quote one government minister, they are "people who have lost hope, trapped in fatalism. They are today's and tomorrow's underclass."

Tackling concentrations of poverty might be a way of breaking this cycle of exclusion. But, as Kleinman points out, there is no evidence to suggest that the resi dents in areas of concentrated poverty are cut off from the mainstream by anything except their lack of income. There is no evidence that their norms and values differ from the rest of society.

The remarkable improvement in the US and UK labour markets over the last five years proves this point. As unemployment has fallen to 30-year lows in the US and 20-year lows in the UK, unemployment among even the most disadvantaged groups has shrunk. While unemployment rates among ethnic minorities, young people and unskilled workers remain higher, the most important determinant of whether or not they find a job is the state of the overall economy.

Kleinman says national policies on education, employment, housing, social security and families will have far more impact on the life chances of people living in the poorest areas than local policies. The working families tax credit has already begun redistributing income to those at the bottom of the pile.

If national policies are more important than local initiatives, is there any role at all for area-based policies? Kleinman suggests there are several. They can supplement national strategies and provide opportunity for innovation. Improving access to government services, which are worst in the most deprived areas, ought to be a priority for its own sake.

But perhaps the most useful idea to come out of the proliferation of zones may be the importance of local particpation in decision making. It is one of the paradoxes of the poverty debate that while in the development world, a consensus is emerging among official donors and NGOs that the best anti-poverty programmes are those developed in conjunction with the poor themselves, this is not a lesson many western governments have applied at home.

fields.headline: VAT cat Britain
fields.standfirst: Health authorities, local government and organisations receiving lottery money are unhappy with their high tax burden, as Chris Wheal reports
fields.trailText: Health authorities, local government and organisations receiving lottery money are unhappy with their high tax burden, as Chris Wheal reports.
fields.body:
There's daylight robbery going on across the public services - and the villain is VAT. Customs robs charities of more than £400m in non-recoverable VAT each year according to the Charities Tax Reform Group.

In the NHS, it is worse. Graham Tabb, financial services manager of the Cheshire Health Agency, chairs the VAT technical sub-committee of the Healthcare Financial Management Association. He says 95% of an NHS trust's VAT is irrecoverable, and for health authorities that rises to 99%.

Worse still is national lottery money. If the organisation receiving the grant cannot recover the VAT then the grant has the VAT added to it. In other words, the lottery giveth, and customs taketh away. Customs says it doesn't know how much lottery money it takes, but the latest lottery figures to April last year show a total of £10.85bn had been allocated to the good causes (28% of the ticket price) since the lottery began and, of that, £6.3bn had been spent. If just half the projects so far had non-recoverable VAT that would mean customs getting more than £420m, which is on top of the £660m a year the treasury already takes as its 13% lottery tax.

According to Tabb, VAT has also been used to bash the unions. "Maggie [Thatcher] was trying to crush the unions by putting things out to tender and contracting out services, but outside firms were costing more than in-house teams because they had to charge VAT and the NHS couldn't recover it," he says.

The general rule of VAT is that it can only be recovered on business activities, which, for the NHS, include running car parks and some other paid-for activities. Medical treatment is exempt.

To counter that, the government introduced special categories, covering all the areas it wanted contracted out, and allowed the NHS, and other central government departments, to reclaim the VAT in these areas.

That way, the private sector companies were no longer 17.5% more expensive and could undercut the in-house bids. These are not the rantings of the Socialist Workers Party. In fact, presented with Tabb's analysis, customs officials agreed. Customs even lists how much this bullying tactic costs in its annual report - £1.75bn in 1998/99 alone.

Even local government, which has its own specially formulated and generous VAT rules, is not happy. When VAT was being introduced in Parliament in 1972, a slip of the tongue by a cabinet minister that VAT would not impact on the rates (now council tax) caused civil servants to rush out and redraft the rules. Unusually, councils can reclaim VAT on their normal activities, even though these are not business activities and should be exempt. Latest customs figures show that this benefited local government to the tune of £3.3bn in 1998/99.

But when councils get involved in spending other money, such as lottery grants,they have another set of rules allowing it to reclaim VAT on these activities too, providing the total reclaimed does not go over 5% of the council's total VAT bill. Colin Ager, director of the tax advisory service run by Price Waterhouse Coopers for the Chartered Institute of Public Finance and Accountancy, says making sure councils don't breach the 5% limit is vital. If a council goes over the limit, it loses all that extra recovered VAT.

"You have to balance the whole of the authority's expenditure programme, and it drives you to do things you don't want to do," Ager says. Councils end up having to charge VAT on some things, such as small business units, when they would rather not. By charging VAT, the council can reclaim the input VAT without affecting its 5% threshold.

Ian Fleming, director of the Institute of Indirect Taxation, says the anomalies in VAT and the public services make no sense when explained to members of the public. "If you go to the doctor's and get a prescription, it is a zero-rated supply so the high street chemist can reclaim the input VAT on the drugs," he says. "But in a hospital, you don't get a prescription, so there's no supply to you, which means the pharmacy cannot reclaim the VAT on the same drugs. One hospital did try to set up their pharmacy as a separate business to charge the wards for drugs but customs declared it tax-avoidance and won the case."

Charities collecting money and spending it on their charitable aims are not making taxable supplies, so cannot reclaim VAT. If they have business ventures,selling products to raise money, they can reclaim the VAT. That means they have to calculate how much of their phone bills and stationery budgets and gas and electric bills were for the business so they can reclaim that portion of the VAT.

Keith Warner, a partner with accountants Horwarth Clark Whitehill, flags up another anomaly. If a charity buys blankets to send to a disaster abroad, it can reclaim the VAT because it is exporting. If it buys blankets for use in the UK, it cannot reclaim the VAT. Jim Pinder, VAT partner with BDO Stoy Hayward, says: "Charities have a lot of exempt activities and a lot of non-business activities, so they get two bites at the cherry of non-recoverable VAT."

Customs puts up a spirited defence: local government should shut up because it already gets a fantastic deal. Customs points out that the judge in a test case involving Haringey council and Alexandra Palace said the 5% special allowance was too generous already. And businesses already moan that councils have a competitive advantage through being able to reclaim VAT without having to charge it.

Charities in the UK get a better deal than almost anywhere else in Europe, the officials say. VAT is now fiercely policed by the EU because it falls under the sixth directive. If Britain fell in line with Germany's VAT rules, charities wouldn't know what had hit them. And the NHS should stop trying tax avoidance schemes as its funding from central government already contains a substantial sum that recognises the fact that it cannot reclaim VAT. If it starts to reclaim more, then central funding will be cut accordingly.

Tabb has an even more radical proposition: tell the NHS it cannot reclaim any VAT at all and it could sack thousands of admin staff and stop using tax consultants who, between them, often cost more than the VAT they reclaim.

Sack accountants? That really would be a crime.

fields.headline: New age travails
fields.standfirst: As families face poverty, divorce and disintegration, growing numbers of children are being reaised by their grandparents. But, ask Michael Young and Jean Stogdon, where is the help and recognition for these invaluable older carers?
fields.trailText: As families face poverty, divorce and disintegration, growing numbers of children are being reaised by their grandparents. But, ask Michael Young and Jean Stogdon, where is the help and recognition for these invaluable older carers?
fields.body:
The main difference in being old is that we can have a bit more leisure, a bit more choice about what we do with ourselves. We are given a precious last chance - if only we can avoid poverty - to cure ourselves of the pandemic hurry sickness before we subside into rest. We even have a little time to experience education for education's sake, not because it will qualify us for a more monied and a more hectic life.

But life cannot be given over entirely to the delights of non-vocational education and to relief from the pressures of a competitive market. New pleasures are being combined with new duties, particularly because ever increasing numbers of grandparents are becoming more involved with the rearing of grandchildren than they were, and some are becoming active parents for a second time round.

The need is obvious. Marriage has become less popular, divorce more so. There are more and more single parents and, above all, more children in distress because their parents have broken apart.

Some geneticists consider that women experience the menopause in order that they can assist in the survival of their descendants who are not their children but their grandchildren.

Ample evidence for the growing modern practice comes not from Britain but, as so often, from the US. A report by the US census bureau last year showed that 4.7m grandparents live with their grandchildren - and this does not include the millions more who are, in one way or another, caring for grandchildren without actually living with them.

Out of the 4.7m grandparents, 3.7m are raising them in their own home. One million others are living with their grandchildren, because they need to play an active part in supporting them.

Climbing divorce rates, teenage pregnancies and drug use are cited as the main reasons for grand-parents being in a supportive role.

The US is fortunate in having a more impressive array of support groups than in Britain. There are between 600 and 700 active local grandparent groups which provide all manner of services for their members, including representing them to the local authorities.

In addition, there are strong grandparent lobbies at Washington and in individual states. The politically powerful American Association of Retired Persons, with more than 34m members, is taking an interest in its grand-parent members, and more financial support is coming to those in poverty.

The part played by grandparents is generally respected and acknowledged in the US; they are seen as an indispensable resource for children who would otherwise be parentless.

Social workers in the US also hold the view, distinct from their counterparts in Britain, that grandparents should be considered first - although they are, of course, not always suitable - as foster parents. The old myth lingers in Britain that if the parents have in some way failed, it must be the fault of the grandparents in not bringing up their own children well enough - creating a sort of guilt by association which is quite unjustified.

A recent report from the Child Welfare League of America spells out the advantages - apart from avoiding the stigma of being a foster child - for the children being cared for by relatives:

* Enabling children to live with persons whom they know and trust;

* Reducing the trauma children may experience when they are placed with persons who initially are unknown to them;

* Reinforcing children's sense of identity and self-esteem;

* Facilitating children's connections to their siblings;

* Encouraging families to consider and rely on their own family members as resources;

* Enhancing children's opportunities to stay connected to their own communities and promoting community responsibility for children and families;

* Strengthening the ability of families to give children the support they need.

There are English exceptions, of course. In Plymouth, for example, the city council's social services department has taken an interest. One of their social workers, David Pitcher, published a report in 1999, called When Grandparents Care. He interviewed grandparents who had their grandchildren living with them after a case conference or court had found there was a risk of abuse as long as the child remained in the parental home.

It was not always easy going for the grandparents. They did not have as much energy for rough and tumble and dealing with schools as when they were younger; the grandchildren could be less respectful towards them; and drugs and violence in the streets were common concerns. But the comments were overwhelmingly favourable, ranging from: "They've kept me young" to "Whatever price I've had to pay, it's been worth it."

In Britain, the first full study of grandparenting using a large representative sample has just been completed by Geoff Dench, of the Institute of Community Studies, in conjunction with the National Centre for Social Research. The results show that the proportion of children living with grandparents is much lower in Britain than in the US. But in all sorts of other ways the grandparents of Britain are doing a great deal for their grandchildren - especially when the parental family is breaking up.

The evidence begs certain questions. Why grandparents are not paid when they step in, in some instances giving up work to make caring possible; and why do they get nothing extra for grandchild care, even when the grandparents are on income support?

What we are seeing is a revival in the importance of the extended family. This is going on alongside a vital change in its structure. When studies of families in Bethnal Green, in the East End of London, were first being done in the 1950s, the extended family had a very large lateral extension. Some people had dozens, even hundreds, of relatives living locally - married brothers and sisters and their nephews and nieces and all the in-laws. Children were surrounded by aunts and uncles and cousins of different degrees.

As fertility has continued to fall and families have become smaller, the lateral has given way to the vertical. More people live longer, so there are more grandparents lasting longer and more great-grandparents still alive. The uncles and aunts have to some extent been replaced by the grandparents and, when there are stepchildren, the numbers of grandparents a child possesses can be more than four. A new cross-generational extended family is coming into existence.

This new kind of family pattern has profound consequences for the society of the new century. Alongside the more traditional family, there will be growing numbers of grandparent/ grandchild families taking over from the parents who are bearers of the children.

Many parent-grandparent agreements are made individually wherever both parties are willing. Parents might be working and have some freedom while they are still relatively young and not take on parental responsibilities until later.

Meanwhile, there is much that can be done by government if it is willing to support grandparents. The Children Act of 1989 recognised that grandparents are "family". As a result, some children who would otherwise be institutionalised in homes or placed with unrelated foster parents, have been placed with grandparents instead. But the policy is still very patchy.

A good deal has also been done to provide finance for childcare. But although grandparents commonly act as child carers when their sons or daughters are working, they cannot receive any allowance for all that they do - even if they are on income support themselves. We are given a precious last chance - if only we can avoid poverty - to cure ourselves of the pandemic hurry sickness before we subside into rest. We even have a little time to experience education for education's sake, not because it will qualify us for a more monied and a more hectic life. But life cannot be given over entirely to the delights of non-vocational education and to relief from the pressures of a competitive market. New pleasures are being combined with new duties, particularly because ever increasing numbers of grandparents are becoming more involved with the rearing of grandchildren than they were, and some are becoming active parents for a second time round. The need is obvious. Marriage has become less popular, divorce more so. There are more and more single parents and, above all, more children in distress because their parents have broken apart. Some geneticists consider that women experience the menopause in order that they can assist in the survival of their descendants who are not their children but their grandchildren. Ample evidence for the growing modern practice comes not from Britain but, as so often, from the US. A report by the US census bureau last year showed that 4.7m grandparents live with their grandchildren - and this does not include the millions more who are, in one way or another, caring for grandchildren without actually living with them. Out of the 4.7m grandparents, 3.7m are raising them in their own home. One million others are living with their grandchildren, because they need to play an active part in supporting them. Climbing divorce rates, teenage pregnancies and drug use are cited as the main reasons for grand-parents being in a supportive role. The US is fortunate in having a more impressive array of support groups than in Britain. There are between 600 and 700 active local grandparent groups which provide all manner of services for their members, including representing them to the local authorities. In addition, there are strong grandparent lobbies at Washington and in individual states. The politically powerful American Association of Retired Persons, with more than 34m members, is taking an interest in its grand-parent members, and more financial support is coming to those in poverty. The part played by grandparents is generally respected and acknowledged in the US; they are seen as an indispensable resource for children who would otherwise be parentless. Social workers in the US also hold the view, distinct from their counterparts in Britain, that grandparents should be considered first - although they are, of course, not always suitable - as foster parents. A recent report from the Child Welfare League of America spells out the advantages - apart from avoiding the stigma of being a foster child - for the children being cared for by relatives: * Enabling children to live with persons whom they know and trust; * Reducing the trauma children may experience when they are placed with persons who initially are unknown to them; * Reinforcing children's sense of identity and self-esteem; * Facilitating children's connections to their siblings; * Encouraging families to consider and rely on their own family members as resources; * Enhancing children's opportunities to stay connected to their own communities and promoting community responsibility for children and families; * Strengthening the ability of families to give children the support they need. There are English exceptions, of course. In Plymouth, for example, the city council's social services department has taken an interest. One of their social workers, David Pitcher, published a report in 1999, called When Grandparents Care. He interviewed grandparents who had their grandchildren living with them after a case conference or court had found there was a risk of abuse as long as the child remained in the parental home. It was not always easy going for the grandparents. They did not have as much energy for rough and tumble and dealing with schools as when they were younger; the grandchildren could be less respectful towards them; and drugs and violence in the streets were common concerns. But the comments were overwhelmingly favourable, ranging from: "They've kept me young" to "Whatever price I've had to pay, it's been worth it." In Britain, the first full study of grandparenting using a large representative sample has just been completed by Geoff Dench, of the Institute of Community Studies, in conjunction with the National Centre for Social Research. The results show that the proportion of children living with grandparents is much lower in Britain than in the US. But in all sorts of other ways the grandparents of Britain are doing a great deal for their grandchildren - especially when the parental family is breaking up. The evidence begs certain questions. Why grandparents are not paid when they step in, in some instances giving up work to make caring possible; and why do they get nothing extra for grandchild care, even when the grandparents are on income support? What we are seeing is a revival in the importance of the extended family. This is going on alongside a vital change in its structure. When studies of families in Bethnal Green, in the East End of London, were first being done in the 1950s, the extended family had a very large lateral extension. A new cross-generational extended family is coming into existence. This new kind of family pattern has profound consequences for the society of the new century. Alongside the more traditional family, there will be growing numbers of grandparent/ grandchild families taking over from the parents who are bearers of the children. Many parent-grandparent agreements are made individually wherever both parties are willing. Parents might be working and have some freedom while they are still relatively young and not take on parental responsibilities until later. fields.headline: Marshall law
fields.standfirst: David Walker meets the sociologist who has been put in charge of distributing £42m
fields.trailText: David Walker meets the sociologist who has been put in charge of distributing £42m.
fields.body:
Sloppy sociologists, unrigorous economists and illogical psychologists beware. The Oxford academic who is about to take over as new chief executive of the government social research quango is a hardliner. If research applications to the Economic and Social Research Council (ESRC) do not pass muster as science - meeting the same basic tests as bids to the physics or biology research councils - they will not get funding, however "relevant" their subject matter.

The man in question is Gordon Marshall, a leading sociologist and a fellow at Nuffield College, the postgraduate centre for social studies. In Oxford and previously at Bath and Essex universities, the 47-year-old Scot's concerns are close to Labour's heart.

His research has focused on social class, income distribution and inequality. If he was not off this month to run the ESRC, he would be embarking on a £250,000 study questioning whether globalisation is all it is cracked up to be - in particular, whether it has changed the reference points we use when comparing our pay packets with other people's.

Marshall, who is on unpaid leave from the college, claims that his political values are private and irrelevant to the job of overseeing the ESRC's £42m annual research programme. His mission is to protect social science; no ESRC project, he pledges, will be open to the charge that it is not methodologically sound or that its numbers don't add up.

His conception of the ESRC is diametrically opposed to that of Sir Keith Joseph, the former Tory education secretary, who insisted in the early eighties that the old Social Science Research Council change its name, on the grounds that what it did was not science.

Marshall, a lad o'pairts from the Falkirk area, who graduated in sociology from the brand new University of Stirling in the early seventies, cut his academic teeth with a study of whether Max Weber's famous thesis about the origins of capitalism lying in the consciences of Calvinists actually worked in his native country. (He concluded it did.) Since then, apart from his empirical work on international comparisons of social justice, he has compiled an Oxford dictionary of sociology and a volume in praise of his discipline, -prompted, he says, by unjust and ill-informed criticism of sociologists in the media.

Marshall is not going into battle for a single discipline, but for social studies as a whole. He will address, for example, the concern among economists about the brain drain from their ranks to the City. The ESRC is plugged into a network of researchers and opinion leaders whose views it pays attention to in deciding on its programmes and themes. Marshall is keen to maximise the scope of the ESRC in responding to bids for grants from academics to do "blue skies" research.

He gives the example of work done nearly 30 years ago by his Nuffield colleague John Goldthorpe on social classification and mobility, which resurfaced in the nineties as the basis for the official government redefinition of social background.

Immediate policy relevance cannot be the only criterion for judging what the ESRC should support - a view shared by many of his academic colleagues.

Professor David Rose, of Essex University, says, "If it's not good science, it is no use to users anyway." Dr Janet Lewis, head of research at the Joseph Rowntree Foundation, says problems sometimes arise over how data is interpreted, when people take results out of context. She suggests that the ESRC might take more of a role over the general standards of social research, whoever pays for it. That might require the ESRC, for example, to criticise what government departments do with the large amount of social and economic work they commission.

Marshall says he knows Whitehall well enough by proxy - his partner is a civil servant - but accepts he will be on a learning curve for those parts of the ESRC job which bring him into close contact with ministers, and the press.

He was appointed by the office of science and technology, which enjoys a fair degree of autonomy within the department of trade and industry. It was not "political" and certainly was not approved as such by Number 10. It is fair to say that the Nuffield idea of sociology is not entirely that espoused by the prime minister's guru, Tony Giddens, director of the London School of Economics. Marshall is diplomatic. Applications for grants to study globalisation by the apostle of the third way will be treated strictly on their merits, he says.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: Hats off to Leigh Environmental | Biosafety protocol | Global Climate Coalition
fields.body:
Hats off to Leigh Environmental, who have started the new year with a record that few other corporates are likely to match this year. The giant landfill company likes to maintain it is environmentally responsible and has never hesitated to reach for its lawyers if anyone suggested it was not. But it has now admitted falsifying a staggering 252 scientific reports out of 517 it had to send to the Environment Agency about what it was putting into its site at Coalmoor, near Telford, a few years ago. A two-year investigation by the agency found that Leigh had lied about the levels of cyanide, mercury and other dangerous wastes going in, and also about the amount of liquids that were leaching out. A Telford court heard last week that one man in the company's Yorkshire office was entirely responsible, that no one else knew what was going on and that the company was really sorry. Hmm. A fine of £87,500 - roughly zilch % of the company's annual profits - should really concentrate minds.

How different the world of international diplomacy is after the Seattle world trade conference may become clear in the next two weeks. From January 24-28, environment ministers (including, it is thought, Michael Meacher) will meet in Montreal to try to negotiate a "biosafety protocol", which would set international rules governing the transfer, handling and use of all GMOs. First some history: the Protocol fell apart last year because six countries who control the world market in GM crops (they include the US, Argentina, Australia and Canada) blocked it because they believed attempts by developing countries to introduce strict safety assessments and socio-economic considerations would endanger free trade. Not surprisingly, this "Miami group" wanted any GMO agreement to come under the wing of the WTO. Fast forward to today, when, after the spectacular shambles of Seattle, those who want strict regulation of GMOs are now stronger than ever and developing countries are more than ever resolved not to be bullied.

Small but significant happenings: Chrysler, one of the world's biggest car makers, joins the 21st century by leaving the Global Climate Coalition, the small bunch of corporates which, like flat earthers, still believe that burning fossil fuels has nothing to do with global warming.

The House of Commons environment committee has a long history of slapping governments, and yesterday's report on supermarkets was no exception. The MPs slammed the office of fair trading, the treasury and DTI for backing plans to relax planning rules governing the destroyers of so many small towns, yet failed to give Mr Blair a dishonourable mention. Was it not our great leader who appeased the supermarket lobbyists before the election and who recently smoothed the way for Wal-Mart? Was not, as Friends of the Earth remind us, planning policy discussed on both occasions?

fields.headline: Home front
fields.standfirst: Whether you are objecting to a bypass or simply fighting to set up house, Planning Aid guides people through the red tape, says Andy Farquarson
fields.trailText: Whether you are objecting to a bypass or simply fighting to set up house, Planning Aid guides people through the red tape, says Andy Farquarson.
fields.body:
Traveller Lenny Finney - "I'm a true-born gypsy" - had been on the road all his life. Seven years ago, however, he was forced to settle down due to ill health and bought a disused bee farm in open countryside near the river Severn. He obtained planning permission for two caravans and a permanent storage building for his carpet business. But when he applied for residential use of the building, the local planning authority turned him down flat.

"I'm not an educated man," admits Finney, "and I realised I needed some expert help." He was put in touch with a little-known organisation, Planning Aid. As its name suggests, the service is akin to legal aid: it offers free advice to individuals and community groups who otherwise could not afford professional help with planning applications, hearings and tribunals.

Planning Aid assigned a volunteer, Andrew Ford, to the case. Ford lectures in planning at the University of Central England and, recognising Finney had a strong case, prepared an appeal to the planning inspector.

Further information: Planning Aid, The Custard Factory, Gibbs Street, Birmingham B9 4AA (tel: 0121-693 1201).

"Ford was a marvel," enthuses Finney. "He worked really hard for my family, did all the paperwork, wrote out the application, found legal arguments in case law and came to all the meetings with me." As a result, the inspector found in Finney's favour and he now lives permanently in a neat bungalow.

"Often it can appear that the little guy has no chance against the system," says Ford, who has since been seconded for a year to Planning Aid by his university. "In this case, we helped Mr Finney participate fully in the planning process - and that is his right."

Exercising that right is not easy unaided. Planning regulation can be a bureaucratic nightmare, and public confidence in the system is at an all time low. Whether they are challenging by mass protests, such as Twyford Down or the Newbury bypass, or merely trying to sort out a neighbour's high-growing hedge or ugly house extension, people find the welter of arcane rules and procedures mystifying and opaque.

Established in 1973 by the Town and Country Planning Association, Planning Aid now comes under the aegis of the Royal Town Planning Institute (RTPI) and has 12 regional offices. Three are independent charities and nine are part of the RTPI, itself a registered charity. Nearly 1,000 planning professionals give their time as volunteers; between them, they handle 3,200 inquiries each year.

Robert Upton, general secretary of the RTPI, describes Planning Aid as "a core activity of the institute". But more needs to be done, he says. "We need to find more champions, more sources of funding, better means to communicate our purpose, and more volunteers."

Unsurprisingly, opposition to supermarket and out-of-town retail developments generates a significant proportion of Planning Aid's caseload. Opposing a major retail development requires a strong, well-argued case. Volunteer profes sionals can advise on grounds for objection, how to present the case and, in some instances, can attend the public inquiry as advocate for the objectors.

Take, for example, Asda's plan to open a major superstore near Solihull. "We opposed this from the word go," says Conrad James, of the nearby Hall Green residents' association. "There is a high proportion of retired people in this area and a new superstore would have had a disastrous impact on the local shops and small supermarkets they rely on."

The local authority turned down Asda's original application, but the company appealed to planning inspectors. The scale of the development led to it being referred to the secretary of state for a decision.

West Midlands Planning Aid helped the residents' association prepare their case. "There were several complicated planning issues," says WMPA's full-time co-ordinator, Sheena Terrace, a former local authority planning officer. "But the outcome hinged on the superstore's impact on local retailing generally." Eventually, the inspector dismissed Asda's appeal - a decision later confirmed by the secretary of state.

"We couldn't have beaten this application without Planning Aid," says James. "They were both professional and supportive." Terrace is pleased at the outcome, too: "The residents were at a disadvantage opposing such a major development," he says. "We tried to level the playing field for them."

Planning Aid's work is not entirely reactive and case-centred, however. During the last two years, the charity has launched two out reach projects to raise awareness of its services to target communities. A rural areas project, funded by the Countryside Agency and piloted in Herefordshire and Worcestershire, has involved liaison and training with parish councils, as well as local residents' groups. The emphasis is on community participation and education.

In marked contrast, Yorkshire Planning Aid has concentrated on inner-city Bradford. Its urban outreach programme is funded by EU money, the lottery and Bradford city council. Designed to involve, support and train disadvantaged groups, particularly ethnic minorities, the project's emphasis is on long-term regeneration projects.

"At the end of the day, our job is to lead ordinary people through the planning maze," says Planning Aid national co-ordinator, Ian Silvera. "We're open to anyone who cannot afford to hire planning consultants and we have the capacity to handle a lot more cases than we do at present. We'd like our service to become as widely known as legal aid."

fields.headline: Off cuts
fields.trailText: What could do more to dispel all those millennial hangovers than a shot of optimism about the future of civilisation? Mary Kaldor, director of the programme on global civil society at the London School of Economics, is happy to oblige.
fields.body:
What could do more to dispel all those millennial hangovers than a shot of optimism about the future of civilisation? Mary Kaldor, director of the programme on global civil society at the London School of Economics, is happy to oblige. Even though she's spent much of her academic career analysing the wars of the 20th century, she resolutely refuses to entertain post-modern cynicism about the myth of human progress and passionately argues that it is "terribly dangerous" for societies to abandon utopian projects.

Her "utopia" has, though, little in common with the sort of state-promoted ideologies that created the totalitarian horrors of the last century. What she and fellow members of the Centre for the Study of Global Governance at the LSE look forward to is the time when the rule of law and a respect for human rights applies not just within but across national boundaries. Although such rule of law might be guaranteed by organisations like the UN, the EU or an international criminal court, it would initially be promoted by groups of citizens in a variety of non-governmental groups - human rights organisations, church alliances, academic networks.

This notion of a "global civil society" owes much to the dialogue which took place in the 1980s between opposition groups in eastern Europe and the peace movement in western Europe. At the time, the east Europeans were recognising that the tyranny of the state could only be curbed by the growth of citizens groups which had alliances with similar groups in other countries.

These non-governmental organisations are a vital antidote to nationalism and dictatorship. "In Slovenia and Romania, there were post-communist dictators for a long time, but they were eventually defeated by active NGOs," she says. "It is where the civic sector is weak that dictators are effective."

Kaldor opposes her vision to the more pessimistic scenarios painted by other theorists of globalisation: the prospect of a new cold war or the anarchy which could arise from escalating inequality and environmental degradation. She envisages global civil society becoming as much a goal for the 21st century as prosperity was for the 20th. And how long will that take to achieve? Kaldor pauses for a second. "A few years," she says.

Laurie Taylor will be talking to Mary Kaldor about the prospects of a global civil society in Radio 4's Thinking Allowed at 4pm today.

fields.headline: Peddling poison
fields.standfirst:
Gender-bender chemicals are now inside all of us. Paul Brown reports on calls by scientists to control unknown and dangerous substances.
What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Gender-bender chemicals are now inside all of us. Paul Brown reports on calls by scientists to control unknown and dangerous substances.
fields.body:
It all sounds rather scary. "A hundred or more novel chemicals are swilling around in our bloodstreams, chemicals which, before this century, were not found in human beings. It makes all of us, as well as our children and grandchildren, a walking experiment - one with completely unknown results."

But John Peterson, director of the W. Alton Jones Foundation in the US, was not trying to frighten his audience. He was talking last month in Japan to a group of international scientists, already deeply concerned about the issue of chemical contamination of the human body. They agreed that the major danger seems to be hormone dis ruption, and that the most vulnerable group are as yet unborn children. Peterson said: "No mother anywhere on earth does not carry some of these compounds in her body."

When this first became an issue five years ago, research was concerned with what were dubbed "gender-benders" - chemicals capable of causing sex changes in fish and other animals exposed to them, otherwise known as endocrine disrupters. Was this the cause of low sperm counts in men, the increase in testicular cancer and male sex organ deformities? But by the time of the Japanese meeting last month, it was clear that many scientists believe that endocrine disrupters affect all aspects of human development from the embryo onwards, and in much lower concentrations than were thought possible.

The most disturbing research is on a substance called bisphenol A, a substance worth billions of pounds to the chemical industry. It is a building block of polycarbonate plastic, which means little until you realise that it is used for lining the inside of food cans - everything from baked beans to baby food.

Independent scientists say that, in experiments, this substance had a powerful effect on the reproductive tract of mice at levels thousands of times below what was thought possible. The chemical industry denies it, saying it has conducted the same experiments but cannot get the same results. Much is at stake for shareholders if the substance is banned.

Peterson was preaching to the converted in Japan. The 25 scientists gathered there were so concerned about the mass of new evidence before them that they demanded steps be taken to reduce the levels of the hundreds of untested chemicals in the environment. They were particularly anxious about organochlorines, used as pesticides in Britain on fruit and vegetables, because evidence already existed that they were harming wildlife.

At the same time as these scientists were sounding the alarm, the UK government was deciding not to ban either organochlorines or their replacements in certain applications - the equally controversial organophosphates. Although some new restrictions are being placed on organophosphate sheep dip, it is still likely to be widely used this summer.

The restrictions are on the type of container, after evidence that sheep farmers were badly affected if the concentrated form was spilt on the skin. The government has also finally agreed to investigate the 800-plus cases of people too crippled to work who blame exposure to sheep dip.

The ministry of agriculture's reluctance to delve too deeply into this area, following the disaster of BSE, has long held up progress, but at last the government is beginning to move.

Not so the European Union. After intense pressure before Christmas, some substances used as softening agents in plastic toys were banned. These were toys that children might suck, thereby ingesting hormone disrupting chemicals.

After this single action, the EU issued a strategy to deal with "substances which disrupt human and wildlife hormone systems". But while the EU statement looks to "identify appropriate policy action" and use the "precautionary principle", little further action is proposed - apart from more research.

Instead of compulsory action to cut the number of chemicals contaminating human blood the EU suggests "voluntary initiatives" to identify substitutes in order to eliminate or find replacements for substances of concern.

This does not satisfy Peterson, the 25 scientists or the campaigners in this field. The World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) said in a statement: "The commission's strategy is a limp response to a major problem - no doubt at least in part due to industries' pleas for minimal disruption to business as usual, and to the lack of resources being made available. One of the main thrusts of the commission's strategy is to list priority chemicals, but it is still not clear that exposure to these will be controlled or eliminated. There is no clear strategy to investigate the bulk of chemicals to which we are exposed for their ability to disrupt endocrine systems."

Gwynne Lyons, toxics and policy adviser to the WWF, said: "The European Commission seems content to focus only on the tip of the iceberg, but there is a need for a far more robust strategy to protect man and the environment from these gender bending and mind numbing chemicals."

Peterson has no doubts about the dangers either. "We know now that while there can be acute health impacts on adults with high exposures, the most vital are low level exposures in the womb. These have lifelong, debilitating impacts that erode the very essence of what a young baby can aspire to as he or she grows and matures and becomes a functioning - or dysfunctional - adult in society.

"All this is happening fast, certainly more rapidly than advances in our understanding of what we have done or what risks we have created. And because the scale is now global, we have no place to hide from our mistakes. No human baby has been born for several decades without experiencing measurable contamination in the womb. These are experiments whose results we will not know until it's too late to call them off."

But he and his colleagues in Japan urged politicians at least to stop the situation getting worse. As a minimum, they said, substances that accumulate in the human body and persist should be eliminated from products and commerce.

Peterson also suggested a shift of burden of proof for endocrine disrupting chemicals, even those that are not bio-accumulative and persistent. Currently, science has to prove them dangerous before they can be banned. If tests showed a compound carried plausible risk, commercial use exposing vulnerable populations should not be allowed until the material is proven as safe to people, he argued.

fields.headline: Chain reaction
fields.standfirst:
Steve Taylor anticipates Jonathan Aitken's experience under home detention curfew
The Aitken affair: special report
fields.trailText: Steve Taylor anticipates Jonathan Aitken's experience under home detention curfew.
fields.body:
Through a mixture of my own naivety and stupidity, I spent a short time in prison, and was released in February last year to be "tagged" at home. This meant that I had to stay at home between 7pm and 7am seven days a week for two months. Maybe my diary of that period might offer some insight of what is to come for Jonathan Aitken, who is now serving the last two months of his sentence under "home detention curfew".

Day 1: Released from prison at 8.30am. I have to be home - which is 120 miles away - by 3pm, calling en route at the probation office and the pub. (The latter being de rigeur, you understand.) I must arrive home early to allow them time to come and install the unit in my home and fit the tag to me. They arrive at 11pm! The Home Monitoring Unit (HMU) looks like a cheap 1970s alarm clock, and the tag itself is like a big watch, minus the clockface. Fitted to my ankle, it is nicely discreet. The HMU is connected to the telephone and electricity. I then complete an equal opportunities form. The two Securicor officers wear plain clothes (for discretion, I'm told) but proudly sport Home Office ID cards.

Day 2 : As I enjoy a nice relaxing bath, the telephone rings. It's the Securicor monitoring centre in Manchester, asking if I am at home. Either the bath water obscured the signal, or I was out of range. They say they will send someone round to investigate.

Day 3 : No one arrived yesterday to investigate my bath. I dusted the flat during the day and knocked the HMU, which promptly rang up and grassed on me, prompting a terse call from the monitoring centre.

Day 4 : Securicor came to change my tag; the old one was from a faulty batch. They obviously aren't too sophisticated. There was talk in prison that they could sense alcohol and that you could be located by satellite at any time.

Day 6 : Another visit - to change the tag again.

Day 9 : Telephone call in the evening to check that I am in, and they ask me a security question: "What's your middle name?"

Day 13 : Another visit - the HMU has reported that I'm out. Reliability doesn't seem to be a key feature.

Day 16 : Visited by two new officers who change the HMU and the tag. The new HMU resembles digital kitchen scales, while the tag plays a tune if you knock it. After they have gone, while talking to a friend on the telephone, I am inter rupted by the HMU's female voice telling me to hang up.

Day 28 : My first day in a part-time job working 9am to 5pm. The tag didn't present any problems.

Day 31 : Armed robbery at the shop opposite my flat, and I am prevented from helping for fear of the tag amputating my ankle if I set foot outside the boundary.

Day 32 : My partner's grandfather died, and I am passed from pillar to post and back again between the prison, Securicor and probation to try to vary my curfew hours to attend the funeral.

Day 33 : Established that the decision lies with the prison governor. He says he'll let me know tomorrow.

Day 34 : He hasn't decided. Securicor call me and ask me why I didn't apply direct to them.

Day 36 : The governor called to say that he has endorsed my application, but it is too late to arrange transport.

Day 40 : Best friend's birthday party at his flat next door, starting at 4pm. At 7pm, all the guests moved to my flat to carry on the party. Graham, the birthday boy, gets paranoid about the tag listening to his conversations.

Day 44 : Call Securicor to apply for a change of hours to allow me to start work at 6am. Amazingly, it took only seven phone calls.

Day 57 : Invited to a charity reception at the House of Lords, but decline on the basis of the sheer cost of the phone calls to arrange it. Later regret it - Chardonnay on the terrace does sound appealing.

Day 58 : The curfew ends tonight at midnight. They arrive at 11.15, and remove all the equipment, and wish me good luck, in the style of King Herod congratulating Mary on the birth of her son. Spent an hour after midnight standing outside, just for the sheer hell of it.

Aitken may enjoy similar experiences, although it might get embarrassing. Imagine being on the phone for a benefits agency -crisis loan when the woman from HMU tells you to hang up. And he needs to be careful, because while the "simple sword" may cut through the tag, the "trusty shield" of his HMU will soon tell the truth. Welcome home, Jon Boy!

Steve Taylor is reading politics at Goldsmiths College, University of London.
