fields.headline: Cover stories
fields.trailText: Safe and sorry: A pensioner in Hove, Sussex, fitted so many locks to her door after a burglary that it took firefighters three hours to free her when she locked herself in.
fields.body:
Safe and sorry: A pensioner in Hove, Sussex, fitted so many locks to her door after a burglary that it took firefighters three hours to free her when she locked herself in.

Deadly distraught: A company in Corby, Northamptonshire, is offering bunches of dead roses wrapped in black paper for jilted lovers to send to their former partners.

Cheeky chat: Callers trying to buy mobile phones from a Manchester company were accidentally put through to a hardcore sex chatline.

Say that again . . . An apology has been sent to a grandfather in Modbury, Devon, after he was sent an appointment for a pregnancy scan by the hospital where he was due to have a hearing test.

Learning the drill: The new town crier for North Tyneside council was chosen after a trial in which his voice registered 113 decibels, as loud as a pneumatic drill.

And so to bed . . . Four postal workers were taken to hospital after inhaling fumes when a bottle containing a sex aid chemical got broken at a sorting office in Peterhead, Aberdeenshire.

On a jelly roll: A struggling football team in Crawley, Sussex, has soared up the league after a winning streak that started when the players decided to eat jelly babies before matches to give them energy.

Wrong tree . . . A woman in Farnborough, Hampshire, is battling with the local council for the right to chop down a protected silver birch tree because she says her dog is allergic to its pollen.

Tree huggers: Farmers near Harrogate, Yorkshire, are using raw fleeces from Herdwick sheep to protect their apple trees from frost and suppress weed growth.

Paper chase: Police officers in Stoke-on-Trent are being told to do their paperwork in marked patrol cars parked outside the homes of known burglars.

Spell check: A white witch has cast a spell to block the erection of a mobile phone mast on the tower of a 15th-century church near Ashford, Kent.

Feeling better: A man from Winchester, Hampshire, who had his bank details stolen ended up £438 richer because the thief used them to place winning bets by telephone.

Scent into battle: Electricity meter readers in Yorkshire are being given herbal sprays, containing a blend of peppermint oil and cloves, to fend off vicious dogs.

Royle occasion: Actor Ricky Tomlinson, who plays the slobbish father in the TV comedy The Royle Family, took his own beer to a celebrity awards event because he doesn't like champagne.

fields.headline: Early daze clears
fields.standfirst: Kendra Inman on a project helping to reduce the mystery and misery of autism
fields.trailText: Kendra Inman on a project helping to reduce the mystery and misery of autism.
fields.body:
The most difficult children's birthday party Zoe Jerome ever held took place an hour after her son was diagnosed as being autistic. Still numb with shock from the news, she organised the games and food for her son Ashley's third birthday, thinking the worst but not really knowing what was in store. The paediatric assessment unit that broke the news had sent her away with a leaflet and told her to return after the summer holidays.

"At the party," she recalls, "I looked at the other children and thought, 'Why are they normal and he's not?' I felt like I was grieving for a child I'd lost - the one I thought he was going to be."

Zoe, who lives in Sheffield, knew Ashley had a problem when he was just over a year old. "At first, I thought he was deaf as he didn't react to things," she says. "When he had tantrums, people would say he was just going through the 'terrible twos' early. But at 12 months old? I knew something was wrong."

Like most people, Zoe's knowledge of autism came mostly from Dustin Hoffman's portrayal of an autistic man with a talent for maths in the film Rain Man. But people with autism can have a wide range of disabilities. It affects their social and communication skills, which means they have difficulty understanding the world and, therefore, interacting appropriately with it.

After the news sunk in, Zoe demanded more help. Eventually, she was put in touch with an EarlyBird programme, then being piloted by the National Autistic Society (NAS) in south Yorkshire. The programme aims to teach parents of pre-school children diagnosed with autistic spectrum disorder how to communicate more effectively with their children and to help them prevent the development of inappropriate behaviour as they grow older.

The NAS wants more parents to benefit from EarlyBird and this month is rolling out the scheme nationally and offering training courses for staff to be trained in the techniques. Next week, the society is hosting a conference on different models of early intervention.

The scheme has been evaluated by researchers from the University of Teesside, who found that parents were less stressed after completing the programme and saw their children as "less autistic". The parents reported that the programme provided "light at the end of the tunnel".

Once a week, for three months, parents attend group training meetings or have home visits, where they are videoed interacting with their children and taught to apply what they learn in the group. Since the pilot, two more centres - in Wandsworth, south London, and in Leicestershire - have been licensed to use the EarlyBird model.

Provision for under-fives diagnosed as autistic is patchy, says Dr Jane Shields, manager of the EarlyBird project. Many local authorities fail to provide specific services for this age group, while other programmes aimed at parents of young children are very intensive. EarlyBird is a more manageable scheme for parents, she claims, and relatively cheap for local authorities to run, once staff have been trained.

"We help them understand what is different for a child with autism," Shield says. "We help them analyse the underlying causes of the inappropriate behaviour."

This can mean teaching simple techniques such as how to cut down on the number of words parents use when talkingto their child. "Parents are in danger of talking too much to a child," Shield explains. "Even those children who have a wide vocabulary have difficulty processing the language. Parents found the most benefit in simplifying what they say and inserting pauses in between what they say. The parents often say it is a relief to find out their child isn't just naughty and doing it on purpose to annoy them. Once you understand why they are behaving that way, you can retrain your instincts in dealing with them."

Just as important for Zoe Jerome was the support of other parents: "Ashley had a thing about chewing carpets," she says. "You could tell people at the group because they would say something like, 'That's OK, mine chews curtains.'"

fields.headline: How the general escaped trial
fields.standfirst: Fear that former dictator could die in Britain ended extradition case that stunned the world
fields.trailText: The image of a Chilean military guard escorting the flag-draped coffin of General Augusto     Pinochet across the tarmac of RAF Northolt to a waiting airforce jet may have been     enough of a nightmare to persuade the home secretary to send the ailing dictator     home, says Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
The image of a Chilean military guard escorting the flag-draped coffin of General Augusto Pinochet across the tarmac of RAF Northolt to a waiting airforce jet may, in the end, have been enough of a nightmare to persuade the home secretary, Jack Straw, to send the ailing dictator home.

For all the tough talking about international justice over the past 18 months attributed to sources close to the governent, the last thing any high-ranking cabinet minister wanted was for the general to die in British custody, even if he was staying in a mansion on the luxury Wentworth estate in Surrey rather than in one of Her Majesty's prison cells.

Anglo-Chilean relations have already been strained, at times almost to breaking point, by the 18-month legal battle for possession of the general. Last year the Chilean ambassador in London was withdrawn to Santiago in protest at Gen Pinochet's continued arrest. He returned soon afterwards, but foreign office officials feared a complete breakdown in relations between the two countries, something that would have been hard to avoid if the general had died.

Rumours began circulating some time ago that during meetings with Chilean government officials the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, had hinted that the general's best chance of gaining an early release would be on humanitarian grounds.

It is something that Pinochet supporters have been actively pursuing for some time, leaking stories to the press about his ailing health, including the fact that a priest had been called to Wentworth on one occasion to administer the last rites.

Ever the brave old soldier, Gen Pinochet let it be known, through his daughter, that he would rather die in Britain with honour rather than return home humiliated. But when the chance came for a medical release the general grabbed it with both hands, accepting Mr Straw's request that he undergo independent medical tests.

The beginning of the end of Gen Pinochet's extended stay in Britain came in October when the Chilean foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, sent a formal petition to the home office asking for him to be sent home because of ill health.

Mr Straw made the request that he undergo medical tests, and last week he was examined by a team of doctors at Northwick Park hospital in north London.

Ailments

The medical tests, carried out over six hours by a neurologist and two geriatricians, found he was suffering from a variety of ailments, including a viral infection, diabetes, heart disease and the effects of two mild strokes.

Faced with the overwhelming evidence Mr Straw would have had little choice but to recommend the former dictator's return to Chile. He is under a duty to act in a judicial capacity in deciding extradition cases. Like all suspects Gen Pinochet is presumed innocent and Mr Straw is under an obligation to free him if he is likely to die before he is tried.

Critics of the government's handling of the Pinochet case - and there are many, from Lady Thatcher to Lord Lamont and a whole host of rightwing luminaries in between - will doubtless suggest that yesterday's decision is one that should have been taken 18 months ago.

But the medical reports that landed on Mr Straw's desk this week are not the first he has seen relating to the 84-year-old general. When Gen Pinochet was first arrested in 1998 representations were made on behalf of the Chilean senator that his age and health would render it unjust or oppressive to issue an authority to proceed. In answer to a written question in the House of Commons Mr Straw replied that he had considered these carefully, but concluded that it did not appear that Gen Pinochet was unfit to stand to trial, and for him to do so would not be unjust or oppressive.

But according to yesterday's statement Gen Pinochet's condition has deteriorated significantly in the past few months.

It is ironic that he was in London receiving medical care when he was first arrested in October 1988. His back had gone into spasm during the 17-hour flight from Santiago, and he was in extreme discomfort when he was led from the Lufthansa jet straight into the Hounslow suite, one of four foreign office VIP rooms at Heathrow that are reserved for visiting dignitaries.

Little did he know that his arrival in London would set in motion what will no doubt go down as one of the most controversial episodes in British, and international, legal history.

A few weeks after his arrival, as he convalesced after back surgery in a London clinic, rumours began circulating that the Spanish magistrate Baltasar Garzon was preparing to request Gen Pinochet's detention. Less than a week later, still groggy in his hospital bed, he was arrested on charges of murder, torture and terrorism carried out under his 17 year military regime.

His arrest stunned and divided the world. The case forced the international community - and the circumstances dictated that it was largely Britain's legal and political institutions to which the task fell - to examine how it could, would and should deal with those who transgress the norms of international behaviour.

The legal challenge by Gen Pinochet's lawyers went all the way to the House of Lords where a panel of three law lords threw it out in December 1998, prompting Mr Straw to give his consent to the action proceeding. But the initial ruling was then set aside in an unprecedented move as Gen Pinochet's lawyers argued that links between one of the law lords, Lord Hoffmann, and the human rights group Amnesty International cast doubt on his impartiality.

The issue then had to be re-examined by a new panel of law lords. They also decided that Gen Pinochet had no immunity as a former head of state, but they did decide he could only face trial on charges relating to incidents after Britain signed up to crucial international treaties - December 1988.

This had the effect of massively reducing the number of charges faced by the senator, offering him perhaps the first glimmer of hope that he would not be sent to Spain.

But Mr Straw again sanctioned the extradition proceedings against Gen Pinochet, saying that despite calls to the contrary he could find no compassionate grounds to end the action. Judge Garzon, the Spanish judge leading the attempt to extradite Gen Pinochet, responded by immediately filing more charges relating to incidents after the cut-off date.

In October last year London magistrates decided there was nothing to stop him being extradited to Spain. That decision, inevitably, attracted another appeal from Gen Pinochet's lawyers that was due to be heard later this year - but which may now prove irrelevant.

Dismay

No doubt last night's decision will cause dismay among those who were pinning their hopes on seeing a man regarded as a brutal dictator brought to trial on the legal action sparked by Spain.

But if they can take one crumb of comfort from what has happened it will be that the man responsible for the deaths of more than 3,000 of his own citizens now knows how it feels to be wrenched away from his home and his country.

Gen Pinochet may be destined to fly home, but his bruising encounter with a determined Spanish judge and the British courts have spelt out to human rights abusers around the world that international law is catching up with them.

The case set a crucial precedent - that former heads of state cannot hide behind the concept of state immunity to avoid prosecution for crimes committed in office.

webTitle: Proust regains a slot in bestseller lists

fields.headline: Proust regains a slot in bestseller lists
fields.trailText: It could be millennial angst, the lunar eclipse, or simply the fact that half the nation has taken to its bed too - but Proust is back in the bestseller lists.
fields.body:
It could be millennial angst, the lunar eclipse, or simply the fact that half the nation has taken to its bed too - but Proust is back in the bestseller lists.

Sales of Remembrance Of Things Past, his epic four-part meditation on life, wallpaper and twice-baked biscuits, have trebled in the last month. Something very odd indeed is happening, scholars and booksellers agree.

Proust retired to bed to write the novel prompted by a sudden childhood memory as he bit into a madeleine dipped in weak tea. Two decades - and a Prix Goncourt later - he finished it and ever since it has vied with James Joyce's Ulysses as the most famous least read literary classic.

For years it has sold at a steady dribble, yet in a matter of weeks, the latest outbreak of Proust mania fuelled by Time Regained, a film version of his final volume, Le Temps Retrouvé, has seen it jump more than 3,000 places in the list Booktrack.

True, Remembrance Of Times Past sold only 217 copies last week, but Proust fans and academics see the leap as a small but significent strike for high culture.

In Paris at the Bibliothèque Nationale one of the largest exhibitions dedicated to Proust's genius is already under way with more than 300 paintings, drawings and sculptures. Marcel Proust: l'écriture et les arts, which lasts until Fbruary 6, also includes manuscripts and letters.

Alain de Botton, whose own bestseller How Proust Can Change Your Life, prompted a mini-boom in Proust sales in the US, said the spurt was probably prompted by guilt as much as anything else.

"There is no doubt, like Joyce, people put off tackling him," he said. "It is probably the year 2000 that has done it. It is a new year, and a new century, and people are saying: 'I'll finally conquer Proust before I die."

"Again, like Joyce, I think people think that if they read A la Recherche du Temps Perdu they will never have to read another book. That all wisdom, and everything they will they ever need to know will be in it. Of course, it is not like that at all."

There may be another much less worthy reason, he said. "A lot of things happen in summer, so it's a great escape from the gloom of mid-winter."

DJ Enright, who took two years to translate the full four volumes, said he wished he could claim that the world was finally appreciating a writer who could find profundities in the most trifling things. "I doubt it though. It's the film." In a delicious irony Proust himself would have appreciated, Enright's wife and co-translater is called Madeleine. "A lot of people have thought it unfilmable. And most people who try to read it give up very quickly. It's that beginning bit which they can't get over, which is a great pity, because it such a wonderful book to be absorbed in."

The film, directed by Chilean Raoul Ruiz stars Marcello Mazzarella as Proust, Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve. A hit of the Cannes film festival, it is on limited release here.

fields.headline: Legal saga of former dictator
fields.trailText: September 21 1998 Pinochet, 82, flies to Britain.
fields.body:
September 21 1998 Pinochet, 82, flies to Britain.

October 16 Arrested in London Clinic, Harley Street.

October 22 Baroness Thatcher calls for Pinochet's immediate release.

October 28 High court rules him "entitled to immunity as a former sovereign". He remains under arrest pending appeal. The then attorney general, John Morris QC, declines consent for UK prosecution, citing "insufficient admissible evidence".

October 29 Pinochet moved to a private psychiatric hospital in north London.

November 11 Formal extradition request from Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon sent to Jack Straw.

November 25 On his 83rd birthday, Law Lords overturn High Court decision and rule he is not immune.

December 1 Pinochet moves to Surrey house.

February 18 1999 It emerges that in November the Vatican made representations, apparently sympathetic to Pinochet, to foreign office.

March 24 By a 6-1 majority, law lords again overturn high court decision giving Pinochet immunity (after his lawyer accuses Lord Hoffmann of possible bias because of link to Amnesty International) but they reduce the charges: Pinochet can be extradited only for torture and conspiracy to torture alleged to have been committed after December 8 1988, when International Torture Convention became binding on Spain, UK and Chile.

April 15 Straw says there are no compassionate grounds to halt proceedings.

April 16 New arrest warrant served on Pinochet.

July 2 Pinochet has electro-cardiogram. Friends say general's pacemaker is now maintaining his heartbeat.

July 8 Law lords rule that the taxpayer must meet lion's share of costs.

September 13 Pinochet has brain scan followed by neurological tests.

September 27 Four-day extradition hearing at London's Bow Street magistrates court.

October 1 Belgium renews its arrest warrant for Pinochet.

October 6 Pinochet excused from appearing at extradition ruling after court hears he has suffered two minor strokes.

October 8 Magistrates court commits Pinochet on all 35 charges, awaiting Straw's final decision on extraditing him.

October 14 Chile formally asks Britain to free Pinochet because of deteriorating health.

October 16 In Santiago up to 40 people are arrested as Pinochet supporters protest outside the British embassy.

October 18 In Madrid two former security aides to deposed president Salvador Allende tell Judge Garzon Pinochet personally beat prisoners.

October 21 Spain says it will not appeal if Mr Straw frees Pinochet on humanitarian grounds.

October 22 Pinochet lawyers lodge challenge with High court to extradition ruling.

November 5 Home office asks for Pinochet to have medical examination.

January 5 2000 Pinochet has seven hours of tests at north London hospital to assess his fitness to be extradited.

January 11 Straw announces he is "minded" to release Pinochet based on medical reports.

fields.headline: Thatcher banned for two matches
fields.trailText: Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher has been banned for two matches by the Football Association for elbowing Sunderland midfielder Nicky Summerbee last week.
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Wimbledon defender Ben Thatcher has been banned for two matches by the Football Association for elbowing Sunderland midfielder Nicky Summerbee last week.

The punishment was announced by an FA disciplinary commission in London today. Although Thatcher was not in attendance, he had pleaded guilty to the charge of misconduct by correspondence.

Referee Graham Poll missed the event at the time, and the FA charged the defender 48 hours later after studying video evidence. Poll subsequently admitted that he would have red-carded the full-back had he seen the challenge.

Thatcher is not the first Premiership player to get in trouble for misuse of the elbow in recent months. But while Leicester defender Matt Elliott and Middlesbrough striker Brian Deane were also found guilty by the FA, they only received one-match bans.

FA spokesman Adrian Bevington said of the ban: "In the cases of Brian Deane and Matt Elliott, they were suspended for one game apiece following video evidence of misuse of the elbow being brought to our attention.

"Clearly the two-match suspension handed out to Ben Thatcher shows there is no room in the game for players demonstrating such conduct."

webTitle: Pinochet opponents demand access to medical reports

fields.headline: Pinochet opponents demand access to medical reports
fields.trailText: Jack Straw today faced growing pressure to release General Augusto Pinochet's medical records after he indicated he would block the former dictator's extradition to stand trial on charges of torture.
fields.body:
Jack Straw today faced growing pressure to release General Augusto Pinochet's medical records after he indicated he would block the former dictator's extradition to stand trial on charges of torture.

Ann Clwyd MP, chair of the all-party parliamentary human rights group, said it was unfair to expect parties such as Amnesty International to make representations within seven days without access to such important information.

She said: "It's in the public interest for that sort of information to be given to those interested parties and it should be done. It should have been left to the Spanish courts to decide whether he was fit to stand trial. There are a number of unanswered questions here."

Amnesty, which has been involved in the legal manoeuvres for extradition, indicated it wanted to see the medical report by independent experts that appears to have let Gen Pinochet off the hook as far as extradition is concerned.

"I think we will want to see the medical evidence. If he is being released for medical reasons, we would like to see that evidence, so that we are as confident as the home secretary that he is unable to stand trial for medical reasons," said Brendan Paddy of Amnesty.

But Downing Street said Gen Pinochet and his defence team had the right to privacy, concerning the details of the medical report.

"The point is people having the right to privacy for their medical records - it's the simple point about medical records," said the prime minister's office.

Although Gen Pinochet appears to have won his fight against extradition to Spain, human rights groups today insisted that human rights law has been strengthened by General Augusto Pinochet's detention, even if the former Chilean dictator eventually returns home.

"While we're sorry that Pinochet and his victims will never have that day in court, this has been a victory from start to finish for the principle of human rights and the rule of law," said Reed Brody of Human Rights Watch.

Moreover, Gen Pinochet's hopes of fading quietly away in Chile may be illusory. Pablo Cabrera, Chile's ambassador in Britain, pointed out that many changes had been made in Chilean law since the closing days of the Pinochet regime, when the dictator passed a wide-ranging law giving himself immunity from prosecution.

Nearly 60 criminal complaints await the general in Chile and human rights lawyers are waiting to test the government's promise to strip the general of his senatorial immunity from prosecution and send him to face the courts.

"The law in Chile (now) allows the people and the tribunal to strip off immunity, as has been done already with another senator for other reasons," Mr Cabrera said. "We have many examples that these things are happening now in Chile."

The 84-year-old general is expected to return to Chile after Mr Straw last night accepted medical evidence that Gen Pinochet is unfit to stand trial in Spain. Mr Straw said he was "minded" to block Gen Pinochet's extradition after a team of medical experts reported a deterioration in his condition.

Spain quickly signalled it would not take issue with Britain's decision. In a statement, the foreign ministry said: "The Spanish government has maintained from the first moment an attitude of absolute respect for judicial decisions taken in relation to this case. It is its intention also to respect the decisions of the British government."

The Spanish government, like Downing Street, had little appetite for a controversial trial that could have disrupted relations with Chile.

There was no immediate comment from Baltasar Garzon, the Spanish judge who launched the extradition case, but lawyers working with him said they would continue their fight. Before Mr Straw makes a final ruling, he has given everyone involved in the case seven days to submit arguments for his consideration.

Mr Straw also invited France, Switzerland and Belgium, which have extradition requests pending against Gen Pinochet, to respond. But even the general's opponents and human rights groups said there was little chance now he would be extradited.

Police, meanwhile, stepped up security around the home near London where Pinochet has been under house arrest for the past 15 months while a debate raged about whether his health - mainly heart problems - was an excuse for him to evade justice.

Gen Pinochet has been detained since his arrest on October 16, 1998, following an extradition request. He is accused of using torture to intimidate and silence political opponents throughout his 1973-90 dictatorship. An official Chilean government report says 3,197 people died or disappeared after Gen Pinochet led a coup that toppled the elected Marxist president, Salvador Allende.

Last October, Gen Pinochet lost his case before a London magistrate, who ordered him extradited to Spain. But his lawyers appealed and a hearing was scheduled for March 20. His supporters, who include Baroness Thatcher, contend that Gen Pinochet's health has steadily deteriorated since his arrest.

He suffers from diabetes, wears a pacemaker and has difficulty walking. His doctors have said that he suffered two minor strokes in September. The Chilean government had urged Mr Straw in October to allow an independent medical team to examine Gen Pinochet's health. Two geriatricians, a neurologist and a fourth doctor spent seven hours examining the former dictator on January 5.

"Following recent deterioration in the state of Senator Pinochet's health ... he is at present unfit to stand trial and no change to that position can be expected," the doctors concluded. Their exact medical findings remained confidential.

Gen Pinochet was said by friends to be "delighted" by the latest twist in his case. But Carlos Reyes, a journalist jailed for two years under Gen Pinochet's rule, said: "It's unbelievable that a criminal should escape justice because perhaps he is ill or in pain. The pain of my Chilean people is worse than what Pinochet is suffering."

webTitle: Sleaze committee calls for curbs on government spin doctors

fields.headline: Sleaze committee calls for curbs on government spin doctors
fields.standfirst: Report also urges better justice system for MPs accused of corruption
fields.trailText: Committee on standards in public life
fields.body:
Committee on standards in public life

The chairman of the anti-sleaze committee on standards in public life, Lord Neill, today called for a new code of conduct to be introduced for government spin doctors.

The committee found that parliament should introduce a limit on the number of special advisers appointed to counsel ministers on policy and briefing the media.

The report stopped short of criticising the actions of advisers, saying it was not necessary to create "a wide range of new obligations" for them. But it said: "In the interests of accountability, there needs to be a single code that guides special advisers and sets out for their departments and the wider public the rules they should observe."

The number of special advisers appointed by the government is now 74 - up from 38 at the beginning of 1997 under a Conservative government. They are employed at a cost of £3.9m to taxpayers.

Opposition parties have repeatedly criticised the increase since Labour came to power. They claim the government has created an "army of spin doctors" which is proof of Labour's "politicisation" of the civil service.

Today's 163-page report also called for a better system of justice for MPs accused of corrupt practices or bribery. It said a new criminal law of bribery should be introduced "as soon as possible", making clear "that members of both houses of parliament, acting in their capacity as members, and those who bribe a member of either house of parliament fall within its scope".

The report said that if there was an allegation of serious misconduct against an MP a "trial" procedure or disciplinary tribunal should be set up by the parliamentary commissioner for standards.

The accused MP should be allowed legal representation when the case was heard in front of the tribunal, which should consist of a legal chairman and two or four MPs "of substantial seniority".

The report follows Mohamed Al Fayed's victory in the libel trial brought against him by former MP Neil Hamilton. Both would have been liable to prosecution under the recommendations.

Useful links

Current code of conduct for House of Commons members
Standards and privileges select committee Benjamin Wegg-Prosser, a former special adviser to Peter Mandelson, defends the profession

webTitle: Tyrant who will never be a martyr

fields.headline: Tyrant who will never be a martyr
fields.standfirst: It was right to arrest Pinochet - and it is right to let him go home
fields.trailText: Jack Straw's timing could have had more sensitivity to Chilean politics. He might have waited to announce his decision to let General Pinochet go home until after the weekend elections. By raising a dormant issue now, he risks reintroducing the general into a domestic political argument that had mostly forgotten him. But the medical plight of this rotting old tyrant has extracted from Mr Straw a judgment that, while undoubtedly convenient for the British government, is also correct.
fields.body:
Jack Straw's timing could have had more sensitivity to Chilean politics. He might have waited to announce his decision to let General Pinochet go home until after the weekend elections. By raising a dormant issue now, he risks reintroducing the general into a domestic political argument that had mostly forgotten him. But the medical plight of this rotting old tyrant has extracted from Mr Straw a judgment that, while undoubtedly convenient for the British government, is also correct.

It was right that Pinochet was arrested, and an act of reverberant justice that the Spanish magistrate who started all this should have been so determined to bring him to trial for the unspeakable crimes he supervised in the 1970s. Anyone whose family was touched by the tortures and murders that were part of the Chilean state machine in those days will feel cheated if Pinochet goes home untried.

They would like him to suffer, even unto death, a mite of the hard fate he inflicted on thousands of Chilean citizens. They don't see why the Spanish case should not be heard to completion, and their feelings at his reprieve are totally understandable. There could hardly be a greater contrast, in moral quality, between the protests of these wronged Chileans and the hypocritical special pleading on Pinochet's behalf by the gang of British rightists, from Lady Thatcher to Lord Lamont, who see in him a heroic role model for conservatives everywhere.

But Pinochet, the doctors say, would be incapable of following his own trial, and Mr Straw has drawn the right, pragmatic conclusion. Pinochet is a discredited figure in Chile. In the election campaign, even the right-wing candidate has failed to line up behind him. Only a coterie of the retired military still worship at the shrine. What could change all that would be death on foreign soil, supplying the general with an aura of martyrdom, giving him a heroic afterlife he will now, with luck, be deprived of.

H e returns home with few of the accoutrements of heroism. He will, after all, have been officially declared ga-ga. Such a figure may remain an object of pity, but hardly an icon of power. He will slink away from foreign internment, after the humiliation of all that has happened to him, a broken man. Better this than the spectacle of an aged prisoner, feeble in mind and body, being hurried towards death by a Spanish court.

The home secretary's decision brings the right end to a thoroughly satisfactory episode. The arrest brought to world prominence a shocking history that many people, including governments such as the British which were happy to treat with Pinochet as an arms-purchaser, had conveniently forgotten. It brought out from under their stones politicians who were prepared to justify what Pinochet did, with arguments that were revealing in their brazen indifference to human decency: an instructive sight for all to witness.

Next, arrest kept the suspect in captivity, subjecting him to an extended withdrawal of freedom that it was a pleasure to witness, however slight the inconvenience caused to him compared with the brutal interventions he made in other people's lives. The galere of enrages who came to share his ordeal and rail against it somehow only added to the rightness of what was happening.

Finally, he made a deathless contribution not only to British but international law. If Pinochet had not been arraigned, the House of Lords would not have had the opportunity to rule that former heads of state can no longer claim immunity from prosecution under international conventions. This was a historic piece of law-making, underwritten by no fewer than nine law lords, which fundamentally extends the reach of international law into domestic courts and, as such, will help to reinforce that concept in courts far beyond these islands.

That might have happened anyway, in some other case of a torturer who strayed into a foreign land where he thought the establishment would make him safe. God knows, there are enough of them about. But it fell to General Pinochet to cause the mark to be made. He will be the forbear of others like him, now likely to think twice before imagining they can rely on amnesty in any place with an honest legal system.

This new legality is inextinguishable. Mr Straw does not wipe it out by sending the untried criminal home. No doubt he saves himself some trouble; and the Spanish government will be even more relieved. These are not edifying considerations. If the general had been in proper health, it would have been good to see the legal process to its end. Pinochet's last years of ruin offered only modest retribution. But since he is a wreck, let comfort be drawn from the immortal service he most unwillingly did: help, via the judges, make the civilised world better protected against people like himself.

fields.headline: Milburn denies flu outbreak bungle
fields.trailText: The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday insisted that the flu outbreak had put unprecedented pressure on the NHS and was the reason for the cancellation of routine operations, despite allegations from the Tory leader, Wiliam Hague, that the government had failed to prepare for a predictable winter crisis.
fields.body:
The health secretary, Alan Milburn, yesterday insisted that the flu outbreak had put unprecedented pressure on the NHS and was the reason for the cancellation of routine operations, despite allegations from the Tory leader, Wiliam Hague, that the government had failed to prepare for a predictable winter crisis.

Mr Hague, speaking in the over-stretched accident and emergency department of Northwick Park hospital in north London, said that the country was in the grip of an outbreak - not an epidemic - and that the government should have ensured the NHS was better able to cope.

"I think to some extent the government has exaggerated the problem in order to claim that the health service is dealing with a problem that it has not had to deal with before.

"This was an easily anticipatable problem, that there would be an increase in demand at winter. It was a problem that could have been seen coming by ministers and they haven't seen it coming and they haven't done anything about it."

Doctors responsible for collating the flu figures said the outbreak mirrored the problems of last winter. The viral strain - named after Sydney where it was first identified - was the same and, like last year, those affected were mostly elderly. Public health laboratory service statistics showed a level of 197 per 100,000 of the population visiting their GP with flu, just below the normal seasonal peak of 200. By PHLS standards, 400 per 100,000 is an epidemic.

But this year, the Chief Medical Officer, Liam Donaldson, has pointed to the increasing numbers contacting NHS Direct with flu symptoms rather than going to their GP. Those, he said, had to be counted in, raising the total to perhaps 300 per 100,000. John Knottenbelt, an accident and emergency consultant at Northwick Park, put the blame on NHS Direct for increasing the pressures on his department. "This NHS Direct thing is not a good thing as far as we are concerned. All they are telling patients is 'if you are feeling ill, go to A&E'."

Mr Milburn visited the casualty department at St Mary's hospital in Paddington, where elderly patients were lying on trolleys in the corridor waiting for beds. He insisted that the NHS was coping despite unprecedented demand.

"What we have seen this year is planning and better preparation for the winter pressures which have been put on the health service ... Of course the NHS is under a great deal of pressure, and staff are doing a fantastic job and we are coping with what is a very, very serious outbreak."

Hospitals would not face financial penalties if they were unable to meet their waiting list reduction targets in the summer because of the backlog caused by the winter crisis.

Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said the crisis revealed the under-funded state of the NHS. "We are running at the limit all the time. Even at a so-called slack time, medical beds will be 95 to 100% full."

Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, which represents health authorities and trusts, called for more funding.

He told the BBC: "Unless we have significant additional resources available for the NHS next year I fear that we could have exactly the same problem in January 2001 as we have got this January."

 The flu outbreak has put a stop to one cancer patient's surgery four times. Mavis Skeet, 74, was due to have an eight-hour operation at Leeds general infirmary five weeks ago to remove her gullet and see if her cancer of the oesophagus had spread. The first operation was cancelled because her anaesthetist had flu. On the other three occasions, there has been no intensive care bed available because of the numbers of elderly people with respiratory complications due to flu.

"My mum has been strong up to the last time, but then she broke down and was in tears," said Mrs Skeet's daughter, Jane. "We are very angry. Doctors say they can't tell whether the cancer's spread until they operate, which means it could be spreading all the time there's a lack of beds.

"This is due to lack of resources and bad planning. The government are trying to cover it up by saying the hospitals are coping, but they're obviously not. The operating team seem as frustrated as we are."

Of course the NHS is under a great deal of pressure, and staff are doing a fantastic job and we are coping with what is a very, very serious outbreak." Peter Hawker, chairman of the British Medical Association's consultants committee, said the crisis revealed the under-funded state of the NHS. "We are running at the limit all the time. Even at a so-called slack time, medical beds will be 95 to 100% full." Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, which represents health authorities and trusts, called for more funding. He told the BBC: "Unless we have significant additional resources available for the NHS next year I fear that we could have exactly the same problem in January 2001 as we have got this January."  The flu outbreak has put a stop to one cancer patient's surgery four times. Mavis Skeet, 74, was due to have an eight-hour operation at Leeds general infirmary five weeks ago to remove her gullet and see if her cancer of the oesophagus had spread. The first operation was cancelled because her anaesthetist had flu. On the other three occasions, there has been no intensive care bed available because of the numbers of elderly people with respiratory complications due to flu. "My mum has been strong up to the last time, but then she broke down and was in tears," said Mrs Skeet's daughter, Jane. "We are very angry. Doctors say they can't tell whether the cancer's spread until they operate, which means it could be spreading all the time there's a lack of beds. "This is due to lack of resources and bad planning. fields.headline: Pinochet's release is a blow to humankind
fields.standfirst: The former dictator must be laughing in his luxury mansion, writes Tito Tricot, who was tortured under the general's regime

fields.body:
Someday, perhaps overwhelmed by the ferocity of highland volcanoes, I will be able to write calmly about General Pinochet's release. Perhaps on a sleepless night I will find the precise moment to carry out a thorough sociological, ontological and - with divine inspiration - even an eschatological analysis of the so-called humanitarian release of the most inhumane dictator in Chile's history. However, for now I just need to conduct a profoundly personal and subjective gut exercise. Mine is a simple viewpoint filled with anger, frustration, bewilderment and sorrow. It is hard to understand how, after so much suffering and terror brought upon our people by the military dictatorship, the British government is willing to let him go.

The dictator must be laughing in his luxury mansion, no doubt reminiscing about the ignominious glory days when he ordered the secret police to kill, torture, rape and maim. He must be cruelly smiling, the same way he did when we were violently thrown into a smelly, claustrophobic armoured vehicle to be driven to a concentration camp. Blindfolded, our hands and feet bound with barbed wire, we thought the military were going to execute us. Amidst the unbearable heat we could clearly make out a distant cry, a friendly whisper, a lonely tear. We could touch the tearing memories of our childhood, the pouring rain, the amazing wind blowing through the plum trees, our first kiss behind the church doorway. We could smell life amidst death, but we were not in control of our destinies, because for 17 years Pinochet held sway over the Chilean people's lives.

Our sole dream was to have a waterfall full of sparrows and blue butterflies. Instead we got torture centres. All we wanted was a rainbow kissed by silver seagulls and red toucans. Instead, we got death squads. We got Pinochet.

The British government has accepted "unequivocal and unanimous" medical evidence that Pinochet is unable to stand trial in Spain on charges of torture. The British government is not alone: its Chilean counterpart has been fighting to have the dictator released ever since he was arrested in London in October 1998. In fact, in the traditional address to Congress in May last year, President Eduardo Frei promised MPs and the Chilean people at large that Gen Pinochet would be released before the end of his mandate in March 2000. What did President Frei know seven months ago that ordinary people did not?

Whatever negotiations were under way at the time, when Jack Straw announced his decision Frei proudly declared: "We have done our job". Shame on him, shame on all those who have defended the dictator with more passion and devotion than they have devoted to defending his victims. It is not only preposterous, but also utterly monstrous that the man who ordered the disappearance of thousands of our brothers and sisters is returning home. He will be able to enjoy the summer breeze, the green ocean and the scent of apricots, while the disappeared have no shadow, no eyes, no past or future.

Their dreams were shattered by the dictator's assassins; by all those who remained silent while the whole country was bleeding to death. Joaquín Lavín is one of these. He is the rightwing candidate standing for president at next Sunday's elections. His political alliance has striven to distance itself from Gen Pinochet in order to capture the popular vote. That is no doubt why their reaction to the dictator's impending liberation has so far been very cautious. There have been no street celebrations or arrogant public statements.

This will change, of course, if Pinochet returns after the elections, for then Lavín and the right will have no qualms about showing their true nature. Until now Lavín has been sold to the electorate as a detergent: the whitest, the purest and most efficient, ecological and biodegradable. During the two-month campaign he has dressed as a peasant, a miner, a worker and a fisherman. He has sung, danced and given away a thousand smiles. He was - and still is - a clown, but a very dangerous one, for in a matter of seconds he can turn into a trapeze artist, an acrobat, a contortionist, a juggler or a lion tamer simply to go on deceiving our people. But make no mistake, Joaquín Lavín was and is an active supporter of Gen Pinochet and his dictatorship.

Ricardo Lagos, the ruling party presidential candidate, was a well known opponent of the military. However, as part of the ruling coalition he has defended Gen Pinochet's right to return home. In fact, the dictator's release as a direct result of Chilean government intervention may hamper his chances of maintaining the slight advantage over Lavín that he obtained during the first round of voting in December. Many leftwing electors who voted for Lagos - a liberal social democrat - to prevent Lavín from winning, may think twice before giving their vote away to someone who has helped to release the man who killed, tortured or kidnapped their relatives and friends.

To appease his supporters Lagos said that if a crime had been committed, Pinochet should be tried in Chile. Nonetheless, and despite the fact that 55 lawsuits against the dictator are currently being investigated by the Chilean judge Juan Guzmán, very few people believe that Pinochet will ever be brought to justice in our country. He is far too powerful. Besides, he is still a senator of the republic and therefore immune from prosecution, although human rights lawyers have begun legal proceedings to get his immunity lifted.

The most likely scenario is that Pinochet will retire from public life. But no matter what he does when he gets to Chile and whatever the British home secretary says, he is not innocent. He is being sent home on "humanitarian" grounds, not because he has been tried and found not guilty. He may be 200 years old and sit in a wheelchair, but I have no compassion for him; as long as he breathes, as long as his heart beats, as long as blood runs through his veins, we will strive for justice. Then and only then can we paint the sky with the colours of a new beginning.

Tito Tricot
Chile
January 2000

fields.headline: The charges against Pinochet
fields.trailText: While the home secretary's decision not to extradite General Augusto Pinochet means the former dictator is unlikely to ever answer the charges against him, they remain a testament to the horrors inflicted upon opponents of his regime by the Chilean security forces.
fields.body:
While the home secretary's decision not to extradite General Augusto Pinochet means the former dictator is unlikely to ever answer the charges against him, they remain a testament to the horrors inflicted upon opponents of his regime by the Chilean security forces.

Spanish prosecutors requested his extradition on 35 charges, one detailing an allegation of conspiracy to torture, the other 34 charges concerning individual cases of alleged torture victims.

Below are a small selection of the charges.

1. Between December 7, 1988 and March 12, 1990 you agreed with others that the following course of conduct should be pursued, namely: a. persons that you believed ... would be disposed to pose a threat to the ... political positions, comforts and beliefs of yourself and other members of the conspiracy, would be abducted, and undergo severe pain and suffering, causing grievous bodily harm; b. some of those victims would be killed; c. such pain, suffering, harm and murder would be inflicted by public officials ... commanded by you; d. it would extend to such pain and suffering as, through the accounts of survivors ... would terrify persons who might otherwise be disposed to criticise or oppose you; e. the fate of many hundreds of persons known as "the disappeared" ... would continue to be concealed from their families; which course of conduct ... necessarily involved the commission of offences of torture by public officials.

2. That you on December 15, 1988 being a public official ... jointly with others intentionally inflicted severe pain or suffering on Wilson Fernando Valdebenito Juica by inflicting severe electric shocks causing his eventual death. 4. December 31, 1988: That you tortured Dolores Paz Cautivo Ahumada by repeatedly beating her and by threatening to rape her sister.

13. A day unknown in July 1989: You tortured Edmundo Meza Schaffer by suspending him, inflicting electric shocks on him, beating him, inserting a tube into his anus and by keeping him in conditions of acute physical discomfort.

14. July 16, 1989: Jorge Alejandro Escobar Diaz by beating him, inflicting electric shocks on him and by forcing him to imbibe hallucinogenic drugs.

17. Between August 20 and mid-September 1989: Jessica Antonia Liberona Ninoles by depriving her of sleep, making threats about her nine-year-old daughter, conducting repeated interrogations while she was naked and keeping her in dark, solitary and insanitary conditions.

20. August 22, 1989: Luis Orlando Vargas Miranda by beating him and subjecting him to severe mental pain or suffering precipitating his death.

22. Between August 29 and September 10, 1989: Jorge Muzz Fernando by tying him, confining him in a small cage, suspending him and by inflicting electric shocks on him.

23. June 24, 1989: Marcos Quezada Yanez aged 17 years, by inflicting severe electric shocks causing his eventual death.

24. September 1, 1989: Avelino Villarroel Munoz by beating him, inflicting electric shocks on him, restricting his breathing and allowing him to hear the infliction of severe pain and suffering on others.

30. Between October 26 and November 1, 1989: Marcos Paulsen Figueroa by beating him, suspending him, threatening him with instant death and threatening that his sisters would be tortured and sexually assaulted.

31. Between October 27 and early November 1989: Andrea Paulsen Figuera by depriving her of sleep, food and water for several days and by threatening that her five-year-old daughter would be tortured.

fields.headline: The Diana papers
fields.standfirst: David Hencke and Rob Evans explain how they got hold of top secret files that will not be revealed in the UK until much nearer the end of the century
fields.trailText: The documents on this site are secret cables from the US ambassadors in London and Angola to US Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright describing the aftermath of Princess Diana's funeral and her dramatic and controversial visit to Africa endorsing the campaign to abolish landmines. Under Britain's new Freedom of Information Act they would be kept secret until 2072 because they are communications about royalty.
fields.body:
The documents on this site are secret cables from the US ambassadors in London and Angola to US Secretary of State, Madeleine Albright describing the aftermath of Princess Diana's funeral and her dramatic and controversial visit to Africa endorsing the campaign to abolish landmines. Under Britain's new Freedom of Information Act they would be kept secret until 2072 because they are communications about royalty.

The Guardian obtained these candid cables by applying to Washington under the US Freedom of Information Act which is much more liberal than anything Jack Straw would allow in Britain.

They show what the outspoken US ambassador in London, Admiral William Crowe really thought about the Royals, Tony Blair and William Hague. Totally uncensored, they reveal a glowing view of New Labour in Britain and a damning portrait of the aloof Royals.

The cables on Princess Diana's visit to Angola show how keen the Americans were on her campaign to get rid of landmines - something they have been less supportive of since.

The FBI file is something else. The censored cables reveal how the US authorities were alerted to a bomb plot on Princess Di's wedding day... and the difficulties they had in tracing the people responsible. This sort of information is totally banned in Britain - the equivalent MI5 file will certainly not be revealed for possibly 100 years. Anybody asking under the new freedom of information act would not even be told if the file existed.

Read the memos

fields.headline: Arms sales
fields.standfirst: Labour cabinet ministers are reported to be embroiled in one of the biggest internal disputes since Labour came to power, over a proposal to lift restrictions on arms sales to Pakistan, imposed after a military coup in October 1999. Patrick Barkham explores the issues
fields.trailText: What is Labour's policy on arms sales?
fields.body:
What is Labour's policy on arms sales?

"Labour will not permit the sale of arms to regimes that might use them for internal repression or international aggression," the party's manifesto promised before its election in 1997.

In government, say critics, it has followed a subsequent manifesto pledge more closely: "We support a strong UK defence industry, which is a strategic part of our industrial base as well as our defence effort."

The sale of arms to foreign countries is big business - and Britain is the second biggest exporter of arms in the world. The latest annual report on British weapons sales records the granting of more than 10,000 export licences in 1998 to a number of countries, including Argentina, China, Colombia, India, Mozambique, Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Zimbabwe.

Foreign secretary Robin Cook, who inaugurated an "ethical foreign policy" one month into office, last July reaffirmed the importance of ethical considerations when importing arms. He said that the government "will not issue an export licence if there is a clearly identifiable risk that the proposed export might be used for internal repression" and promised to publish an annual report detailing arms export applications.

But the tension between Labour's two manifesto promises has continued, as demonstrated by rows over the sale of arms to Indonesia and now by a serious cabinet dispute over the issuing of arms export licences to Pakistan.

How are British-made weapons sold to other countries?

Licences to export "strategic goods" are issued by the government's export control agency, which is part of the department of trade and industry.

Businesses wanting to export their products fill in a form (they can even do it online). The DTI circulates relevant licence applications to other ministries, such as the foreign office and the department for international development, before approval is given. A raft of regulations and guidance notes for exporters restricts the sale of arms or other goods which could be used to make weapons, to regimes embroiled in conflict.

The UK also has to obey EU-wide arms trade embargos. Robin Cook courted controversy after approving the delivery of nine British Aerospace Hawks to Indonesia, part of an export contract agreed under the previous Conservative government. Three were delivered in September 1999, but a four-month EU embargo on arms sales to Indonesia stalled the remaining delivery.

How is the government divided on the issue of arms?

The department of trade and industry works to boost British industry: its ministers and civil servants favour free trade and tend to take a relaxed view of exporting weapons. Similarly, the ministry of defence instinctively supports Britain's arms industry. The secretaries of state for these two ministries, Stephen Byers and Geoff Hoon respectively, are reported to be in favour of lifting restrictions on arms sales to Pakistan.

The foreign office and Claire Short's department for international development are reported to be against lifting arms restrictions on Pakistan. The foreign office works to boost exports with the DTI through British Trade International and the Invest in Britain bureau, and more than a third of foreign office staff time is spent helping British exports and investment opportunities abroad. However, Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, has repeatedly stressed the importance of an ethical foreign policy since 1997.

What about export credit guarantees?

The government's export credit guarantee department (ECGD) operates as insurance for British exporters involved in risky export projects. It guarantees that if a foreign country defaults on paying for British goods the government will recompense the exporter. Last year, more than 50% of ECGD cover supported arms sales.

In December 1999, prime minister Tony Blair controversially allowed an export credit guarantee to be issued to underwrite engineering firm Balfour Beatty's building of a hotly disputed Turkish dam, which will flood 52 Kurdish villages and 15 towns.

Yesterday, chancellor Gordon Brown announced that the treasury would ban export credits for arms sales to 63 of the world's poorest countries. These include Bolivia, Mozambique, Afghanistan and Sri Lanka, as well as countries embroiled in wars, such as Sierra Leone and Ethiopia.

While these moves appear to discourage British arms exporters and bad debt, the Campaign Against the Arms Trade argues that the government has not gone far enough. It says that, with the exception of Sri Lanka, none of the countries listed are big customers of the UK arms trade. Big markets in the past have included Indonesia, Pakistan and Nigeria.

At what point good business becomes bad ethics, as well as bad diplomacy, will continue to trouble the government.

fields.headline: Gloom in the east
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Romney on Russian cinema

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Jonathan Romney on Russian cinema
fields.body:
In 1904, a Russian peasant in the back of beyond murders his brother with an axe, then hops the train to St Petersburg. Arriving in the city, he steps on to the platform and sees something he can't begin to understand - a Frenchman turning a handle on a wooden box. Our man peers closely at this marvel, and gets booted out of the way for his pains. Ninety years later, documentary makers open a can of film - a roll of 1904 Pathé cinematograph footage, showing a train arriving at St Petersburg. It's pretty much a direct remake of the Lumière Brothers' train film of 1895, except for this inopportunely curious hick from nowhere, sticking his bearded face into the lens just when the footage was looking usable. The documentarists trim the film and toss the rejected footage, with our hero on it, into the bin, never to be seen again.

This poignant vignette is the story of Trofim, a 1995 short by Russian film-maker Alexei Balabanov. Trofim can be taken either as a Borges-style parable of the way that history's best anecdotes - the blood-and-passion, true-crime stuff - are invariably consigned to oblivion, or as a scathing comment on practices of film preservation in the former Soviet Union. Or you might see it as an oblique comment on the current status of Russian cinema, which these days, like Trofim the peasant, might as well not exist at all.

The last time the west really noticed Russian-language film was in the early 90s, when there was a brief buzz about the prospects for post-perestroika cinema. But hardly any new Russian films were released in Britain in the 90s, and the few exceptions were barely noted: Sergei Bodrov's critically praised Prisoner of the Mountains made not the faintest stir with audiences, Valery Todorovsky's superb Katia Ismailova - film noir in a Chekhov setting - even less.

There's next to no chance of British exposure for Alexei Guerman's film Khroustaliov, My Car!, a Fellini-esque delirium set in the Stalin era, which provoked disgruntled walk-outs in Cannes in 1998, but went on to be acclaimed as a masterpiece when released in Paris and New York. The only film-maker who has any real western following is Aleksandr Sokurov, whose brief, enigmatic - and for my money, indigestibly mystical - Mother and Son had high-powered pundits such as Paul Schrader and Susan Sontag acclaiming it as the spiritual real deal.

Since the western art-house circuit is still ruled by the cult of the auteur, then a cultish auteur is surely Russian cinema's best chance to re-establish itself on the map. Such a contender gets an airing in Britain this week: Trofim's director Alexei Balabanov, with his first feature Happy Days screening at the ICA. It's the least confident of the three Balabanov features I've seen - the fourth is a version of Kafka's The Castle - but it's as bizarre and distinctive as debuts come.

Tenuously based on Beckett, it has a nameless hero who wanders through St Petersburg's eerily deserted streets, takes up with a faintly demented prostitute and tangles with an angry clock-seller. The logic is entirely dream-like, and although the romantic melancholy takes a little swallowing, Balabanov's eye for grandeur and squalor, from sweeping shots of palace rooftops to explorations of ancient corridors and stairwells, makes Happy Days seem like a film from another time and another planet.

Also due for release this year is the fabulously perverse Of Freaks and Men (1998), a tale of early 20th-century St Petersburg in which two respectable families fall prey to a gang of pornographers: their speciality is filming young Russian maidens getting spanked with birch brooms by stout baboushkas. The silent-era pastiche, all sepia tints, is spot-on, although nostalgists would be horrified by Balabanov's scabrous picture of an art form developing in such profoundly sordid circumstances.

But it's Balabanov's venture into hard realism that has caused most stir in Russia. The 1997 thriller Brother has an apparently clueless young man signing up as a mafia hireling and showing such a propensity for businesslike killing that he soon rises to the top of the criminal tree. A brutally streamlined piece of storytelling, Brother struck Russian audiences as a timely state-of-the-nation horror tale, although there was much debate about its seemingly amoral stance. While young audiences eagerly took to Balabanov's young hood Danila as a modern folk hero, more conservative viewers saw Brother as a shockingly amoral tale that boded ill for the nation's spiritual welfare. Its most notable opponent was the veteran director Nikita Mikhalkov, who attacked it for being "imbued with destruction".

Then again, Mikhalkov himself did Russian cinema no favours with his international pudding of a historical epic, The Barber of Siberia, starring Julia Ormond. This three-hour repertoire of touristic myths of old Russia - bears, vodka and gallant waltzing cadets - proved something of a laughing stock at Cannes last year. Amoral or otherwise, the bracingly cynical Balabanov has succeeded in taking Russian cinema out into the world, and is now completing Brother 2, in which Danila takes on America.

There are no plans yet for The Barber of Siberia 2.

fields.headline: Only in Miami
fields.standfirst: When screenwriter and novelist  Alexander Stuart  was asked to make an offbeat film about America's most vibrant city, he decided to let the locals talk for themselves. Weird was what he wanted and weird was what he got...
fields.trailText: When screenwriter and novelist Alexander Stuart was asked to make an offbeat film about America's most vibrant city, he decided to let the locals talk for themselves. Weird was what he wanted and weird was what he got...
fields.body:
Channel Four may be the only film or TV production company in the world that not only gives you a bundle of money to go off and make something, but actively encourages you to make it weirder - to go that little bit farther, take it to the edge and over the cliff. When Robin Gutch, the then-Commissioning Editor for Documentaries, offered Laura Ashton and me the chance 18 months ago to make a film about Miami, his key words of advice were: "I don't want a travelogue. Do something different. Give me a take on Miami that gets behind the clichés, that gives us a sense maybe of Miami as a liberating city - but also perhaps somewhere that sucks your blood dry. It's a young city, focus on the young people there."

Actually he said nothing quite so lucid - or if he did, I didn't absorb it, since I was in the midst of shooting Tim Roth's film of my novel, The War Zone, and I'd had very little sleep for the past couple of weeks.

I relied on Laura, a dynamic young documentary film-maker with a seemingly inexhaustible energy supply, to rekindle my memory and enthusiasm when, during the five months of making our film, The End Of America (tonight, 12.40am, Channel 4), my own batteries would run flat.

I had lived in Miami - specifically, in increasingly trendy South Beach - for almost eight years, and had written a book about the insanity of everyday existence there called Life On Mars, but of course by the time we came to make the documentary I had moved to Los Angeles, and thus we had to find a justification for me coming back. One of the reasons I had written a non-fiction book about the place was that when I tried to write a novel, I realised that the people I knew - John Hood, for instance, an affluently born white boy who lived his life like a 50s B-movie gangster, right down to the suit and hat - were stranger than anything I could invent.

So for the documentary we thought we'd try the same approach: I would return to Miami from LA to research a movie script, also to be called The End Of America, and we would film me meeting Miami natives - many of them teenagers, like the club kids I had written about in the book - and try to persuade them actually to perform in the drama they inspired. That way, we could make a film which explored, in true docu-soap fashion, the real lives of these characters, while also seeing how those lives might be shaped into some kind of fiction - a loose plot I had developed based on an incident a friend had told me about, when she had shot a gun at a wall in frustration, and realised that she might have accidentally killed someone on the other side.

There is neither the space nor the guaranteed immunity from libel here to fully recount what happened during our collaboration with the likes of Hood (still, remarkably, a good friend of mine), a group of self-proclaimed "Baby Lesbians" (aged between 17 and 24), a 16-year-old Haitian-born boxer called Kervens, a Marilyn-Monroe-impersonating drag queen called Frankie, who happened to be suffering severely with AIDS, or a young Cuban DJ called Sugar, whose five-year-old son, Kaya, was without doubt the most beautiful and stable presence before our cameras.

Let it just be said that one of our subjects, besides being required to appear in court while we were shooting (and be filmed in the dock), chose on the last night of production to allegedly "borrow" the furniture from the apartment building we had been using as a base, and that said furniture was later recovered by the unflappable Ms Ashton from a crack house in downtown Miami.

It is also perhaps relevant that, during the filming of the drama segments of our story, Little Angie and the Baby Lesbians had such a falling out with their only slightly older protector Big Angie (having two Angies was the least of our worries), that they refused to work in the same room together - this despite the fact that they were supposed to be arguing face-to-face with one another on camera. Passions were so frayed on that particular night that one of our producers, who had just arrived from London, was heard to remark, "I didn't know we'd be working with Satan."

Add to this the more predictable difficulties of doing anything in Miami - a town where time means very little to anyone, and where the simple fact of assembling a group of vocal, often sleepy, sometimes druggy, usually transport-less, unpaid kids in one place was an achievement alone worthy of some newly-minted award, perhaps the Golden Bong - and you have an idea of why The End Of America presents Miami as both a beginning and an end: a young city reflecting America's promise, but also a fraught one, mirroring its nation's problems.

But that's Miami for you, an unlikely junction at which the speed and technology of the First World meet the languor, poverty and dusty pastel shades of the Third. A city now so heavily Cuban-populated that Spanish is pretty much the accepted language, and any hint of approval of Fidel Castro will land you at the very least with a filthy look. A heat and humidity-soaked little paradise which I enjoyed living and writing in for eight years of my life. A place where you can lose yourself in madness, reinvent yourself in any conceivable incarnation, or simply, if this happens to be more useful to you, disappear off the face of the earth.

webTitle: Romario runs United out of town

fields.headline: Romario runs United out of town
fields.trailText: Vasco da Gama ensured an all-Brazilian final in the Maracana on Friday despite Quinton Fortune's two goals for Manchester United against South Melbourne.
fields.body:
Vasco da Gama ensured an all-Brazilian final in the Maracana on Friday despite Quinton Fortune's two goals for Manchester United against South Melbourne.

Vasco's 2-1 victory over Necaxa meant they finished second on goal difference in Group B and will go on to face Real Madrid in the third place play-off.

Romario's exquisite finish 21 minutes from time sealed Vasco's triumph against the plucky Mexicans who had given their illustrious opponents several nervous moments.

Necaxa, the reigning CONCACAF champions, took the game to their hosts early on and playmaker Alex Aguinaga slotted them ahead after just five minutes with a low shot from just inside the box.

Vasco, desperate not to miss out on a showpiece final against Sao Paulo-based compatriots Corinthians, were stunned into action and equalised nine minutes later when Odvan timed his jump perfectly to head home at the far post following a corner. Odvan had only come on as a substitute five minutes earlier following an injury to Junior Baiano.

Romario, who scored twice against United last Saturday to break the hearts of the Premiership and European champions, ensured he would bag the headlines once again as he settled matters in the 70th minute, ending an exciting run with a low shot past Necaxa keeper Hugo Pineda.

fields.headline: The best Linda Fiorentino scene
fields.standfirst: Dogma
fields.trailText: Struggling through a melee of anti-abortion protestors, Bethany (Linda Fiorentino) attempts to gain entry to the women's health clinic where she works.
fields.body:
Struggling through a melee of anti-abortion protestors, Bethany (Linda Fiorentino) attempts to gain entry to the women's health clinic where she works.

"You're going to burn in hell", one protestor screams. "Baby killer!"

Bethany looks past the crowd.

"Holy shit!" she exclaims. "It's the Pope!"

As the anti-abortionists bow their heads, Bethany sneaks past them and through the door. Once inside, her colleague Liz (Janeane Garofalo) greets her.

"Jesus, Bethany, you're Catholic, can't you talk to them?"

"They hate me more than you. At least you have an excuse. You're Jewish."

The two women hover over their morning coffee.

"So, where were you yesterday?"

"I went to church."

"That still kills me you're in church. Why, do they do your planned parenthood check?"

"I don't know why I go, Liz. I remember going to church when I was young and being moved. Now I sit there and feel nothing. I don't think I have any faith left."

"Remember that seminary student I tried to set you up with? He told me faith is like a glass of water. When you're young the glass is little, so it's easy to fill. As you get older the glass gets bigger, the same amount of water doesn't fill it any more. So periodically the glass has to get re-filled."

Bethany stares at her coffee.

"You're saying I need to get filled?"

See also: The Last Seduction, After Hours, The Moderns

Don't see also: Jade

Pointless trivia: Linda Fiorentino won her role in Men In Black during a poker game with the director.
