webTitle: Ooh, missus! A star is born as MPs pump out jargon

fields.headline: Ooh, missus! A star is born as MPs pump out jargon
fields.trailText: Bit by bit, parliamentary debate is being taken over by jargon. Yesterday we had questions on the environment, much of which was devoted to incinerators, or the zippier, modern-sounding "energy from waste", as we are now supposed to call the process.
fields.body:
Bit by bit, parliamentary debate is being taken over by jargon. Yesterday we had questions on the environment, much of which was devoted to incinerators, or the zippier, modern-sounding "energy from waste", as we are now supposed to call the process.

Many MPs were angry that these furnaces are pumping out poison, straight into the lungs of their constituents.

Michael Meacher, the minister, was sanguine. "There has been some small increase in primary liver cancers," he said, "but it is not yet clear if this is due to the incinerators." That must have cheered everyone downwind of a pile of smouldering tyres and chemical by-products.

"Currently, no more than one nanogram per cubic metre is released into the atmosphere!" Mr Meacher said.

I always assumed that a "nanogram" was a stripper dressed up as Mary Poppins who comes to Tory MPs' birthday parties and spanks them on the botty with a hairbrush. Apparently it's something much worse.

Hilton Dawson, a decent sort of cove, was hugely en thusiastic about new bus schemes. "Isn't it marvellous," he chirruped merrily, "that local councils are going to be able to meet new targets under Objective Two, and under SRB 6, and 7!"

The environment, bizarre new jargon, impenetrable terminology - our thoughts naturally turned to the deputy prime minister, John Prescott. Yet after one brief, bland answer at the start of the session he said not a word for 44 minutes. I have the suspicion that they are shutting him up. His understrappers are told their hopes of promotion depend on keeping the boss quiet.

"I think I can field this one, John," say his eager junior ministers. "Stamp duty on large-scale voluntary housing transfers? I'm your man!"

"Gosh, sir, you'd really make my day if I could tackle that tough question on the Garstang Super 8 minibus service!"

As a result Mr Prescott sat happy but silent on the front bench, reading a paper entitled Conservative Party News. Possibly he was looking for new government initiatives, as New Labour has stolen all the rest.

None of this mattered, since a star was born yesterday. Keith Hill, the MP for Streatham, now handles transport in the Commons and found himself matched against John Redwood.

Mr Hill is most definitely not gay, but he has developed a camp manner reminiscent of Larry Grayson in The Generation Game. "Ooh," you expect him to say, "Black Rod's coming. Shut that door!"

His voice dives and swoops. His fingers flutter, or occasionally come to rest on his hips. Asked a fierce question about road building by Edward Leigh, he pirouetted round and said: " Madam Spe-e-e-ker!" in a way that might have brought a blush to all of Julian Clary's cheeks.

Mr Redwood asked one of his long, angry, convoluted but curiously ineffective questions, this time about public transport, ending up with an attack on the London underground, which was stopping people getting to the dome, "and is one of the main rea sons why the Big Top is being written off as the Big Flop!"

Mr Hill paused briefly, then said: "More! More! Missus!" (I made up the last word, but it helps convey the flavour.)

"I read an article by you about making the trains run on time. Ooh, yes, our home-grown Mussolini. The Il Duce of the home counties! Yer cheeky cow!" (Likewise with the last phrase.)

Mr Redwood resumed. On New Year's Eve, he raged, no ministers had been in London explaining to revellers how to get home. What on earth did he expect? Keith Hill on the platform with a clipboard, saying: "Take the Jubilee line to Swiss Cottage, and give my regards to Fritz when you're in there. Whoops!"

fields.headline: More ticket booth tales
fields.trailText: I have every sympathy with Cherie Booth's embarrassment at having to pay a fine after boarding a train without a ticket (It's still a £10 fine - even if your name is Cherie Booth, January 11). It is about time that this money-making trick operated by the train monopolies was brought to light.
fields.body:
I have every sympathy with Cherie Booth's embarrassment at having to pay a fine after boarding a train without a ticket (It's still a £10 fine - even if your name is Cherie Booth, January 11). It is about time that this money-making trick operated by the train monopolies was brought to light.

I was fined three times in a year on my way to work simply because a train company would not fix broken ticketing machines at my local station, nor do anything to reduce queues that were often 20 people deep. I now drive to work.
Jon Mainwaring
London

 Not only Mrs Blair, but ordinary rail travellers can be condemned as fare-dodgers under railway companies' policy of making no provision for their own inefficiencies. I follow with a letter my own occasional brushes with those apparently instructed to presume me guilty unless I can prove my innocence, protesting that I am publicly shamed while real fare-dodging is often rampant.

The replies usually involve a refund. I hope Mrs Blair will claim back her £10. It will help those less articulate, and whose headed notepaper is less impressive.
The Rev Horace F Harper
Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs

 Cherie Booth was lucky. I travelled on Connex last year: ticket office closed, ticket machine broken, no guard on the train. I was "apprehended" by an undercover inspector and although I offered to pay the £1 fare I was nicked and subsequently fined £120. I hope Ms Booth's experience brings similar iniquities to light.
Andrew Wood
London

 Owing to wholly inadequate ticketing arrangements at several stations I am often forced to travel on Thameslink services without a ticket until I can purchase one at my destination, but have yet to meet any guard or inspector with the temerity to suggest that I should be the one who is fined for their shortcomings. I cannot help but feel that Mrs Blair was recognised and singled out for this treatment.
Andrew Ward
St Albans

 Some 50 years ago the late Professor CEM Joad was caught travelling by train without a ticket and suffered not only a court appearance and fine, but also the premature ending of a brilliant broadcasting career. How times change.
Allan Horsfall
Bolton

 At least Cherie Booth travels by train.
Jill Forbes
London

fields.headline: Still squabbling over votes
fields.trailText: Paul Whiteley and Patrick Seyd's analysis (Vote winners, January 11) flies in the face of most Labour party activists' experience in the current debate on electoral reform. Every recent test of opinion proves that party members do not want PR for Westminster.
fields.body:
Paul Whiteley and Patrick Seyd's analysis (Vote winners, January 11) flies in the face of most Labour party activists' experience in the current debate on electoral reform. Every recent test of opinion, including the 1998 Labour party conference which demonstrated overwhelming support for retaining First Past The Post, and reported results of the recent consultation exercise, prove that party members do not want PR for Westminster.

It might interest Whiteley and Seyd that trade unions like the AEEU have democratically reached a policy of supporting FPTP. PR is the politics of defeatism and I for one, along with many colleagues of every shade of opinion in the Labour party and trade union movement, want our Labour government to create jobs, improve the NHS and provide ever better education, rather than tinker with the voting system.

Let's face the facts: Labour party members do not want PR, have never wanted PR and will never want PR. Our loyalty is to the Labour party - not to the politics of coalition and defeatism.
Sir Ken Jackson
General secretary
Amalgamated Engineering and Electrical Union

 The survey by Professors Whiteley and Seyd on the support for electoral reform in the Labour party is interesting but not entirely relevant to the recent consultation on the Jenkins report.

The statement put to the panels of Labour members in the survey was whether or not Britain's electoral system should be replaced by a system of proportional representation. Unfortunately for the pro-PR lobby, Labour members have been asked to comment on the particular system of AV plus proposed by Roy Jenkins. Jenkins proposes more party lists, a weakening of the constituency link and coalition governments. Faced with the reality of this system, it is little wonder that Labour members have been less than enthusiastic in their submissions to the party's policy forum. In government, it is not enough to want to change something. You have to be clear about what you are changing to.
Michael Dugher
London

 Jack Straw believes that "people can see that fair votes will lead to very unfair elections" ('Fair and effective' Straw lays down the law, January 10). What people can see is that more proportional voting systems do not allow politicians to do everything they want when they only have minority support within the electorate. They see that Labour, with little more than a third of the vote, was denied outright control of the Scottish parliament and that in the European elections, the Conservatives, with only 36% of the vote, were denied a massive majority over Labour.

It is too early to know what balance of opinion will emerge from Labour's recent consultation but, as the Guardian's coverage of last week's leaks makes clear, Jack Straw's "evidence" of a swing against reform is not of the quality which should satisfy a former barrister.
Dr Ken Ritchie
Chief executive
Electoral Reform Society

 Roy Hattersley has blown the gaff (Fighting the soggy centre, January 10). By opposing PR old Labour "can - and it seems we will - prevent the institutional change which would extinguish all hope of a democratic socialist government ever being elected". In other words, a "democratic" socialist party will never win majority support, so they have to rely on first past the post eventually delivering power on a minority vote. Did he say "democratic"?
Mike Falla
Macclesfield, Cheshire
mike.falla@ukonline.co.uk

fields.headline: Bombs report off target
fields.trailText: Your report (Nato under fire for choice of targets in Kosovo, January 7) incorrectly attributes to Human Rights Watch the claim that unexploded cluster bombs in Yugoslavia are "still killing or maiming two civilians a day."
fields.body:
Your report (Nato under fire for choice of targets in Kosovo, January 7) incorrectly attributes to Human Rights Watch the claim that unexploded cluster bombs in Yugoslavia are "still killing or maiming two civilians a day." We are preparing a report on Nato's use of cluster bombs and their tendency to leave dangerous, unexploded, bomblets on the ground, but we know of no factual basis for such a high casualty figure.

We are concerned that Nato bombed the civilian infrastructure not because it was making a significant contribution to the Yugoslav military effort but because its destruction would squeeze Serb civilians to put pressure on Milosevic to withdraw from Kosovo. Using military force in this fashion against civilians would violate the "principle of distinction" - a fundamental principle of international humanitarian law - which requires mili tary force to be used only against military targets, not against civilians or civilian objects.

By stating that Human Rights Watch is drafting reports "to be submitted to the war crimes tribunal in the Hague," the mistaken impression is given that this is their primary purpose. In fact, as the article notes accurately later, it is unlikely that the Hague tribunal will find any of these possible violations of international humanitarian law to be criminal.

Rather, Human Rights Watch will distribute the reports broadly, including to all Nato governments and defense ministries, with the hope of correcting this disturbing aspect of Nato doctrine in order to avoid unjustified harm to civilians in future wars.
Kenneth Roth
Executive director
Human Rights Watch
rothk@hrw.org

fields.headline: Regional rumblings
fields.trailText: Peter Hetherington may well detect a rising sense of Englishness (Nationalist hail Straw's English awakening, January 11) but he failed to appreciate the even greater sense of English regionalism.
fields.body:
Peter Hetherington may well detect a rising sense of Englishness (Nationalist hail Straw's English awakening, January 11) but he failed to appreciate the even greater sense of English regionalism.

The devolution of power to Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland has indeed led many in Yorkshire and the Humber to demand a greater say in running our own affairs, but I can assure you that no one here is calling for an English parliament (inevitably based in London).

We want to see genuine devolution of powers away from London and to the region to allow us to take control of our own affairs and give voice to Yorkshire aspirations.
Jane Thomas
Director, Campaign for Yorkshire

webTitle: Doctors claim some immunity from criticism

fields.headline: Doctors claim some immunity from criticism
fields.trailText: Alan Maynard (Letters, January 11) criticises general practitioners unfairly for failing to immunise high risk patients against influenza when the government has failed to put in place a system that justly rewards family doctors for the vital work involved in organising an immunisation programme and administering vaccines.
fields.body:
Alan Maynard (Letters, January 11) criticises general practitioners unfairly for failing to immunise high risk patients against influenza when the government has failed to put in place a system that justly rewards family doctors for the vital work involved in organising an immunisation programme and administering vaccines.

To propose extra payments for practice nurses when there are no rewards at present for GPs recognises the value of incentives but fails to understand the contractual relationship of practice nurses with the NHS.

Where Professor Maynard is entirely correct is to point to the cost-effectiveness and desirability of immunising the elderly, those at particular risk because of chronic disease and health care workers themselves. It is particularly regrettable that so few hospitals organise programmes for their own staff.

Far from displaying lethargy, GPs have been involved in immunisation against influenza for a great many years, often organising their own recall systems for patients at risk. However, there would be advantages in centralising these arrangements and in funding the resource implications. The aim we all share is to reduce the number of people suffering from influenza.
Dr JW Chisholm
Chairman, General practitioners committee
British Medical Association

 It is just as well that Alan Maynard is a health economist and not a doctor. He correctly identifies part of the problem relating to the current widespread outbreak of flu, namely that not as many people have been immunised as ideally should have been. However, his diagnosis that this is the fault of GPs is wrong and the solution he prescribes is not the best way forward.

The government has adopted its predecessor's introduction of local development schemes, which could provide the necessary resources to undertake programmes such as large scale flu vaccination.

Sadly, health authorities and their primary care group sub committees have not felt able to fund many such schemes. GPs hope that Professor Maynard will use his influence to obtain adequate funding for the NHS, rather than blame them for its shortcomings.
Dr Tony Stanton
Secretariat for London Local Medical Committees

 Last year's government clamp-down on "sick-note culture" was regrettable. Taking time off sick is seen as a bad career move, with the result that everyone in the office catches flu. My advice: prevention is better than cure, so call in sick before you get ill.
Brian Dean
Chester

 I'm glad we've got the NHS to deal with the flu outbreak. I've had a taster of how the private sector is coping - Tesco has been sold out of paracetamol for my last two visits.
Rom Lucek
Colchester, Essex

webTitle: Shake-up at group making battlefield radio system

fields.headline: Shake-up at group making battlefield radio system
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Days after leaked army documents showed a third of personal radios were broken and sensitive security details overheard by Serbs during the Kosovo conflict, more than half the senior management at the consortium which is building a substitute communications system is to be replaced.
fields.body:
Days after leaked army documents showed a third of personal radios were broken and sensitive security details overheard by Serbs during the Kosovo conflict, more than half the senior management at the consortium which is building a substitute communications system is to be replaced.

BAE Systems will next week unveil a shake-up among directors at the consortium building the battlefield system to ensure it is delivered on time and to budget. Five directors will leave the board.

John Gutteridge, managing director of the consortium, Archer Communications Systems Ltd, is understood to have brought in fresh blood to make sure that the £2.2bn Bowman programme, already running eight years late, can enter service in 2002 or 2003.

The consortium, formed in 1996 from two competing teams, comprises BAE (30%), Racal (30%) and ITT Defence, the military arm of the US telecoms giant (40%). It was, however, placed under BAE's management after changes to ministry of defence requirements and industry in-fighting caused the delays.

Mr Gutteridge will bring in six out of a board of eight directors from organisations such as BAE and Marconi. They include a new finance director, Gary Marsh, a new programme director, Malcolm Peto, a new engineering director, Brian Gill, and a yet-to-be-appointed delivery director.

The new team is designed to refocus the consortium's activities on delivering the Bowman programme within the £2.2bn budget after a re-costing of MoD requirements revealed it could cost up to £4bn.

Bowman, a replacement for the ageing Clansman combat radio that failed in Kosovo, comprises 56,000 back-pack and vehicle-mounted VHF radios. Unlike Clansman, introduced in 1972, it is a digital system offering secure voice and data communications.

The new management team, according to defence sources, is to make a revised commercial offer to the MoD within weeks, with the contract to be implemented by the end of the year.

fields.headline: The 2014 world cup...
fields.standfirst: ...won't be won on school playing fields
fields.trailText: Upon better performance on the playing fields that were not sold off by the Tories depends English identity: for where else does that straw man better express himself (English women do not seem to figure much in the nationalism debate) than on the football or cricket pitch.
fields.body:
Government, these days, is supposed to be joined up. We have to assume then that the Ulsterwoman in charge of sport does sometimes talk to the Essex lad at the home office - or ministry for Englishry as we should perhaps now label it. Kate Hoey has successfully lobbied Ofsted to turn its baleful inspectorial eye upon school sports. It is not just because the reading, writing and reckoning mind should be in a body that can jump high or kick a ball between two posts. Upon better performance on the playing fields that were not sold off by the Tories depends English identity: for where else does that straw man better express himself (English women do not seem to figure much in the nationalism debate) than on the football or cricket pitch.

The model is simple enough. An inspector calls and a generation on, Kevin Keegan's successor, picking from an embarrassment of talent, gets to sweep the 2014 world cup. In his dreams. The fact is, there is no ready correlation between triumph in the school first XI and national sporting success. Besides, it is not clear England has a problem. Look at the success - even if temporary - of David O'Leary's largely home-grown outfit at Leeds: much talent still flows into professional football. English cricket has its problems, true, but they have as much to do with the governance of a sport where the old fart factor remains strong.

On the Continent school sports - activities organised by teachers in school hours - are largely unknown but that has not stopped Les Bleus or impeded Italian skiers. There are all sorts of ways the state can and ought to encourage participation in competitive sport (ballroom dancing and skateboarding included). They do not necessarily include Chris Woodhead's pedagogical stormtroopers getting their stopwatches out to time performance in the 100 metres or measure the penalty-taking potential of England's future Gareth Southgates.

webTitle: Israelis show increasing reluctance to give up Golan

fields.headline: Israelis show increasing reluctance to give up Golan
fields.standfirst: Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, returned from Washington yesterday to mounting domestic opposition to his plans to broker a peace accord with Syria, which would include an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights.
fields.body:
The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, returned from Washington yesterday to mounting domestic opposition to his plans to broker a peace accord with Syria, which would include an Israeli withdrawal from the Golan Heights.

In a week of Middle East peace talks in Shepherdstown, West Virginia, there were few signs of success - not so much as a handshake. And Israelis seem ever more reluctant to pay the price for that peace.

On the eve of Mr Barak's return, 200,000 protesters gathered in Tel Aviv to voice opposition to a withdrawal from the Golan Heights, home to about 17,000 Israelis.

"People are watching this high drama in Shepherdstown and no one here knows what is being discussed," said Marla Van Meter, a spokeswoman for the Golan Residents Committee, which organised Monday night's protest.

"And yet this is as deep, as far-reaching a question for the people of Israel as it goes."

Syria's condition for making peace with Israel is the return of the Golan Heights, which Israel captured in the 1967 six-day war.

As that land-for-peace trade-off moves closer to becoming a reality, the number of Israelis willing to accept it appears to be shrinking. On Friday, an opinion poll for the Dahaf agency found that only 41% of Israelis would back a withdrawal from the Golan Heights in return for peace, down from 45% last month.

Mr Barak must convince Israelis to support any peace deal with Syria, which must pass a referendum before being implemented. His task appeared to grow more complicated yesterday when two of his cabinet ministers said they would quit if he agreed to a full withdrawal from the Golan.

The interior minister, Natan Sharansky, and the housing minister, Yitzhak Levy, both rightwingers in Mr Barak's broad coalition government, said they would leave his cabinet if he acceded to Syria's conditions.

Mr Sharanksy, a former Soviet prisoner of conscience, sat on the stage during Monday's rally, which was well attended by Russian immigrants, who make up about one insix Israelis. They are seen as a potentially worrying opposition to a peace deal on the Golan, as are members of Shas, the ultra-Orthodox party that represents mainly Jews of Middle Eastern descent.

Mr Barak may also find it difficult to maintain public support while making simultaneous concessions to the Syrians and the Palestinians.

While Mr Barak was discussing peace with Syria this past week in the US, his negotiators back home met Palestinian delegates in an attempt to come to an agreement on the framework of a "final status" accord, which Mr Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, agreed would be completed by February 15.

Israel confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to give the Palestinian Authority civilian control over all Arab East Jerusalem neighbourhoods.

Though Palestinians have vowed to establish the capital of their state in East Jerusalem, most Israeli politicians - including Mr Barak -have pledged not to divide Jerusalem and to keep it under Israeli sovereignty.

Mr Sharanksy, a former Soviet prisoner of conscience, sat on the stage during Monday's rally, which was well attended by Russian immigrants, who make up about one insix Israelis. They are seen as a potentially worrying opposition to a peace deal on the Golan, as are members of Shas, the ultra-Orthodox party that represents mainly Jews of Middle Eastern descent. Mr Barak may also find it difficult to maintain public support while making simultaneous concessions to the Syrians and the Palestinians. While Mr Barak was discussing peace with Syria this past week in the US, his negotiators back home met Palestinian delegates in an attempt to come to an agreement on the framework of a "final status" accord, which Mr Barak and the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, agreed would be completed by February 15. Israel confirmed yesterday that it had agreed to give the Palestinian Authority civilian control over all Arab East Jerusalem neighbourhoods. Though Palestinians have vowed to establish the capital of their state in East Jerusalem, most Israeli politicians - including Mr Barak -have pledged not to divide Jerusalem and to keep it under Israeli sovereignty.

fields.headline: 'Assault victim' exhumed
fields.trailText: The body of a 91-year-old woman, who died four days after she was allegedly assaulted in hospital, was exhumed yesterday.
fields.body:
The body of a 91-year-old woman, who died four days after she was allegedly assaulted in hospital, was exhumed yesterday.

Merseyside police removed Elizabeth Vasey's body from Bootle cemetery, Merseyside. A post mortem examination was then carried out.

A criminal inquiry was launched after Mrs Vasey died in Fazakerley hospital, Liverpool, in November. Another elderly patient claimed that Mrs Vasey was assaulted by a hospital carer. She died 17 hours after the alleged assault.

Detective Chief Inspector Tony Doherty said: "Because of the nature of the allegation that Mrs Vasey was assaulted, we will be firstly looking for any signs of an assault and secondly trying to find a possible link between any injury and her death."

It was very upsetting for Mrs Vasey's family and the police were trying to make it as easy as possible for them. The exhumation was attended by Father Martin Poulsom of St Richard's Church in Bootle.

A woman in her 40s was arrested in December in connection with the incident and police say a female member of staff has been suspended by the hospital.

The hospital was unable to comment yesterday.

fields.headline: Irvine faces new bias allegations
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, faces accusations of discrimination against Catholics in a high court challenge by two newly appointed Northern Ireland QCs who are refusing to pledge themselves to well and truly serve the Queen.
fields.body:
The lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, faces accusations of discrimination against Catholics in a high court challenge by two newly appointed Northern Ireland QCs who are refusing to pledge themselves to well and truly serve the Queen.

The allegation confronts the government with an embarrassing issue in the aftermath of the Northern Ireland agreement. This foreshadows rights to guarantee "mutual respect for the identity and ethos of both communities".

The lord chancellor has already been found guilty by an employment tribunal of indirect sex discrimination in appointing a friend, Garry Hart, as his special adviser, bypassing civil service appointment procedures.

Barry Macdonald and Seamus Treacy, the QCs seeking judicial review, are backed by the Northern Ireland bar council. In 1997 the council unanimously resolved that the declaration should be changed to remove the reference to the Queen so as to be acceptable to all practitioners, whatever their political and religious beliefs.

On Monday, Northern Ireland's lord chief justice, Sir Robert Carswell, was also joined in the case as a respondent. Sir Robert wrote to Lord Irvine after the bar's decision saying he had consulted the judges and they wanted the declaration retained. The QCs were unaware of the letter's existence until it emerged last week when their court challenge opened.

Sir Robert's letter to the Lord Chancellor has not yet been disclosed to the other side, and on Monday the case was adjourned for two weeks for further evidence to be produced.

fields.headline: 8m attend church once a year
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: English churches, facing a decline in the number of worshippers, were offered a crumb of comfort yesterday with figures showing that as many as 8m people go to church at least once a year.
fields.body:
English churches, facing a decline in the number of worshippers, were offered a crumb of comfort yesterday with figures showing that as many as 8m people go to church at least once a year.

Amid the gloom of sliding Sunday attendance revealed in a new book, The Tide Is Running Out, published by the English Church Attendance Survey, there were a few bright spots.

The traditional count of people going to any church, including Anglican, Roman Catholic and Methodist, each Sunday showed that the number had slumped from 4.7m in 1989 to 3.7m in 1998, 7.5% of the population.

But for the first time the survey asked about people who went to church less often. It found that 10.2% of the population went at least once a month, 12.6% at least twice a year and 16.2%, or about 8m, at least once a year. In TV terms, said Peter Brierley of the Christian Research organisation which did the survey, this meant that churches had low ratings but high audience reach.

Another glimmer of hope for the church was the number of people, estimated at around 500,000 who did not go to regular Sunday services but attended midweek services or special services for young people.

webTitle: Museum of pop loses its rescuer

fields.headline: Museum of pop loses its rescuer
fields.trailText: Britain's troubled National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield suffered a fresh blow yesterday when its rescuer quit for a better paid job.
fields.body:
Britain's troubled National Centre for Popular Music in Sheffield suffered a fresh blow yesterday when its rescuer quit for a better paid job.

Martin King, who was head-hunted as the saviour of the £15m pop museum only four months ago, said that he was sorry to go but could not turn down an offer to run the Alexandra Palace exhibition centre.

His decision stunned management at the depleted centre, which axed 16 of its 79 jobs in November.

But the search for a replacement of the upbeat impresario, who is 41 and made his name by taking London's Rock Circus to financial success has already begun.

The centre said that visitor numbers were already up following Mr King's initial moves towards lower prices, big name gigs, and more conventional exhibits than the Centre's original, sometimes bafflingly vague, displays

The centre was reprieved by the majority of 200 creditors in November, when Mr King's appointment was the centrepiece of a package to deal with debts of £1.1m.

Visitor targets had earlier been scaled down to 150,000 a year from the initial 400,000 when the centre opened in March last year.

Mr King said that he would remain on the centre's board of directors and was leaving his post as chief executive "with great regret."

webTitle: Briton killed in Spanish holiday villa

fields.headline: Briton killed in Spanish holiday villa
fields.trailText: A British businessman was killed yesterday when he tackled a burglar who had broken into his holiday villa on a golf course in the Costa del Sol.
fields.body:
A British businessman was killed yesterday when he tackled a burglar who had broken into his holiday villa on a golf course in the Costa del Sol. John Robinson, 65, from Willaston, Cheshire, heard a noise soon after 2am and surprised the intruder who hit him on the head with a heavy object before escaping.

Mr Robinson, who had a heart condition, is thought to have died instantly. His wife and 88-year-old mother, who were also in the villa and tried to stop the attack, are suffering from shock.

Police believe the intruder broke into the villa through the kitchen window, the only one not protected by metal bars.

Mr Robinson, who owned a precision engineering firm on Merseyside, bought his home on the Naranjos golf course near Marbella just four months ago. He was a frequent visitor to Spain after having a heart bypass operation two years ago.

A post mortem examination will be carried out to determine whether he died from the blow itself or from other causes.

"Around 500,000 British people live in Spain, mainly on the coasts, and it is very unusual for anything like this to happen," said a British embassy spokesman in Madrid. "Obviously we will give Mr Robinson's relatives and the police any help we can."

Mr Robinson's daughter Yvonne was said to be devastated. Friends described her father as a well liked man devoted to his family.

"It's a desperate waste," said Michael O'Neill, a fellow golfer at Bromborough golf club, Merseyside.

webTitle: World's artists rise to old master challenge

fields.headline: World's artists rise to old master challenge
fields.trailText: The National Gallery has persuaded 24 of the world's leading artists to create works for a new exhibition - free.
fields.body:
The National Gallery has persuaded 24 of the world's leading artists to create works for a new exhibition - free.

Such names as David Hockney, Howard Hodgkin, Lucian Freud, Louise Bourgeois and Claes Oldenburg - whose works sell for millions - all agreed "without the slightest hesitation" to make works inspired by old master paintings in the gallery.

Sir Anthony Caro, best known for his gigantic iron abstract sculptures, has made seven pieces in response to Duccio's tiny 14th century Annunciation.

Others have gone straight to the source. The reclusive Freud, who has spawned more myths and legends than any other British artist, has been haunting the gallery at night. He has already painted two canvasses in front of Chardin's The Young Schoolmistress, and he may again grace the National with his spectral presence before the exhibition, Encounters: new art from old, opens on June 14.

Hodgkin and Leon Kossoff have also taken their sketch books into the building to sit before Seurat's Bathers at Asnières and Rubens's Minerva Protects Pax from Mars.

The gallery's director, Neil MacGregor, said the idea was to match the greatest artists of our time with the greatest of all time.

"This collection has always been the one to which great artists have come to compare themselves. Nowhere else in the world can you see artists from Giotto to Monet in such depth. Monet himself came here in 1871 to see Turner and then painted his famous Thames view in response to his work.

"We did not have to prompt any of the artists at all. They knew straight away which works they wanted to respond to."

He admitted that there might even be "an element of competition" between the likes of Frank Auerbach, Patrick Caulfield, Paula Rego, Jasper Johns, Ian Hamilton Finlay and Antoni Tapies.

Only the National Gallery could assemble such an array of modern artists, he said. "If we were commissioning the works for ourselves - which we could never do - you just couldn't put a figure on it."

Pointedly, none of the YBAs - Young British Artists - led by Damien Hirst will be in the show, although Mr MacGregor said it "would be indecorous to say whether we invited them".

But a number of YBAs had "been involved until a late stage ...They are a movement that is in great demand; they are all very busy indeed."

The idea for the exhibition had more resonance with more mature artists, he said. "As artists get older they get more conscious of the tradition and where their place is in it."

The big surprises are the matching of the emotionally wrenching Auerbach with Constable's quiet landscapes and Oldenburg, who makes cats and compasses as big as buildings, with Vermeer.

Hockney has more predictably chosen the portrait painter Ingres, while Paula Rego, who has already done a version of Hogarth's The Quack, revisits his Marriage a la Mode.

The artists will keep the paintings, sculptures and video installations after the exhibition. Mr MacGregor said it was up them whether the works were then put up for sale.

webTitle: Skeleton in well probably victim of foul play

fields.headline: Skeleton in well probably victim of foul play
fields.standfirst: Inquest hears that woman who went missing in 1942 may have been killed but the prime suspect, the womanising son of a landowner, is dead
fields.trailText: A woman whose remains were found buried in a well 57 years after she disappeared was probably the victim of foul play, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A woman whose remains were found buried in a well 57 years after she disappeared was probably the victim of foul play, an inquest heard yesterday.

Jessie McMahon vanished from her Hampshire home in April 1942, after telling her mother she was going out to collect firewood. The woman's husband and the son of a local landowner were questioned but no charges were brought.

The inquest in Portsmouth heard that her skeleton had been found by workmen last year, and that Mrs McMahon, who disappeared when she was 31, had probably been pushed into the well.

Recording an open verdict, the coroner, James Kenroy, said foul play seemed probable, but the skeleton had lain undiscovered for too long for the cause of death to be identified.

After the inquest, Mrs McMahon's daughter, Eileen Howard, said she was convinced her mother's death had not been an accident.

Workmen were turning the disused well at Liss, near Petersfield, into a garden feature when they discovered the body in June last year. As they excavated the rubble and debris they found the skeleton lying head first in the well.

Detectives traced the wedding ring and shoes which were found with the skeleton.

Local historians told police of a woman who had disappeared from Lyss Place farm during the war and had never been seen again.

From details of the story detectives were able to contact Mrs McMahon's daughters, Eileen and Maureen, who were aged eight and four at the time of the disappearance.

DNA tests eventually linked the remains with the family and she was formally identified as the mother.

In a report read to the inquest, Detective Constable David Keevil said Mrs McMahon's marriage to John McMahon, a bus driver, was stormy and violent.

The family had been evacuated to Liss from Portsmouth several months before the disappearance and Mr McMahon had taken on a second job, driving lorries at night.

On the night of the disappearance, April 29, Mr McMahon had been asleep upstairs at the farm. Mrs McMahon said she was going out to collect firewood and her mother had warned her to be back in time to wake her husband at 9pm.

When her husband woke up he went out to look for her, saying: "I'll kill her when she gets back."

A police and Home Guard search also failed to find any trace of the woman.

Ponds and manure heaps were searched but the well, which was disused, was not. The landowner's son, Alfred Stanley, who had taken part in the search, later emerged as one of the prime suspects.

He was known as a womaniser and was believed to have made advances towards Mrs McMahon.

Speaking after the inquest Mrs Howard said that when she was 13 or 14 she had returned to confront Mr Stanley about the death of her mother, but was told he and his father had gone to Australia.

Mr McMahon was questioned for 24 hours but later released. He died in 1992. The inquest was told that Mr Stanley had also died, although no death certificate could be found.

A home office pathologist, Roger Ainsworth, said there was no evidence of any bones having been broken, and he could not ascertain the cause of death.

Mr Kenroy said it was tragic that two children should have been robbed of their mother and then left ignorant about her fate for more than half a century.

"The circumstances certainly suggest foul play.

"But due to the passage of time it would seem that anyone who could have helped police with their inquiries is now deceased."

Mrs Howard, 65, said her younger sister, who now lived in York, had always hoped her mother had simply run away. But she herself had always believed her mother had been killed.

webTitle: Nervous Glitter apologises after leaving jail

fields.headline: Nervous Glitter apologises after leaving jail
fields.trailText: Gary Glitter's rock career seemed a distant memory when he stepped out of an ageing Mercedes to face the media a few hours after being released from prison yesterday.
fields.body:
Gary Glitter's rock career seemed a distant memory when he stepped out of an ageing Mercedes to face the media a few hours after being released from prison yesterday. Once, the singer would have happily played to the superstar stereotype in front of a bank of cameras; now, Glitter's glam rock get-up could not hide his disgrace.

Facing at least 100 photographers and journalists who had gathered for a photocall in Regent's Park, London, Glitter, who was convicted of child pornography offences, looked unusually uncomfortable in a black crushed velvet suit and outlandish wig. Despite a heavy application of makeup, his face looked drawn and he was unsteady on his feet; he stood unsmiling, his hands buried deep in his pockets, as the cameras whirred from the other side of the street.

He refused a photographer's request to give a thumbs-up sign; after a minute or two, he removed his dark glasses, took a few steps forward, and the media scrum surged around. Holding out his hands in a nervous appeal for calm, Glitter began what appeared to be a prepared statement. "I deeply regret doing what I was sent to prison for," he said.

Quickly, his voice began to falter. "I have served my time. I want to put it all behind me..." He paused, before adding: "... and live my life."

The singer then replaced his glasses, turned to his solicitor, Henri Brandman, and said: "No more." He strode back to the scruffy H-reg car to be driven off, his face hidden behind blacked-out windows.

There was speculation that he was on his way to Heathrow airport for a flight to Havana, to start a new life with his Cuban girlfriend, Yudenia Sosa Martinez, 26. But there was no sign that he had left the country last night.

Mr Brandman had arranged the unusual photocall "on account of the substantial amount of media interest shown in taking a photograph of my client". Hours earlier, Glitter had avoided the waiting media when he was smuggled out of prison after serving two months of a four-month sentence for child pornography offences. Prison officials made special arrangements after receiving anonymous death threats.

Police were on hand at Regent's Park, where two roads were closed to allow the photocall to take place. The singer received a four-month sentence last year when he admitted downloading indecent photographs of children, some as young as two, between January and November 1997. Hours earlier, a jury had cleared him of eight charges of sexually assaulting an underage fan, Allison Brown, now 34.

Glitter, whose real name is Paul Gadd, will be put on the sex offenders' register for seven years, but he is free to travel abroad. Glitter's plans are not known, although he is believed to have sold his house in Wedmore, Somerset, leaving only a flat in London.

A police officer on duty for the photocall said Glitter would be leaving for Heathrow and a flight out of the country. Glitter, 55, has 14 days to inform police of his address in Britain, but if he goes abroad will not have to give details to the authorities.

The singer received a four-month sentence last year when he admitted downloading indecent photographs of children, some as young as two, between January and November 1997. Hours earlier, a jury had cleared him of eight charges of sexually assaulting an underage fan, Allison Brown, now 34. Glitter, whose real name is Paul Gadd, will be put on the sex offenders' register for seven years, but he is free to travel abroad. Glitter's plans are not known, although he is believed to have sold his house in Wedmore, Somerset, leaving only a flat in London. A police officer on duty for the photocall said Glitter would be leaving for Heathrow and a flight out of the country. Glitter, 55, has 14 days to inform police of his address in Britain, but if he goes abroad will not have to give details to the authorities.

fields.headline: Fixated attacker drawn by leather
fields.trailText: A violent intruder with a leather fixation who attacks women alone at home has struck for the eighth time, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A violent intruder with a leather fixation who attacks women alone at home has struck for the eighth time, police said yesterday.

The man is thought to select well-dressed victims, including secretaries and members of the legal profession, and keep them under surveillance before striking.

All the attacks have taken place in south-east London since last September and the man has demanded "trophies" of leather trousers, purses and gloves from the women.

One 42-year-old victim said yesterday she had become too scared to use a vacuum cleaner in case it drowned out the sound of an intruder breaking into her home. She had just got in through her front door when the man ordered her to hand over a glove and her purse.

"He was fairly calm but insistent upon what he wanted. At one point he hit me a couple of times because I couldn't give him what he was asking for - I didn't have my purse on me."

She escaped to neighbours to raise the alarm but said she had completely changed since the attack. "I get paranoid about every noise as if someone has come in my house. I used to be an independent person but now I can't go out or back into my house without someone coming in with me."

Some of the victims, aged from their 20s to their 50s, are thought to have been followed as they walked home alone from railway stations after work.

In the latest attack on Monday night, a 50-year-old woman was confronted at her home in Catford by a man dressed in black with a stocking mask over his face. He grabbed the woman, demanding her leather gloves and shoulder bag.

Detective Chief Inspector Phil Fitzgerald, who is heading the inquiry, said: "It's about power, control and violence which suggests there might be a more sinister motive as to why he's terrorising these women.

"He has made no sexual advances at the moment and he has made no threats to cause someone serious injury. But since the start of this series the violence has increased. We have got to find that man before someone gets seriously hurt."

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Payout in council sex bias case
fields.body:
Payout in council sex bias case

An out-of-court settlement of £135,000 was agreed yesterday for two council officials who complained of sex discrimination by the authority's legal department.

South Lakeland district council, in Cumbria, will pay £125,000 to its head of legal services, Anne Mayo, and £10,000 to Jane Sandham, a former solicitor.

Mrs Mayo complained her job had been undermined after she returned to work from maternity leave in 1997.

Recycling is 'pathetically low'

Recycling rubbish in Britain is at a "pathetically low" level, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, told the Commons yesterday, as he promised that a report into the growing rubbish mountain would be unveiled by the spring.

He said the government's waste strategy would shift the priority away from land fill to the maximum possible increase in recycling.

Red lion logo returns to eggs

The red lion quality mark will soon be back on British eggs nearly 30 years after it disappeared. Producers hope the return of the popular logo, after an intensive programme to reduce salmonella, will help the fight against cheap imports.

20m turn to EastEnders

EastEnders' double wedding and the surprise return of jailed Matthew Rose drew the biggest soap audience for a year, official viewing figures showed yesterday, with 20.89m people tuning in for the New Year's Eve screening of the BBC1 show and its Sunday repeat.

Land-Rover adverts attacked

The Advertising Standards Authority has criticised Land-Rover for adverts it said encouraged dangerous driving and suggested the Discovery four-wheel drive was powerful enough to tow an aeroplane.

It has told the company not to use the newspaper adverts again.

webTitle: The nun who took on Rome

fields.headline: The nun who took on Rome
fields.standfirst: Ordination of women Catholic writer angry at failure to deal directly with female dissenters
fields.trailText: With her feminist views, funky clothes and pierced ears, Lavinia Byrne did not fit the shy, wimpled image of the nun.
fields.body:
With her feminist views, funky clothes and pierced ears, Lavinia Byrne did not fit the shy, wimpled image of the nun.

Yet she thought she was being true to her vows of poverty, chastity and obedience in her order, the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary. She believed that on the cusp of the new millennium the Roman Catholic church was broad enough to live with her view that it was time for women to be ordained.

She was wrong. Explaining her decision yesterday to confront her Vatican tormentors and quit the order she joined as a teenager in the 1960s, she poured out her anger that the elderly men in Rome who forced her to leave would not even deal with her direct.

"What I'm concerned about now is not so much the debate about the ordination of women, because if it's God's will, it's going to happen anyway," she said. "My concern is the way people in the Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith deal with dissenters."

In her statement announcing her departure from the institute, she described how the CDF refused to deal direct with the objects of its displeasure, instead letting its demands trickle down through the heirarchy. "The rightful and necessary administration of the church becomes a faceless bureaucracy condemning individuals without hearing their story or point of view."

She told the Guardian last night that despite her high profile as a writer and broadcaster in England and Wales, the fate of Catholic women was to be "an invisible sub-species". "The lot of most Catholic women is to be deeply devout, to pray, to be there in church on Sunday and not to count. The way that manifests itself is that only men can represent Christ."

She said the intolerable pressure from Rome was a "sad sign of the times": "There was a time when some of the most original thinking in the church came from the religious."

John Wilkins, editor of the Catholic weekly the Tablet, said last night: "It's a great tragedy when an outstanding religious sister like that finds herself unable to continue with integrity within her order. It should make us all wonder whether the structures we work within are satisfactory."

Kevin Flaherty, editor of the Catholic Times, said: "It does not seem to me as though she denounced any part of the Catholic faith. It all gives the wrong impression to the secular world. I'm sure the CDF is well intentioned but it does give the impression of acting a bit like the thought police."

There are few men in the Vatican closer to the Pope than the head of the CDF, Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger.

The Bavarian-born prelate, 72, has held his post at the heart of Vatican counsels for 18 years. As speculation increases about the Pope's health, many liberal Catholics believe a group of ultra-conservative cardinals, Ratzinger foremost among them, has effectively taken over the running of this world religion, with potentially unpleasant consequences for the faithful.

For years Cardinal Ratzinger and his colleagues have been fighting a rearguard action to prevent the spread of liberal ideas among the waning priesthood and congregations of Europe. The bitter struggle has left the church in countries such as Germany, Austria, Switzerland and France divided, with their powerful liberal wings increasingly ready to challenge the Vatican's authority.

So far, England and Wales have escaped the turmoil. There has been a perception that Rome held back from trying to impose its will on Catholics here who did not toe the Vatican line. Much of the credit for persuading the Pope and Cardinal Ratzinger to allow English Catholics their "specialness" went to the late Cardinal Basil Hume, who constantly intervened behind the scenes to prevent open confrontation.

To the Catholic establishment's increasing dismay there is still no sign of a replacement for Cardinal Hume. There were always fears that his absence would leave the church in England and Wales exposed to new pressure from Cardinal Ratzinger and his allies.

The CDF is responsible for enforcing acceptance of Catholic dogma among every member of the priestly hierarchy. Cardinal Ratzinger interprets his task zealously. He frowns on any public discussion of the possibility of women priests, married priests or gay clergy.

"One cannot establish the truth by resolution," he once said. "One can only recognise and accept it."

webTitle: Man held over killings in France

fields.headline: Man held over killings in France
fields.trailText: Portuguese and French police yesterday arrested a suspected serial killer wanted in connection with the murders of three young women in France, including the Birmingham university student Isabel Peake who was thrown from an express train in October.
fields.body:
Portuguese and French police yesterday arrested a suspected serial killer wanted in connection with the murders of three young women in France, including the Birmingham university student Isabel Peake who was thrown from an express train in October.

Sid Ahmed Rezala, 20, the target of a nationwide manhunt since December when he was first linked with the crimes, was detained in Lisbon yesterday afternoon after a Franco-Portuguese operation, a Dijon investigating magistrate, Frederic Desaunettes, said.

He added the suspect, a French Algerian from Marseille, had been found "partly due to his continued use of a mobile telephone", but declined to give further details .

Judicial sources in Paris said he had been picked up by Portuguese and French officers in a street in the Lisbon suburbs. The arrest had been as "the result of a phone-tapping operation on his close friends and acquaintances", one source said.

He added Rezala was being held in a Lisbon prison awaiting a formal extradition request from France.

Rezala, described by police as a lawless drifter who had collected more than 40 bookings for travelling on the railways without a ticket, was released from prison last May after serving a term for assault using a knife.

The partially clothed body of Ms Peake, 20, was found beside the tracks used by the Brive-Paris night train on October 13. The French and law student, from Barlaston, Staffordshire, was on her way to England from Limoges, where she was two weeks into an exchange year.

The early shortcomings of the investigation led to criticism of French police methods in the British press. In the past 20 years, there have been 23 unsolved murders of Britons in France, including Caroline Dickinson, the Cornish schoolgirl raped and suffocated in a Brittany youth hostel in 1996.

Police in Limoges and Chateauroux, near where Isabel's body was found, took nine days to open a murder inquiry. A month later they produced a photofit of a man aged 20 to 30, of north African origin. He was described as 1.7m-1.8m (5ft 6in-5ft9in) tall, of moderate build, with short dark curly hair and wearing a baseball cap back to front.

Several witnesses reported seeing him at Limoges station on October 13, and one saw Isabel boarding the train with him. He was also one of two men booked for travelling on the service without a ticket. But the photofit met with little response and the Limoges detectives appeared to have lost all chance of tracing their suspect when the body of Corinne Caillaux 33, was discovered in the toilet of the Calais-Ventimiglia sleeper service on December 13, near Dijon, central France. She had been stabbed 15 times.

Police investigating Isabel's murder arrived in Dijon with a photofit of their chief suspect the next day, and were rewarded with a likely match.

The Dijon police's suspect had also been travelling without a ticket, but had been identified because he had to check in for the sleeper service. A blood-soaked baseball cap was found on the train.

Four days later, the body of Emilie Bazin, a former girlfriend of Rezala reported missing in October, was discovered in a house in Amiens, northern France, where he stayed regularly.

webTitle: Police van on wrong side of road when it hit newsreader

fields.headline: Police van on wrong side of road when it hit newsreader
fields.trailText: A police driver who knocked down the Channel 4 newsreader Sheena McDonald was on the wrong side of the road, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A police driver who knocked down the Channel 4 newsreader Sheena McDonald was on the wrong side of the road, a court heard yesterday.

Glenn Whiteley, 27, a constable with the Metropolitan police, pleaded not guilty to driving without due care and attention when he appeared before Horseferry Road magistrates, London.

The accident happened last February near Miss McDonald's home in Islington, north London, when Whiteley was answering an emergency call with a colleague. One witness said the police van had been travelling fast but had slowed before it hit Miss McDonald, 44, who was crossing the road.

She suffered brain injuries and was in a coma for 72 hours, remained in intensive care for two weeks, and needed treatment for a further two months.

Helen McCormack, prosecuting, said Whiteley found his path blocked by stationary traffic, so drove on the other side of the road, travelling in the wrong direction.

The van's sirens and flashing lights were on, but Whiteley's colleague warned him the pedestrian was looking in the wrong direction.

"His fellow police officer noted that she appeared to be looking away from the direction they were coming from," said Miss McCormack. "But PC Whiteley was later to tell an officer investigating the case that she had glanced in his direction and he had assumed that, because he had his sirens on, she would have seen him."

Miss McCormack said although he slowed, Miss McDonald was struck by the front passenger side of the van, which braked, carried on a few yards and stopped. "But it had to be reversed to free her from the van," she said.

Paulo Canaccuti, who saw the accident, told the court: "They were travelling really fast at around 40 to 45mph, I guess."

PC Malcolm Cumberlidge, an accident reconstruction specialist, said Whiteley had been driving too close to the centre of the road.

"The vehicle should have been slightly further to the right of the road, which would have been a safer distance. This would have given him more time to avoid pedestrians," he told the court.

He added that the driver was travelling at a considerable speed, but from studies of the accident it was clear he had slowed considerably at the time of the accident.

Miss McDonald will not be giving evidence, but in a statement said she had been returning from a lecture in Piccadilly, where she had drunk two glasses of wine.

The case continues today.

webTitle: Prisoner release at risk if LVF carried out killing

fields.headline: Prisoner release at risk if LVF carried out killing
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: First minister David Trimble yesterday called on Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to consider halting the early release of Loyalist Volunteer Force prisoners if the dissident outfit proved to be behind the killing of a Portadown businessman.
fields.body:
First minister David Trimble yesterday called on Peter Mandelson, the Northern Ireland secretary, to consider halting the early release of Loyalist Volunteer Force prisoners if the dissident outfit proved to be behind the killing of a Portadown businessman.

Police, keen to avoid escalation of a long-running feud between loyalist factions in Co Armagh, last night arrested several people over the shooting dead on Monday at his home outside Portadown of Richard Jameson, 46. Among them were LVF members.

A gunman shot Mr Jameson, a roofing contractor, five times as he parked his car.

Security sources said Mr Jameson was leader of the mainstream Ulster Volunteer Force in mid-Ulster. But his brother, Bobby, vice-chairman of Portadown football club, said: "Richard was a hard working family man with no links to the UVF. He had only one fight, and that was against drugs."

Mr Mandelson demanded a report on the murder from the chief constable of the RUC, Sir Ronnie Flanagan. He could halt the early release of eight LVF prisoners under the Good Friday agreement.

There are fears that the UVF could break its five-year ceasefire to avenge Mr Jameson, described as a staunch supporter of the Good Friday agreement.

Fears over the fragile peace process rose yesterday when the Irish News reported that the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh bombing, which killed 29 in August 1998, was planning a statement next week. There is speculation it could end its ceasefire.

The UVF had recently embarked on an aggressive recruitment drive, winning back many who had defected to the LVF, and there was also friction over LVF members' drug dealing activities.

Tensions came to a head two weeks ago. Mr Jameson is alleged to have led an attack on three LVF remand prisoners out on Christmas parole as they drank in a Portadown social club.

Police sources said Mr Jameson had broken an unwritten rule among paramilitaries by attacking prisoners. But UVF sources indicated he had been assaulted first, before returning with a gang armed with baseball bats. A dozen people were hurt, two seriously.

Mr Trimble, in whose Upper Bann constituency the murder occurred, visited the victim's widow, Moira, yesterday. He said that the family wanted no retaliation, and he pleaded for calm.

webTitle: Indecency offence no bar to job in social services

fields.headline: Indecency offence no bar to job in social services
fields.standfirst: Councils 'need clearer guidelines to protect the rights of children'
fields.trailText: Almost three quarters of local authorities would appoint a job applicant with a previous conviction for indecent exposure as a social worker for children and families, research has found.
fields.body:
Almost three quarters of local authorities would appoint a job applicant with a previous conviction for indecent exposure as a social worker for children and families, research has found.

Even more authorities would be willing to appoint somebody with a record of assault, and a majority would accept a candidate convicted of drink-driving, according to the study.

Only three of 118 authorities surveyed would reject an applicant on grounds of a previous conviction for possession of cannabis, even though official guidance on recruitment says drug offences should give rise to concern.

The study was carried out by Joanne Smith, senior lecturer in social work at Plymouth university. She said the findings revealed alarming inconsistency and showed a need for the government to set clearer guidelines to protect the rights of both children and ex-offenders.

"At the moment, you could tell people with certain offences to their name: 'Don't apply here, here and here, because they won't accept you. But do apply here, here and here'," Ms Smith said yesterday.

The study, reported in the January issue of Professional Social Work, the journal of the British Association of Social Workers, involved interviews with those responsible for making decisions in cases where a social work job applicant has a criminal record.

Ms Smith put forward hypothetical cases ranging from two convictions for shoplifting to one for indecent assault on a child. Recruiters, who were told that the applicants were suitable in every other respect, could ask for details of the offences and the candidate's explanation for them.

Of the 118 authorities in England and Wales which took part, 85% said they would be prepared to appoint somebody convicted of house burglary or of causing actual bodily harm, 74% would accept a candidate convicted of indecent exposure, and 57% would appoint somebody found to have driven under the influence of alcohol. Yet only 32% would approve an applicant with a fraud conviction.

In what Ms Smith described as an "astonishing" finding, six authorities were prepared to offer a job to somebody convicted of indecent assault on a child - five of them because the supposed offence had occurred more than 20 years previously and one because of its nature.

The offence, which the mythical candidate still denied, was said to have happened while he was playing with the eight-year-old daughter of a friend. The sixth authority decided it "probably wouldn't happen again".

Ms Smith said the six authorities had been interviewed in the early stages of her research, before publicity surrounding the conviction of foster parent Roger Saint for indecent assault on boys placed in his care despite a previous conviction.

No authority interviewed after the Saint case had said it would accept the candidate with an indecent assault record. However, Ms Smith said there was still "nothing to stop" an authority doing so.

The fictional case which provoked the most divided views among authorities was that of a woman applicant with two shoplifting convictions: 54% of authorities said they would appoint her and 46% said they would not.

A key factor for many authorities was that the woman was said to have failed to disclose one of the offences - a sign of dishonesty which, as with the fraud conviction, was widely felt to rule her out even though it bore no direct relevance to the job.

Ian Johnston, BASW director, said some of the concerns raised by the research would be addressed by the regulatory body for social workers, proposed in the government's care standards bill.

"It's a complex issue because we believe that people should not necessarily be debarred from the profession for life," Mr Johnston said. "On the other hand, the protection of children and vulnerable adults must be the primary concern."

fields.headline: Tories' legacy of poverty
fields.standfirst: Study shows Britain had worst record for deprivation in the westTories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Two decades of Conservative rule left Britain with the worst poverty record in the developed world, according to figures produced last night by the west's leading economic think thank.
fields.body:
Two decades of Conservative rule left Britain with the worst poverty record in the developed world, according to figures produced last night by the west's leading economic think thank.

Poverty affected 20% of the British population a year on average between 1991 and 1996, said the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

During the six years of the study, 38% of the population spent at least one year below the poverty line.

In the US, which has the next worst record, the average proportion of the population facing poverty each year was 14%, and the proportion spending at least one year below the poverty line was 26%.

The British government has vowed to abolish child poverty within a generation, but a report from the Joseph Rowntree foundation in December suggested that so far it has had little impact on widening inequality, one of the factors which drove the rise in poverty under the Tories.

The OECD's findings challenge the commonly held view that the world's largest economy also suffers from the most ingrained deprivation. Britain performed worse than the US on every count - average poverty rates, long-term poverty rates and the proportion who experienced poverty at some point over the six years.

"This report shows the chal lenge of worklessness and poverty that this government inherited," a treasury spokesman said.

"It also supports the government's approach that the best way out of poverty is to get people off welfare into work and to make work pay."

The OECD research found that gaining employment was the main factor in reducing the length of time spent in poverty in all the countries in the study.

Poverty affected 10% of the population on average in Germany, while in Sweden and the Netherlands the figures were 7.4% and 6.1% respectively.

Britain not only had the highest average poverty rates over the period of the study, it also had the worst problem with long-term poverty.

Using panel data which enabled researchers to track people's incomes over time, the OECD research showed that 6.1% of people in Britain were below the poverty line for all six years, while in the US the proportion was 4.6%.

Long-term poverty is virtually unknown in the rest of Europe.

In the Netherlands, less than 1% of the population suffered poverty for the entire six years of the study, while in Sweden and Germany the proportion was under 2%.

Unemployment has fallen by nearly a million since the OECD study was conducted, which could have significantly reduced the numbers below the poverty line in Britain.

However, the shrinking jobless queues will not help lift retired people out of poverty and the OECD research shows that Britain has more elderly poor than any other country in the west.

Britain's social welfare system plays a vital role in lifting families out of poverty, according to the OECD.

Without the safety net of benefits, the numbers below the poverty line would have been even higher - with one in three people experiencing poverty on average and more than half the population dipping below the poverty line at some point in the six years of the study.

webTitle: Dome chaos zone victims get payout

fields.headline: Dome chaos zone victims get payout
fields.standfirst: The millennium: special report
fields.trailText: Thousands of guests who spent much of New Year's Eve queuing at a tube station in east London trying to reach the Millennium Dome's opening party are to receive compensation for the delay, it was announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Thousands of guests who spent much of New Year's Eve queuing at a tube station in east London trying to reach the Millennium Dome's opening party are to receive compensation for the delay, it was announced yesterday.

All 6,500 people who travelled from Stratford station will be offered a free dome visit, a souvenir brochure and vouchers worth £15 to be spent on food, drink and merchandise at the attraction in Greenwich.

"We recognise that many people coming through Stratford on New Year's Eve did not arrive in time to see the zones," Jennie Page, the chief executive of the New Millennium Experience Company, said. "The ticket vouchers we are providing mean they will be able to come back, with their guests, and see the zones and the millennium show in happier times."

The chaos at Stratford was the first of what has turned out be a series of public relations disasters since the dome opened. Some of the zones have experienced long queues, while others have been criticised for a lack of imagination, irritating visitors and sponsors.

Three thousand people were delayed at Stratford, but the offer is open to everyone who travelled via the station, the company said.

Delays in sending out invitations by post meant many guests had to pick up their tickets at Stratford, adding to the chaos created by the need for everyone to pass through a security checkpoint at the station.

NMEC said the voucher scheme would cost £130,000.

In a letter to all the Stratford guests, Ms Page wrote: "On behalf of NMEC, and everyone involved in these arrangements, I would like to offer our most sincere apologies for the problems you experienced."

Tony Blair and a number of cabinet and shadow cabinet ministers escaped the mayhem at Stratford by travelling to the dome by tube from Westminster with 50 award-winners and their guests.

webTitle: Nun quits over ordination of women

fields.headline: Nun quits over ordination of women
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: One of Britain's best-known Catholic writers and broadcasters, the nun Lavinia Byrne, has left her religious order in despair after she was ordered by the Vatican to stop supporting the ordination of women priests.
fields.body:
One of Britain's best-known Catholic writers and broadcasters, the nun Lavinia Byrne, has left her religious order in despair after she was ordered by the Vatican to stop supporting the ordination of women priests.

Ms Byrne yesterday accused the Vatican's Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith, which ordered her to endorse the Pope's ban on women priests, of acting like the Inquisition.

The pressure from Rome which forced Ms Byrne, 52, to quit the Institute of the Blessed Virgin Mary will disturb the 4m Roman Catholics in England and Wales.

There is a fear that ultra-conservatives in the Vatican will use the lack of a spiritual leader in Westminster since the death of Cardinal Basil Hume, and the frailty of Pope John Paul II, to impose a harsher doctrinal regime on the British Catholic hierarchy.

The CDF ordered Ms Byrne to recant 18 months ago, after her book, Woman at the Altar, in which she argued for women priests. Ms Byrne, a contributor to BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day, said she had kept her head down, but could keep silent no longer.

"The way the CDF works is deeply unpleasant, and smacks of the techniques used by the Inquisition to silence people," she said.

fields.headline: The health check
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Seven days ago a team of senior doctors spent more than six hours examining the former Chilean dictator at the Northwick Park NHS hospital in Harrow, north-west London, after he arrived in a motorcade flanked by bodyguards, a delegation from the Chilean embassy and two doctors - his Surrey GP and a Chilean physician - who were allowed to observe the medical tests.
fields.body:
Seven days ago a team of senior doctors spent more than six hours examining the former Chilean dictator at the Northwick Park NHS hospital in Harrow, north-west London, after he arrived in a motorcade flanked by bodyguards, a delegation from the Chilean embassy and two doctors - his Surrey GP and a Chilean physician - who were allowed to observe the medical tests.

Both supporters and opponents knew the results could pave the way for Mr Straw to send the general back to Chile on humanitarian grounds.

General Pinochet was taken through the back door to the Lister unit for infectious diseases, where he was examined in isolation for security reasons. While police with sniffer dogs patrolled outside and officers stood guard at the doors, the general was examined by a team led by two gerontologists and a neurologist before being whisked back to Wentworth in the late afternoon.

Various stories were leaked to the press about Gen Pinochet's health. They included an account of how a priest had been called to the general's Wentworth home to administer the last rites after he took a sudden turn for the worse. He recovered sufficiently for the priest not to be needed when he finally arrived.

Gen Pinochet's problems are believed to include:

Heart - He wears a pacemaker.

Renal - He suffers from incontinence, possibly brought on by diabetes.

Neurological - He is said to have had three small strokes, suffers from a loss of short-term memory, unsteadiness and fuzzy speech.

Back - He was recuperating from a back operation in London when he was arrested in 1998.

Depression - Brought on by spending 16 months under house arrest.

webTitle: Rape jailing may bar Tyson from UK

fields.headline: Rape jailing may bar Tyson from UK
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson, the fearsome boxer whose record over the  past few years includes a number of world titles and  convictions for rape and assault, is to rely on the  compassion of the immigration service if he is to be  allowed to enter Britain for a fight at the end of the  month.
fields.body:
Mike Tyson, the fearsome boxer whose record over the past few years includes a number of world titles and convictions for rape and assault, is to rely on the compassion of the immigration service if he is to be allowed to enter Britain for a fight at the end of the month.

Home office officials confirmed yesterday that Tyson would be prevented from entering the country because of his 1992 US conviction for rape and that the only way he can get into Britain is on "compassionate grounds" to be decided by immigration officials.

According to immigration rules, entry to Britain should be refused to anyone who has committed a crime that would carry a 12-month jail term or more in Britain.

Tyson, who was also convicted last year of assaulting two motorists, is due to fight the British boxer Julius Francis in Manchester on January 29. All 21,000 seats for the bout at the MEN Arena in Manchester have been sold.

Tyson will earn around £5m for the fight, while his opponent will receive £350,000.

Representatives of Tyson, who is due to arrive in London this Sunday, are to make representations to the home office claiming there are strong compassionate grounds for allowing him into the country.

The home office said: "Compassionate grounds are usually decided by the immigration officals at point of entry or by the immigration service prior to departure. Broadly speaking, if we know someone has a conviction for rape then they are not allowed to enter the country. We cannot comment on individual cases."

The fight is being promoted by the Sports Network company, owned by Frank Warren, who said: "It is not a closed door and we are working on it."

American citizens are allowed to enter Britain without a visa for up to six months. Tyson does not need a work permit for this month's fight and foreigners arriving in this country do not have to declare their criminal convictions.

A Downing Street spokesman hinted yesterday that immigration rules might have to be upheld if Tyson tries to gain entry to Britain. He added: "The room for discretion is very limited. The decision will be taken by immigration officals."

Women's groups also called on the government to take a firm stand on the issue and refuse Tyson entry to Britain. A spokeswoman for Women's Aid said: "The government has to take sexual violence against women very seriously. Many young people make icons of celebrities and if they are seen to get away with certain types of behaviour then what sort of message is that sending out."
