webTitle: Statement that signals freedom for general

fields.headline: Statement that signals freedom for general
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Key extracts from yesterday's home office statement:
fields.body:
Key extracts from yesterday's home office statement:

"The Secretary of State has over past months received a number of representations concerning Senator Pinochet's state of health.

Until last October, these did not appear to suggest any material change in the position since the Secretary of State's consideration of issues relating to Senator Pinochet's health at the time he gave Authority to Proceed in the case on 14 April 1999.

Senator Pinochet has not himself since then made direct representations to the Secretary of State about his state of health, nor has he at any time put his fitness to stand trial directly in issue in any legal proceedings in the case.

Representations on the subject were, however, submitted by the Chilean Embassy on 14 October 1999, attaching recent medical reports on Senator Pinochet...

... When the Secretary of State first received, from the Chilean Embassy, indications supported by medical evidence that the situation might have changed, he took the view that he needed to inform himself more fully before deciding whether any further action by him might be appropriate.

He therefore requested Senator Pinochet to undergo a thorough and extensive medical examination, to be undertaken by an eminent team of clinicians ...

... The examination was undertaken on January 5 by a team of expert clinicians established by the Secretary of State as being of outstanding national and international reputation and as having no inappropriate personal interest in the case ...

... The Secretary of State has now received the team's report. The detail of the report is and remains confidential to Senator Pinochet, but the unequivocal and unanimous conclusion of the three medical practitioners and the consultant neuropsychologist is that, following recent deterioration in the state of Senator Pinochet's health which seems to have occurred principally during September and October 1999, he is at present unfit to stand trial, and that no change to that position can be expected.

In the circumstances, the Secretary of State is minded, subject to any representations he may receive, to take the view that no purpose would be served by continuing the present extradition proceedings and that he should therefore decide not to extradite Senator Pinochet.

The Home Office is writing to the Crown Prosecution Service as representatives of the Kingdom of Spain and to the Government of Chile, informing them of the above matters and inviting them to make representations.

Letters are also going to France, Belgium and Switzerland who have outstanding extradition requests.

Amnesty International, the Caring for Victims of Torture Medical Foundation, the Redress Trust, the Association of Disappeared Persons in Chile and Human Rights Watch, have been invited, in the circumstances, to submit any further representations they consider the Secretary of State should take into account ...

... All representations are sought within seven days.

Senator Pinochet has been asked to agree to Spain and other countries with an outstanding extradition request being provided with a copy of the medical report; he has, however, declined to do so."

webTitle: Ailing Pinochet to be sent home

fields.headline: Ailing Pinochet to be sent home
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet is to be sent home next week after a series of medical tests found that he was unfit to stand trial, the home office announced last night.
fields.body:
The former Chilean dictator General Augusto Pinochet is to be sent home next week after a series of medical tests found that he was unfit to stand trial, the home office announced last night.

In a move that will horrify human rights campaigners, Jack Straw, the home secretary, said he was "minded not to extradite" Pinochet in the light of the medical evidence.

In a statement, the home office said the "unequivocal and unanimous" conclusion of a four-strong medical team who examined Pinochet on January 5 was that he was "at present unfit to stand trial, and that no change to that position can be expected".

It added: "In the circumstances, the secretary of state is minded, subject to any representations he may receive, to take the view that no purpose would be served by continuing the present extradition proceedings and that he should therefore decide not to extradite Senator Pinochet."

Mr Straw is to give the Spanish authorities, who are seeking Pinochet's extradition, seven days to raise objections. Home office sources indicated last night that Pinochet would be sent home next week.

One source said: "Pinochet will be going back to Chile rapidly after the seven-day deadline is over."

webTitle: Enemies clamour for trial in Chile

fields.headline: Enemies clamour for trial in Chile
fields.standfirst: Santiago General's foes lament 'terrible blow' as fans rejoice Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: As the news spread in the Chilean capital that General Augusto Pinochet is unfit to stand trial in Spain for human rights abuses, his foes were quick to demand that the 84-year-old former dictator should face justice at home
fields.body:
As the news spread in the Chilean capital that General Augusto Pinochet is unfit to stand trial in Spain for human rights abuses, his foes were quick to demand that the 84-year-old former dictator should face justice at home. He should also withdraw from politics if he is allowed to return to Chile, they said.

The news of his impending freedom came as "a terrible blow" at the headquarters of an organisation of relatives of dissidents who disappeared after being arrested during Gen Pinochet's 1973-90 regime.

"We deeply lament that health, humanitarian reasons may bring Pinochet back home," said Mireya Garcia, the vice-president of the Organisation of Relatives of Missing Detainees. "This is very bad news for Chile and for justice."

"We believe that, although Pinochet is indeed very old and has problems, he was in shape to stand trial," she said.

"We no longer can expect that justice can be served in any country, when it comes to this kind of crime."

Across town, at the Pinochet Foundation, a private group of Pinochet supporters and former aides, the reaction was one of joy.

"Are you sure?" an official asked when told the news. "This is simply wonderful."

Retired army General Rafael Villarroel, a former close aide to Gen Pinochet, said: "This is going to be good for Chile, for our fatherland, because a process starts to restore its sovereignty and dignity."

Alberto Cardemil, a congressman and close associate of Gen Pinochet, described the British decision as "a victory for a national cause".

The British government made its announcement after receiving a report by a team of four doctors who examined gen Pinochet last week at the request of the Chilean government.

The doctors unanimously agreed that Gen Pinochet was "at present unfit to stand trial," the Home Office announcement said.

Gen Pinochet has been in police custody in London for almost 14 months at the request of Spanish judge Baltazar Garzon, who wants to try him for the human rights abuses during his regime.

The reactions to the British announcement reflected a deep division in Chile.

"Unfortunately, this may be the end of a process that had triggered hopes among us and around the world that justice could be found in any country for crimes against human rights," said Ms Garcia.

Julia Urquieta, a prominent human rights lawyer, also expressed frustration, calling the British decision "lamentable."

But, she added, "We will continue to pursue justice. If he comes back, he must face justice here."

There are more than 50 lawsuits against Gen Pinochet pending in the Chilean courts. The government has said that if he returns he should face those charges.

A Socialist senator, Ricardo Nunez, said that once back in Chile, Gen Pinochet should re sign the post of senator-for-life which was granted to him under the constitution written by his regime, and withdraw from politics.

"If he doesn't, he would make Chile the laughing stock of the world," Mr Nunez said.

The British move comes just five days before the runoff for the Chilean presidency that pits Joaquin Lavin, a rightist who supported Gen Pinochet, against a socialist, Ricardo Lagos, an avowed foe of the former ruler.

The Pinochet situation, however, has been absent from the campaign, with both candidates saying Gen Pinochet is part of the past, and that the time has come for Chile to look to the future. AP

fields.headline: How the general escaped trial
fields.standfirst: Legal battle Fear that former dictator could die in Britain ended extradition case that stunned the world
fields.trailText: The image of a Chilean military guard escorting the flag-draped coffin of General Augusto Pinochet across the tarmac of RAF Northolt to a waiting airforce jet may, in the end, have been enough of a nightmare to persuade the home secretary, Jack Straw, to send the ailing dictator home.
fields.body:
The image of a Chilean military guard escorting the flag-draped coffin of General Augusto Pinochet across the tarmac of RAF Northolt to a waiting airforce jet may, in the end, have been enough of a nightmare to persuade the home secretary, Jack Straw, to send the ailing dictator home.

For all the tough talking about international justice over the past 18 months attributed to sources close to the governent, the last thing any high-ranking cabinet minister wanted was for the general to die in British custody, even if he was staying in a mansion on the luxury Wentworth estate in Surrey rather than in one of Her Majesty's prison cells.

Anglo-Chilean relations have already been strained, at times almost to breaking point, by the 18-month legal battle for possession of the general. Last year the Chilean ambassador in London was withdrawn to Santiago in protest at Gen Pinochet's continued arrest. He returned soon afterwards, but foreign office officials feared a complete breakdown in relations between the two countries, something that would have been hard to avoid if the general had died.

Rumours began circulating some time ago that during meetings with Chilean government officials the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, had hinted that the general's best chance of gaining an early release would be on humanitarian grounds.

It is something that Pinochet supporters have been actively pursuing for some time, leaking stories to the press about his ailing health, including the fact that a priest had been called to Wentworth on one occasion to administer the last rites.

Ever the brave old soldier, Gen Pinochet let it be known, through his daughter, that he would rather die in Britain with honour rather than return home humiliated. But when the chance came for a medical release the general grabbed it with both hands, accepting Mr Straw's request that he undergo independent medical tests.

The beginning of the end of Gen Pinochet's extended stay in Britain came in October when the Chilean foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, sent a formal petition to the home office asking for him to be sent home because of ill health.

Mr Straw made the request that he undergo medical tests, and last week he was examined by a team of doctors at Northwick Park hospital in north London.

Ailments

The medical tests, carried out over six hours by a neurologist and two geriatricians, found he was suffering from a variety of ailments, including a viral infection, diabetes, heart disease and the effects of two mild strokes.

Faced with the overwhelming evidence Mr Straw would have had little choice but to recommend the former dictator's return to Chile. He is under a duty to act in a judicial capacity in deciding extradition cases. Like all suspects Gen Pinochet is presumed innocent and Mr Straw is under an obligation to free him if he is likely to die before he is tried.

Critics of the government's handling of the Pinochet case - and there are many, from Lady Thatcher to Lord Lamont and a whole host of rightwing luminaries in between - will doubtless suggest that yesterday's decision is one that should have been taken 18 months ago.

But the medical reports that landed on Mr Straw's desk this week are not the first he has seen relating to the 84-year-old general.

When Gen Pinochet was first arrested in 1998 representations were made on behalf of the Chilean senator that his age and health would render it unjust or oppressive to issue an authority to proceed. In answer to a written question in the House of Commons Mr Straw replied that he had considered these carefully, but concluded that it did not appear that Gen Pinochet was unfit to stand to trial, and for him to do so would not be unjust or oppressive.

But according to yesterday's statement Gen Pinochet's condition has deteriorated significantly in the past few months.

It is ironic that he was in London receiving medical care when he was first arrested in October 1988. His back had gone into spasm during the 17-hour flight from Santiago, and he was in extreme discomfort when he was led from the Lufthansa jet straight into the Hounslow suite, one of four foreign office VIP rooms at Heathrow that are reserved for visiting dignitaries.

Little did he know that his arrival in London would set in motion what will no doubt go down as one of the most controversial episodes in British, and international, legal history.

A few weeks after his arrival, as he convalesced after back surgery in a London clinic, rumours began circulating that the Spanish magistrate Baltasar Garzon was preparing to request Gen Pinochet's detention.

Less than a week later, still groggy in his hospital bed, he was arrested on charges of murder, torture and terrorism carried out under his 17 year military regime.

His arrest stunned and divided the world. The case forced the international community - and the circumstances dictated that it was largely Britain's legal and political institutions to which the task fell - to examine how it could, would and should deal with those who transgress the norms of international behaviour.

The legal challenge by Gen Pinochet's lawyers went all the way to the House of Lords where a panel of three law lords threw it out in December 1998, prompting Mr Straw to give his consent to the action proceeding. But the initial ruling was then set aside in an unprecedented move as Gen Pinochet's lawyers argued that links between one of the law lords, Lord Hoffmann, and the human rights group Amnesty International cast doubt on his impartiality.

The issue then had to be re-examined by a new panel of law lords. They also decided that Gen Pinochet had no immunity as a former head of state, but they did decide he could only face trial on charges relating to incidents after Britain signed up to crucial international treaties - December 1988.

This had the effect of massively reducing the number of charges faced by the senator, offering him perhaps the first glimmer of hope that he would not be sent to Spain.

But Mr Straw again sanctioned the extradition proceedings against Gen Pinochet, saying that despite calls to the contrary he could find no compassionate grounds to end the action.

Judge Garzon, the Spanish judge leading the attempt to extradite Gen Pinochet, responded by immediately filing more charges relating to incidents after the cut-off date.

In October last year London magistrates decided there was nothing to stop him being extradited to Spain. That decision, inevitably, attracted another appeal from Gen Pinochet's lawyers that was due to be heard later this year - but which may now prove irrelevant.

Dismay

No doubt last night's decision will cause dismay among those who were pinning their hopes on seeing a man regarded as a brutal dictator brought to trial on the legal action sparked by Spain.

But if they can take one crumb of comfort from what has happened it will be that the man responsible for the deaths of more than 3,000 of his own citizens now knows how it feels to be wrenched away from his home and his country.

Gen Pinochet may be destined to fly home, but his bruising encounter with a determined Spanish judge and the British courts have spelt out to human rights abusers around the world that international law is catching up with them.

The case set a crucial precedent - that former heads of state cannot hide behind the concept of state immunity to avoid prosecution for crimes committed in office.

Battle to bring the general to justice

September 21 1998 Pinochet, 82, flies to Britain.

October 16 Arrested in London Clinic, Harley Street.

October 22 Baroness Thatcher calls for Pinochet's immediate release.

October 28 High court rules him "entitled to immunity as a former sovereign". He remains under arrest pending appeal.

The then attorney general, John Morris QC, declines consent for UK prosecution, citing "insufficient admissible evidence".

October 29 Pinochet moved to a private psychiatric hospital in north London.

November 11 Formal extradition request from Spanish judge Baltasar Garzon sent to Jack Straw.

November 25 On his 83rd birthday, Law Lords overturn High Court decision and rule he is not immune.

December 1 Pinochet moves to Surrey house.

February 18 1999 It emerges that in November the Vatican made representations, apparently sympathetic to Pinochet, to foreign office.

March 24 By a 6-1 majority, law lords again overturn high court decision giving Pinochet immunity (after his lawyer accuses Lord Hoffmann of possible bias because of link to Amnesty International) but they reduce the charges: Pinochet can be extradited only for torture and conspiracy to torture alleged to have been committed after December 8 1988, when International Torture Convention became binding on Spain, UK and Chile.

April 15 Straw says there are no compassionate grounds to halt proceedings.

April 16 New arrest warrant served on Pinochet.

July 2 Pinochet has electro-cardiogram. Friends say general's pacemaker is now maintaining his heartbeat.

July 8 Law lords rule that the taxpayer must meet lion's share of costs.

September 13 Pinochet has brain scan followed by neurological tests.

September 27 Four-day extradition hearing at London's Bow Street magistrates court.

October 1 Belgium renews its arrest warrant for Pinochet.

October 6 Pinochet excused from appearing at extradition ruling after court hears he has suffered two minor strokes.

October 8 Magistrates court commits Pinochet on all 35 charges, awaiting Straw's final decision on extraditing him.

October 14 Chile formally asks Britain to free Pinochet because of deteriorating health.

October 16 In Santiago up to 40 people are arrested as Pinochet supporters protest outside the British embassy.

October 18 -In Madrid two former security aides to deposed president Salvador Allende tell Judge Garzon Pinochet personally beat prisoners.

October 21 Spain says it will not appeal if Mr Straw frees Pinochet on humanitarian grounds.

October 22 Pinochet lawyers lodge challenge with High court to extradition ruling.

November 5 Home office asks for Pinochet to have medical examination.

January 5 2000 Pinochet has seven hours of tests at north London hospital to assess his fitness to be extradited.

January 11 Straw announces he is "minded" to release Pinochet based on medical reports.

webTitle: Spain says it will bow to decision

fields.headline: Spain says it will bow to decision
fields.standfirst:
Madrid Ministry makes it plain it will not push for extradition

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The Spanish government last night said it would respect any decision taken by Britain over General Augusto Pinochet and made it plain that it would not push for his extradition to Spain from Britain to go ahead if the home secretary decided to send him back to Chile.
fields.body:
The Spanish government last night said it would respect any decision taken by Britain over General Augusto Pinochet and made it plain that it would not push for his extradition to Spain from Britain to go ahead if the home secretary decided to send him back to Chile.

"The government has been informed that Mr Straw is considering the possibility of interrupting the judicial process," said a statement issued by the Spanish foreign ministry late last night.

"We recognise that decision is based on medial reports according to which the general is not fit to stand trial because of bad health.

"The government has respected the judicial decisions taken since the start of this process and stresses its intention to show the same respect for any decision now taken by Jack Straw who, under British law, has jurisdiction in the case."

A foreign ministry spokesman added that all the parties involved in the case had been given a period of seven days in which to voice their opinions but he stressed that the Spanish government would not be making any legal representation.

A source at Madrid's high court said that the British decision would be difficult to challenge.

"If it is a health problem, there are no legal or procedural arguments that can be made."

Spain's centre-right government had backed an extradition request put forward by the investigating magistrate in the case, Baltazar Garzon, but ministers made it plain, in private, that they did not want to see Gen Pinochet tried in their country.

State prosecutors tried to find loopholes in the judge's case while Spain's foreign min ister tried to repair relations with Chile and several other Latin American countries, strained to breaking point by what they saw as unjustified interference from the former colonial power.

The issue also divided the Spanish left. The Socialist party was strongly in favour of trying the general but a former prime minister, Felipe Gonzalez, said it was not appropriate for a country which had handled its own transition to democracy by blocking out the past to interfere in the Chilean process.

Lawyers representing victims of Gen Pinochet's regime, who pushed to bring a case against him, said last night that they needed to study the reports from London before deciding on their next move.

But Spanish legal experts said it was unlikely that Mr Garzon could prevent Gen Pinochet being sent back to Chile if the Spanish government was unwilling to press its extradition bid.

Joan Garces - a lawyer and former aide to late Chilean president Salvador Allende - who worked for years to build a case against the general, has insisted that he is not involved in a vendetta and that, morally, Gen Pinochet has already been condemned.

But he also stressed that with several international detention orders outstanding, Gen Pinochet would remain a fugitive from international justice even if he returned to Chile as a free man.

Carlos Seploy, another lawyer who is representing Pinochet victims, denounced a possible decision to send him back to Chile as "a very grave error".

"History will recount that the British government allowed Pinochet to return to Chile and remain immune," he said.

His colleague Enrique Santiago added that they would ask the national court, which brought the case against the general in Spain, to request another round of medical tests be carried out on the general in Britain.

"It is not appropriate or just for Gen Pinochet to return to Chile without appearing before the Spanish courts which should decide whether he is guilty or innocent," he said.

An Argentinian human rights lawyer, Carlos Slepoy, who aided the Spanish investigation of Gen Pinochet, said that the reported health problems should not lead to his release.

Proceedings should be suspended but the general should remain held under house arrest until his condition improves, Mr Slepoy said.

"What justice demands is that Pinochet be tried. He is accused of horrible crimes."

Mr Garzon's request for Gen Pinochet to be extradited on charges of murder, genocide and torture dating from 1973 to 1990 received official backing from the Spanish government in November 1998.

After two controversial hearings the British law lords limited the period for which he could be tried, saying he had immunity until 1998, severely weakening Mr Garzon's case.

Mr Garzon was not available for comment last night.

Switzerland and France have also put in extradition requests and legal moves against the general have begun in Belgium, Denmark and Sweden.
fields.bodyText: The Spanish government last night said it would respect any decision taken by Britain over General Augusto Pinochet and made it plain that it would not push for his extradition to Spain from Britain to go ahead if the home secretary decided to send him back to Chile. "The government has been informed that Mr Straw is considering the possibility of interrupting the judicial process," said a statement issued by the Spanish foreign ministry late last night. "We recognise that decision is based on medial reports according to which the general is not fit to stand trial because of bad health. "The government has respected the judicial decisions taken since the start of this process and stresses its intention to show the same respect for any decision now taken by Jack Straw who, under British law, has jurisdiction in the case." A foreign ministry spokesman added that all the parties involved in the case had been given a period of seven days in which to voice their opinions but he stressed that the Spanish government would not be making any legal representation. A source at Madrid's high court said that the British decision would be difficult to challenge. "If it is a health problem, there are no legal or procedural arguments that can be made." Spain's centre-right government had backed an extradition request put forward by the investigating magistrate in the case, Baltazar Garzon, but ministers made it plain, in private, that they did not want to see Gen Pinochet tried in their country. State prosecutors tried to find loopholes in the judge's case while Spain's foreign min ister tried to repair relations with Chile and several other Latin American countries, strained to breaking point by what they saw as unjustified interference from the former colonial power. The issue also divided the Spanish left. The Socialist party was strongly in favour of trying the general but a former prime minister, Felipe Gonzalez, said it was not appropriate for a country which had handled its own transition to democracy by blocking out the past to interfere in the Chilean process. Lawyers representing victims of Gen Pinochet's regime, who pushed to bring a case against him, said last night that they needed to study the reports from London before deciding on their next move. But Spanish legal experts said it was unlikely that Mr Garzon could prevent Gen Pinochet being sent back to Chile if the Spanish government was unwilling to press its extradition bid. Joan Garces - a lawyer and former aide to late Chilean president Salvador Allende - who worked for years to build a case against the general, has insisted that he is not involved in a vendetta and that, morally, Gen Pinochet has already been condemned. But he also stressed that with several international detention orders outstanding, Gen Pinochet would remain a fugitive from international justice even if he returned to Chile as a free man. Carlos Seploy, another lawyer who is representing Pinochet victims, denounced a possible decision to send him back to Chile as "a very grave error". "History will recount that the British government allowed Pinochet to return to Chile and remain immune," he said. His colleague Enrique Santiago added that they would ask the national court, which brought the case against the general in Spain, to request another round of medical tests be carried out on the general in Britain. "It is not appropriate or just for Gen Pinochet to return to Chile without appearing before the Spanish courts which should decide whether he is guilty or innocent," he said. An Argentinian human rights lawyer, Carlos Slepoy, who aided the Spanish investigation of Gen Pinochet, said that the reported health problems should not lead to his release. Proceedings should be suspended but the general should remain held under house arrest until his condition improves, Mr Slepoy said. "What justice demands is that Pinochet be tried. He is accused of horrible crimes." Mr Garzon's request for Gen Pinochet to be extradited on charges of murder, genocide and torture dating from 1973 to 1990 received official backing from the Spanish government in November 1998. After two controversial hearings the British law lords limited the period for which he could be tried, saying he had immunity until 1998, severely weakening Mr Garzon's case. Mr Garzon was not available for comment last night. Switzerland and France have also put in extradition requests and legal moves against the general have begun in Belgium, Denmark and Sweden.

webTitle: Tory MP faces new Commons inquiry

fields.headline: Tory MP faces new Commons inquiry
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: The Conservative MP Teresa Gorman is to be summoned before the Commons standards and privileges committee next week to answer allegations of failing to declare overseas and British property interests which could lead to her to being suspended from parliament.
fields.body:
The Conservative MP Teresa Gorman is to be summoned before the Commons standards and privileges committee next week to answer allegations of failing to declare overseas and British property interests which could lead to her to being suspended from parliament.

The allegations will only add to the damage to the image of the Tories inflicted by the libel trials of the former ministers Neil Hamilton and Jonathan Aitken and the resignation of Lord Archer from the London mayoral contest.

The fresh investigation by the parliamentary authorities into Mrs Gorman's affairs is understood to be the main reason she failed to make the party's new shortlist for its mayoral candidate.

The maverick MP for Billericay is also facing allegations of misleading Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, when she was asked about any land deal in an investigation last year into other undeclared business interests. Last year she was ordered to apologise to the Commons after failing to declare two directorships and a property in south London.

During that investigation she was questioned about overseas land deals by Dale Campbell Savours, Labour MP for Workington, when she appeared before the standards committee. Details of the questioning were excised from the public record at her request when a transcript of the hearing was released to journalists last summer.

She was asked by Ms Filkin "for the sake of completeness" whether she now possessed "any land or property other than any home used for personal residential purposes of you or your husband, which has a substantial value or from which substantial income is derived".

She was asked to declare any other shareholdings in any public or private company worth more than £25,000.

Less than a month afterwards it was reported that she had sublet properties in Streatham, south London, which had not been declared on the register of members' interests.

It was alleged that she had not declared the let properties when she tabled a bill to abolish rent act protection to help landlords in 1990. This would be in breach of parliamentary rules which require a MP to declare any interest when introducing or speaking on legislation.

The claims concerning the rented bedsits in the Independent have sparked a full investigation by Ms Filkin into the running of the properties. The commissioner has sought to interview tenants who said they paid rent to Mrs Gorman.

The Guardian understands that the inquiry was widened to look into overseas trusts, and investigations have started in the Channel Islands, Germany and Portugal, after the commissioner started looking into the financial arrangements behind the deal.

This followed reports that properties were sold to an offshore trust in Guernsey in which Mrs Gorman said she had no beneficial interest. Ms Filkin is understood to have had a battle with Channel Island authorities over the jurisdiction of the British parliament to investigate affairs in the islands but has now completed a preliminary report on the affair.

After completing the investigation, MPs have decided to summon Mrs Gorman to appear before them next Tuesday to explain the situation before they make their final judgment. It is understood that MPs will consider suspending her from the house if the allegations are proved.

Mrs Gorman said last night through an aide, when her forthcoming appearance before the committee was put to her: "I have nothing to say about this at the moment."

fields.headline: Court circular
fields.standfirst: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.trailText: Who's up in front of the judge
fields.body:
It's a sad day for the judicial voyeurs among us, as the lengthy furore over Stephen King's running over at the hands of a Maine van driver finally stumbled to a conclusion at Oxford County Superior Court last week. Until recently, the incident - which left the author in need of five operations to reset a broken hip - had always been claimed by the culprit, one Byron Smith, to be the result of, wait for it, "swerving to avoid a stray dog"; that, however, was before he found himself faced with an aggravated assault rap (and the year of jail-time which comes with it), at which point he plea-bargained his way into the lesser charge of endangerment and the subsequent loss of his license for six months. King, unsurprisingly, was irate at his assailant's non-custodial sentence, later describing it as "irresponsible". Still, at least now he can vent his spleen in peace, having bought the offending Dodge Caravan from Smith last September with the avowed intention of "beating the hell out of it with a sledgehammer".

Meanwhile, although ploughing into best-selling horror novelists may not be grounds for incarceration, attacking motor vehicles with a shovel certainly is - or at least that's the only conclusion you can draw from the six months in chokey handed down to Blaxploitation staple Jim Brown after pounding on his wife's Lexus during an argument last summer. Having said that, it's not as if the fortysomething actor helped his already precarious situation when he eventually appeared in LA Municipal Court: having refused to carry out Judge Dale S Fischer's court-ordered community service, Brown then accused the beak of being racist. "What we're talking about," he commented, perhaps unwisely, "is JB getting on his knees and doing a little cotton-picking and a little dancing." He's due for parole in April.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Them And Us | I Heard It Through The Grapevine - Marvin Gaye
fields.body:
Diana Madill sticks her head in the lion's mouth when Them And Us (8.0pm, Radio 4) invites citizens of Ashford, Kent, to air their views on development plans for the South East. One official proposal is to build 13 new cities there over the next 15 years, each housing 200,000 people. An alternative is for a conurbation which would envelop Ashford, Folkestone and Dover. Among those in the firing line is the leader of Kent County Council.

Charlie Gillett devotes an hour to the meteoric but brief career of one of pop's great idols. I Heard It Through The Grapevine - Marvin Gaye (9.0pm, Radio 2) looks back at the singer who wanted to rise from a deprived and brutalised childhood to become the black Frank Sinatra. He never got that far, and seemed ill-equipped to cope even with the fame that did come his way. The inevitable drugs and unpaid taxes added to his domestic woes.

fields.headline: Bad boys and rude girls
fields.trailText: Say what you like about the humiliating worthlessness of our politicians and millennium celebrations, but we British know how to build a better car thief. Several fine home-grown specimens paraded on Behind The Crime (C4), to explain the theory and practice of knocking off other people's motors. One explained how "a determined and analytical mind" can defeat any built-in alarms or immobilisers. "Some people work for a living, some people thieve for a living", rationalised Mancunian James Lord, who, at 34, has spent a part of each of his last 17 years in jail.
fields.body:
Say what you like about the humiliating worthlessness of our politicians and millennium celebrations, but we British know how to build a better car thief. Several fine home-grown specimens paraded on Behind The Crime (C4), to explain the theory and practice of knocking off other people's motors. One explained how "a determined and analytical mind" can defeat any built-in alarms or immobilisers. "Some people work for a living, some people thieve for a living", rationalised Mancunian James Lord, who, at 34, has spent a part of each of his last 17 years in jail.

The British car thief is bristling with sterling qualities - bold, resourceful, cool under pressure and capable of appreciating the philosophical scope of his vocation. There were scenes of thief Anton and his mate Duane driving around at night in a supposedly stolen vehicle. "There's just one or two give car thieves a bad reputation", Anton reflected. Duane added: "We don't see the point of boasting about things or doing things silly. What's the point of speeding around, risking killing somebody including yourself?" The pair began to sound like keynote speakers at a road safety convention. "You got to give the police their dues, they do a good job at the end of the day", Anton insisted. "You can't slag 'em off for that."

Anton has apparently now abandoned his life on stolen wheels, but it's difficult to imagine where he's going to find a home for his finely tuned skills in breaking, entering and driving away. Yet his talents paled beside the accomplishments of the film's third subject, an anonymous figure in a baseball cap who described in flat, unemotional detail how he'd set up a company specialising in stealing Rovers and then selling the parts to anybody from private customers to official Rover dealers.

His operation had been organised with scientific precision. He'd developed his own gadget to immobilise Rover alarm systems without damaging the car (a panicky statement from Rover insisted this couldn't happen now because their security has been updated), specialised in stealing cars from dealers' forecourts because it seemed somehow less objectionable than nicking an individual owner's vehicle, and bought a car-crusher to dispose of the unwanted parts that couldn't be sold. "We knew we were way out of order", our man confessed. "We were accountable to nobody." He was only caught, apparently, by chance. He now claims to be throwing his energies into a crime-free existence ("I'll just settle for a little bit less"), but he looked as if the boredom was already killing him.

By contrast, parenting remains a closed book to the British, judging by Driving Mum Crazy (C5). This examined single mother-of-five Louise and the traumas she suffers at the hands of five-year-old daughter Tayler, who suffers from Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder. This sounds suspiciously like the kind of designer-complaint doctors invent when they haven't a clue what they're talking about, but anyway, ADHD renders Tayler completely uncontrollable - she attacks her mother, siblings and passers-by, shrieks, swears, and goes berserk in shopping malls.

I couldn't grasp the point of the film. We saw Louise scraping together the cash to take Tayler for a consultation at a specialist children's clinic, but although the doctor tripled her dosage of drugs, the child remained as exasperatingly berserk as hitherto. The punchline was that Louise couldn't afford another visit to the clinic, yet was now pregnant with her sixth child. Should we therefore conclude that the mother is even more unhinged than her daughter?

Hats off to the ingenuity of British newspaper columnists, who have found so much to say about Victoria's Secrets (C4), Posh Spice's venture into TV "journalism". This is an awesome achievement, since in an hour-long programme, neither Posh nor her throng of celebrity chums could think of a single interesting thing to tell the viewer.

With her tiny figure and gaunt bone structure, Mrs Beckham is increasingly coming to resemble the computer-generated heroine Lara Croft, except without the latter's prominent forward-facing assets. Posh seems quite likeable, but it's high time that the myth that a celebrity opening and closing their mouth amounts to gripping TV was dumped, with the rest of the garbage on Greenwich Peninsula.

fields.headline: Watch this: satellite,cable and digital
fields.trailText: The Wicker Man | The Last Metro | Jackie Brown
fields.body:
The Wicker Man (Robin Hardy, 1973)

10pm, FilmFour

To the remote rocky Scottish island of Summerisle goes virginal policeman Edward Woodward, to uncover the truth behind stories of strange Satanic rites and wild, wild women such as Britt Ekland, Diane Cliento and Ingrid Pitt. Director Hardy manages to stoke up a genuinely sinister, sometimes erotic atmosphere, and with the old devil Christopher Lee presiding as local laird, it's hardly surprising that poor old Sergeant Woodward becomes a gibbering basket case.

The Last Metro (François Truffaut, 1980)
10pm, UK Arena

The German occupation of France, as witnessed in a theatre. Catherine Deneuve stars as Marion, actress-wife of director Steiner (Heinz Bennent); she takes over when he is forced to go into hiding. As she struggles to be faithful, and patriotic, a romance develops with co-star Bernard (Gerard Depardieu). It maybe lacks the committed realism of Louis Malle's occupation films, but it is as much a study of the theatre - in the way that Day For Night looked into the cinema - as social document of life under the Nazis.

Jackie Brown (Quentin Tarantino, 1997)

10.15pm, Sky Premier

Tarantino's adaptation of Elmore Leonard's Rum Punch is an account of Pam Grier's middle-aged heroine, a stewardess with a past, trying to make a living, then a killing, in 70s LA . The music's soulful, the characters - Samuel L Jackson's arms dealer, Bridget Fonda his girlfriend, Robert De Niro's dim hood - are right on the money, and some (Grier and Robert Forster as the bail bondsman who falls for her) we actually care for.

webTitle: Ticket to ride Cherie puts brave face on train fare foul-up

fields.headline: Ticket to ride Cherie puts brave face on train fare foul-up
fields.trailText: Judge Cherie Booth rose to the occasion yesterday.  Not only did she travel to Luton crown court by train again, this time she got her act together and bought a ticket. She had it ready for the ticket collector - and for the waiting cameras.
fields.body:
Judge Cherie Booth rose to the occasion yesterday. Not only did she travel to Luton crown court by train again, this time she got her act together and bought a ticket. She had it ready for the ticket collector - and for the waiting cameras.

Twenty-four hours earlier the Downing Street press office had been thrown into light-hearted turmoil over the failure of the prime minister's wife to find the cash or the Blackfriars station ticket office which would allow her to use a credit card to buy her ticket.

She was duly fined £10 at Luton - on her first day as a recorder, a part-time judge. The story appeared on front pages all over Britain yesterday.

Ms Booth QC - as Mrs Blair is known professionally - is 45 and expecting her fourth child in May. She has a lot on her mind. So there was more amusement than outrage at her plight yesterday. Not even John Redwood, the Tories' most assiduous shadow cabinet member, issued a statement demanding someone's resignation. Many commuters up and down the country compared their own experience with unbending rail officials and sympathised.

Yesterday Mrs Blair showed commendable nerve in the face of what she must have known would be a media scrum. She left No 10 early in a silver people carrier, caught the Luton train further up the Thameslink line - probably at King's Cross - and produced her ticket with a winning, knowing grimace at Luton 45 minutes later.

fields.headline: Yesterday day, bad day
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Rural buses. The famously car-loving deputy prime minister John Prescott yesterday anunced an extra £17m would be pumped into rural routes. The scheme will connect remote areas in the north, and the west country.

Bad day

Rubbish. Michael Meacher, environment minister, hit out at Britain's "pathetically low" level of recycling. He will shortly unveil a report into how to deal with the growing rubbish mountain, and cut the amount dumped in landfill sites.

New party of day

Cymru Unedig, or Welsh Solidarity, launched by unemployed lecturer Aled Gwyn Job, 36. Mr Job, who launched his party in a pub in Caernarfon, said he would campaign against pro-Europe Plaid Cymru which had 'betrayed" the ordinary people of Wales.

Today

Commons: Prime minister's questions. Representation of the people bill, committee. Lords: Debates on international situation, and on maternity services.

webTitle: Poll puts pressure on assembly leader

fields.headline: Poll puts pressure on assembly leader
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Wales: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's minority government in Wales was thrown on the backfoot last night after Plaid Cymru triggered a Westminster byelection in one of its strongholds just 24 hours after one of their key figures stepped down as an MP.
fields.body:
Labour's minority government in Wales was thrown on the backfoot last night after Plaid Cymru triggered a Westminster byelection in one of its strongholds just 24 hours after one of their key figures stepped down as an MP.

Labour politicians were both puzzled and angry at the speed of the Welsh nationalist move, three days after Plaid picked its own candidate - not least because the votes will be cast on a 17-month-old electoral register, two weeks before the new one comes into force.

fields.headline: Moira Dunbar
fields.standfirst: Woman scientist the navy refused to take on board
fields.trailText: In 1954 Moira Dunbar, who has died aged 81, applied to join a Royal Canadian Navy icebreaker carrying a team of scientists to the Arctic. Despite being a specialist in sea ice, she was rejected. For six months she persevered. Finally she won permission to join a transport department icebreaker. fields.body:
In 1954 Moira Dunbar, who has died aged 81, applied to join a Royal Canadian Navy icebreaker carrying a team of scientists to the Arctic. Despite being a specialist in sea ice, she was rejected. Naval vessels would not take a woman. For six months she persevered. Finally she won permission to join a transport department icebreaker. On board, she recalled, "I think they regarded me as some sort of cross between a delicate flower and a dangerous disease."

Although most of her trips were on icebreakers, she clocked up almost 600 hours in Royal Canadian Air Force aircraft studying ice formations. In 1956, with the RCAF's Air Commodore Keith Greenaway, she co-wrote Arctic Canada From the Air, the first such airborne geographical study.

Her early academic papers analysed literature of the early explorers; later came research based on cruises and reconnaisance flights. She became one of the first women to fly over the North Pole.

Dunbar was born in Edinburgh and educated at Cranley School for Girls and Oxford, graduating in geography in 1939.

During and after the second world war, she toured Britain as an actor and stage manager. "I was what is known as a character juvenile," she said, "which meant playing a long string of comic maids."

In 1947 she arrived in Canada and found work with the defence research board in Ottawa, which was seeking geography graduates. She studied Arctic conditions to make the frozen waters more easily navigable.

But despite her value as a scientist, she soon faced a barrier to travel - her gender. Air force stations were "no place for a woman" she was told. The issue went to ministerial level but eventually she was accepted. She learned Russian to interpret Soviet studies, and visited the country in 1964 to study icebreaking operations.

Dunbar was an observer in the first Arctic trials of hovercraft, was involved in testing supertanker use in ice, and was the Canadian coordinator of the first successful attempt to evaluate satellite photography for ice reconnaisance. In 1976 she took part in airborne laser profiling of Arctic Ocean ice. Her many published papers include High Latitude Navigational Flights (Arctic Circular, 1951); Ice Islands: Evidence from North Greenland (Arctic, 1953); The Royal Arctic Theatre (Canadian Art, 1958); and Thrust Structures in Young Sea Ice (Journal of Glaciology, 1960).

She retired in 1978, having received the Order of Canada and fellowship of the Royal Society of Canada, among many other honours.

She never married, and leaves a sister.

fields.headline: Eli Goren
fields.standfirst: Not just a fiddler, but an intuitive violinist, leader and teacher
fields.trailText: Eli Goren, who has died aged 76, was leader of the original Allegri String Quartet, former leader of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, and a valued teacher.
fields.body:
Eli Goren, who has died aged 76, was leader of the original Allegri String Quartet, former leader of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, and a valued teacher.

He was the most natural of players, a kind and gentle leader, and was prized for his instinctive musicianship. In teaching he had the ability to open up a spiritual experience and share it. Music was his goal, and neither orchestral politics nor the cultivation of an ego interested him in the slightest.

As with so many of his generation and background in pre-war Vienna, Eli (who later changed his name from Gruenberg) was forced to leave his childhood behind; he and his younger brother Erich found sanctuary in Palestine thanks to Emil Hauser, director of the Jerusalem Conservatoire, who was scouring central Europe for the 24 most talented instrumentalists. As prodigious violinists, the brothers qualified; their parents, assured of their boys' safe future, came to England.

Goren had studied with the leader of the Vienna Philharmonic, and in Palestine had lessons with Heinrich Jacobi, but played in streets and bars before becoming leader of the Jerusalem Radio Orchestra.

He came to England in 1950 to study with Max Rostal. Needing a pianist, he solicited advice from his brother, who suggested Doreen Stanfield. They gave many concerts, including a Wigmore Hall debut in 1951, and married in Jerusalem the same year.

After pneumonia on his honeymoon and other bouts of illness Goren was advised to stay in Britain to eat well.

His first work was as leader of the Melos Ensemble of London, with whom he made many recordings. The Allegri String Quartet was launched in 1953 with Goren as its first leader, his pupil James Barton as second violin, Patrick Ireland as viola, and the late William Pleeth as cello. They had some success, and some of their Haydn recordings and a release of Elgar's Introduction And Allegro with Sir John Barbirolli have, in the view of many, never been bettered, but they were competing with the Amadeus, whose recordings were far more plentiful.

As a leader, Goren had great status and an intuitive feeling for the music, although tensions arose, as the other members had strong views too. Rehearsals were very detailed: Goren's perfectionism led to the first movement of a work getting more time than the rest.

In 1968 Goren joined the BBC Symphony Orchestra as co-leader, sharing first with Hugh Bean; then a year later the long-standing partnership with Bela Dekany was launched. In 1977 he left the BBC SO to return to teaching (he had first taught, while in the Allegri, at the Guildhall School of Music), taking up a post in 1978 at the Royal Northern College of Music.

In 1982, he also started coaching at the Utrecht Conservatory, and in 1985 he left the Royal Northern and moved to Holland to concentrate on his work there; he retired from Utrecht in 1988 but continued to teach, contributing masterclasses to Lake District Summer Music and at the Kuhmo Chamber Music Festival in Finland.

Pupils would seek him out because of his musicianship; he looked upon teaching as a way to help others gain similar depths of understanding. One of his aims was to stop the body obstructing the musical message, and much of his teaching was through imagery. Violinist Richard Ireland loves Goren's analogy about the danger of sounding like a reproduced Queen Anne chair leg - beauty should be original and not just be unthinkingly manufactured.

Sir Colin Davis, who conducted the BBC Symphony Orchestra during Goren's period as leader, noted his extraordinary absence of ego: "He was not just a fiddler but a really thoughtful musician. And with the Allegri his was some of the best quartet playing ever - he had a brain able to organise this kind of music, it wasn't just instinct."

Goren was a musician's musician: he was sensitive within the profession to people not responding to him, and knew that real public success and wider recognition had eluded him. But he also had an idiosyncratic sense of humour.

He remarried in 1982 and is survived by his second wife Mirjam and young daughter, and his son and daughter from his first marriage.

fields.headline: Cliff Lloyd
fields.standfirst: Footballer whose biggest victory came after he hung up his boots
fields.trailText: Cliff Lloyd, who has died aged 83, made a mark in two areas of football - first as a reliable, competent fullback in Fulham's second division team just after the war, and then in his marathon spell as secretary to the Professional Footballers' Association
fields.body:
Cliff Lloyd, who has died aged 83, made a mark in two areas of football - first as a reliable, competent fullback in Fulham’s second division team just after the war, and then in his marathon spell as secretary to the Professional Footballers’ Association, initially known as the Players’ Union.

He was an immensely amiable, dedicated figure, the perfect foil to the more flamboyant and innovative Jimmy Hill, who became the PFA chairman and, as such, fought such a bitter battle before achieving the end of the iniquitous £20 maximum wage for footballers in 1961. Lloyd, it is fair to say, could hardly have won such a battle, but his loyal and consistent support unquestionably helped Hill to achieve his and the PFA’s aim.

When the pair appeared on television, as they often did while the conflict raged on, Lloyd in effect played the straight man to Hill. His approach was rational, principled and logical, and he pointed out that a great deal more than money was at stake. Rather it was a question of the status of the professional footballer, though you would never hear Lloyd mouth the old cliché, so familiar when the ebullient Jimmy Guthrie spoke for the Players’ Union, of “soccer slaves”.

It must have been a great disappointment to Lloyd that, just when he had reached agreement in early December 1960 with the dour secretary of the Football League, Alan Hardaker, on a compromise plan, the League’s committee should promptly amend it.

On June 11 1963, Lloyd had the nerve-racking experience of spending two long hours in the witness box in the high court, when the Newcastle United and Arsenal inside forward George Eastham, backed by Fulham’s future millionaire chairman Ernie Clay, successfully challenged the League’s retain and transfer system, so making it possible for players to move at the end of their contracts. The eventual judgment was a triumph for the players and the PFA, Mr Justice Wilberforce opining that the contract, as it stood, was restraint of trade.

Lloyd also played a key role in negotiations in 1974 over potential freedom of contract for footballers, though the elaborate mathematical transfer fee formula worked out with Hardaker, based on a Dutch model, was not eventually adopted.

Born in Wrexham, Lloyd, a promising young fullback, was signed by Liverpool in 1936, following in the wake of his footballer father. Perhaps he would have gone further but for the second world war, in which he served in the army. He played as a guest for Wrexham, Fulham and Brentford, and joined Fulham when the war ended. On leaving there he coached the Lisleby club in Norway, before joining the PFA.

He became secretary of the players’ trade union in 1953 and remained in office for a remarkable 28 years. The present chairman of the PFA, Gordon Taylor, declared: “Today’s footballers have every reason to be grateful for the hard work and dedication that Cliff Lloyd showed on their behalf. His contribution was a keystone in the success of the PFA.”

A man of easy charm and constant good humour, Lloyd was made an OBE in 1975 for services to football. It was greatly deserved.

His wife predeceased him, and he leaves a daughter.

Cliff Lloyd, footballer and administrator, born November 14 1916; died January 10 2000

• This article was amended on 26 October 2020 to note that Ernie Clay was not Fulham’s chairman in 1963.

fields.headline: Reg Foster
fields.standfirst: Crime reporter jailed in the aftermath of the Vassall spy case
fields.trailText: Reg Foster, who has died aged 95,  came before Lord Radcliffe, chairman of the tribunal inquiring into the activities of John Vassall, the Admiralty clerk sentenced in 1962 to 18 years' imprisonment for selling secrets to the Soviet Union.
fields.body:
In February 1963 Fleet Street crime reporters Reg Foster and Brendan Mulholland made history by being jailed. They had persisted in their refusal to disclose sources of information on their reporting of the Vassall spy case and were thus sentenced at the high court for contempt; the Daily Sketch's Foster was given three months for refusing to name one source and the Daily Mail's Mulholland got six months for refusing to reveal two.

Reg, who has died aged 95, had come before Lord Radcliffe, chairman of the tribunal inquiring into the activities of John Vassall, the Admiralty clerk sentenced in 1962 to 18 years' imprisonment for selling secrets to the Soviet Union. During a Moscow posting, he was photographed at a homosexual party and blackmailed into spying. Reg, one of several journalists who gave evidence to Radcliffe about reports they had written on the case, was asked to say from what type of source he had obtained information about Vassall buying women's clothes in the West End. He refused.

Reg was born in south London, and educated at Alleyn's School, Dulwich. He became a trainee on the South London Press and from 1924 to 1932 was on the Daily Mail, after which he joined the Daily Herald.

During those years he earned the nickname "Fireman Foster", for his enthusiasm in reporting fires. He was aided by a relative in the fire service who tipped him off, explaining why he was the first reporter on the scene of the dramatic 1936 Crystal Palace blaze.

This was the period when Fleet Street's circus of crime correspondents would go out of town for weeks pursuing big stories. Sometimes Reg was away for so long that he would send for his wife, Kate, whom he adored, to join him.

He covered the big criminal cases, for the Mail, the Herald, and later for the News Chronicle, which he joined after wartime army service. His cases included the 1949 acid bath murderer John George Haigh, and the 10 Rillington Place serial killer John Christie. He also reported the 1952 Craig and Bentley case, in which a policeman was shot dead and for which Derek Bentley was hanged, despite not having committed the murder.

Reg was the News Chronicle's "Yard man", spending his time in the smoke-filled press room at old Scotland Yard, or hobnobbing in nearby pubs with police and contacts. As a Chronicle reporter, I only recall seeing the tall figure of Reg, ever unassuming and quietly-spoken, once a week when he called in to collect his expenses.

After the Chronicle closed, Reg freelanced for the Sunday Dispatch, Sunday Express and Daily Mirror; then came the Sketch and the Vassall case. The two journalists were committed to Brixton Prison. On their first night there, Reg recalled later, he heard two other prisoners talking. "Blimey," said one, "someone's gone and put sugar in this cocoa." Replied the other: "It must be because of those bloody reporters!"

Reg served most of his sentence at Ford Open Prison in Sussex, largely tending the gardens. At the age of 58 he also played in the prison football team. "I couldn't run very fast, so they put me in goal," he recalled.

Towards the end of his career, Reg worked for the Yorkshire Evening Post in its London office, and then retired to Pevensey Bay, East Sussex. But he always attended the News Chronicle's annual reunion.

His wife died in 1984 after 53 years of marriage. Reg is survived by a son and a grandson.

Matthew Engel writes: Reg Foster was probably the last survivor of a Fleet Street that now no longer exists even in memory. When he joined the Daily Mail, there was - he recalled - "a large panelled reporters' room with a phone with a handle on the wall, and a big roaring fire and a bell you could ring for boys who'd bring you beans on toast or marmalade on toast. If the news editor wanted you, he's either ring the phone or he'd panic down the corridor with his coat-tails flying."

Marmalade notwithstanding, journalism between the wars was not a gentle profession. Competition for news was fiercer than in any other era of the 20th century, and it bred an approach that would give modern editors kittens. Foster's world of crime reporting was probably the fiercest and most amoral of the lot.

The star Scotland Yard detectives might go out of town on a juicy murder enquiry (like the Cheltenham Torso or the Brighton Trunk Murders) for weeks, pursued by Fleet Street's finest, who would be under pressure to keep the story going at any cost. "Someone might find a bloodstained garter in a ditch," reminisced Foster, "Marvellous story, but no relevance at all to the investigation . . . There was a certain amount of freedom of expression. I think I'd better leave it like that."

This was the background that produced his reporting of the Vassall case, when he may have had a genuine scoop, or may just have used his freedom of expression. I think we had better leave it like that.

Foster was a delightful, cheery man and a rich source of journalistic lore into extreme old age. In the days of bloodstained garters, when reporters all wore hats and grey macs, he must have been a charming colleague.

Reginald William Foster, reporter, born July 23 1904; died December 29 1999

fields.headline: Letter
fields.trailText: Jim Perrin writes: Eirene White (Obituary, December 27) was passionately devoted both to public life in Wales and the landscape of this most beautiful of countries. You could scarcely mention a place in the Welsh hills without her knowing of it.
fields.body:
Jim Perrin writes: Eirene White (Obituary, December 27) was passionately devoted both to public life in Wales and the landscape of this most beautiful of countries. You could scarcely mention a place in the Welsh hills without her knowing of it. Nor could you go to the opening of an exhibition in Harlech or a concert in Aberystwyth without meeting her and thus engaging with a precise, retentive and concerned intelligence.

She could on occasion use dogma and a grande dame persona to mask shyness. Beyond those defences she was warm, witty, playful and even rather girlishly flirtatious. As editor of the magazine Rural Wales, published by the Campaign for the Protection of Rural Wales, I saw a great deal of her in the mid-1980s.

A former journalist, Eirene was both meticulous in her expectation, and supportive. When an attempt was made by a faction within the CPRW to block an article critical of National Trust proposals to lease newly-acquired Enterprise Neptune land on the Ceredigion Heritage Coast to the Ministry of Defence, she investigated the matter thoroughly. Once convinced of its accuracy, she offered me her wholehearted support in getting the article published - but with a proviso that "they", by whom she meant the masonic mafia which then exercised an undue influence in Welsh affairs, would be unforgiving and unforgetting. She spoke from bitter personal experience, was as good as her word, and was absolutely right.

Eirene was an old-style patrician socialist who believed that the class struggle was won, that humanity was ultimately perfectible, and intelligence, not emotion, was crucial to that end. I relished her doughtiness and forceful intellect and knew her kindness. Wales shall miss her.

fields.headline: Microsoft settles out of court
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft has settled one anti-trust lawsuit for an estimated $275m (£167m) a week before it is due to respond to accusations from the United States government that it is a monopoly and harms consumers.
fields.body:
Microsoft has settled one anti-trust lawsuit for an estimated $275m (£167m) a week before it is due to respond to accusations from the United States government that it is a monopoly and harms consumers.

Analysts said yesterday that Microsoft's settlement with Caldera, a small Utah-based software company, could indicate a greater willingness to reach agreement before going to court.

However, settlement with the department of justice is expected to be much harder to reach because of the scale of the landmark action.

The government indicated a desire for substantial remedies at the outset of the settlement talks, which started last month. Microsoft is to present its case against the findings of Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson next week.

On reaching a settlement with Caldera Tom Burt, Microsoft's general counsel, said: "We are pleased to put this issue behind us.

"Rather than litigating, we prefer to focus on building great software for our customers in this dynamic and competitive industry."

On the same day as the settlement was announced Caldera Systems - sister company to Caldera, which trades under the Lineo name - filed to list on the stock exchange. Caldera Systems aims to raise $57.5m with its initial public offering later this year.

webTitle: Human cargo dies in bid to enter US

fields.headline: Human cargo dies in bid to enter US
fields.trailText: Three dead Chinese stowaways were found yesterday inside a cargo container on a ship that arrived in Seattle from Kaohsiung, Taiwan. The deaths are the first to result from a recent boom in attempted illegal entries to the US by sea from China.
fields.body:
Three dead Chinese stowaways were found yesterday inside a cargo container on a ship that arrived in Seattle from Kaohsiung, Taiwan. The deaths are the first to result from a recent boom in attempted illegal entries to the US by sea from China.

An elderly woman and two men were found dead in the soft-top container on board the Cape May when it docked at the port of Seattle. Officials from the US immigration and naturalisation service (INS) said they had been tipped off that the ship might contain illegal immigrants.

The three who died were among a group of 18 stowaways who had been secreted on the ship, which is owned by the Japanese company NYK, although there is no suggestion that the owners were aware of the attempt. All of the 15 survivors were in poor physical condition, suffering from dehydration and malnutrition.

The three dead stowaways are believed to have died at least three days before the ship reached US waters. They had been left in the container alongside the survivors, according to an INS official. The survivors, who are said to be mainly in their 20s and 30s, will be deported when they are fit enough to return.

The ship was the third carrying illegal Chinese immigrants in the space of a week to have been detained on the North American west coast. On January 3, 25 stowaways were found hidden in containers on board a ship in Vancouver.

Last month, another 30 illegal immigrants were found inside containers on a ship that was searched at Long Beach, California.

fields.headline: Paparazzo who 'stalked' Streisand arrested
fields.trailText: The arrest of a paparazzo for allegedly stalking the singer Barbra Streisand has again raised the issue of when pursuit of a celebrity turns into something more sinister.
fields.body:
The arrest of a paparazzo for allegedly stalking the singer Barbra Streisand has again raised the issue of when pursuit of a celebrity turns into something more sinister. The man was being held on $1m bail yesterday as arguments resurfaced about whether his right to freedom of speech was being breached, or whether he was no different from a common stalker.

Wendell Wall, 28, was arrested on Sunday after the Los Angeles county sheriff's department alleged that he had been stalking Streisand and her husband, the actor James Brolin. The couple had reported being tailed by Wall on the Ventura freeway and on the Pacific coast highway near their Malibu home. A statement issued on behalf of Streisand and Brolin said Wall had repeatedly pursued them for the past five years.

"They are essentially prisoners in their own home," it said.

The question of how far photographers and reporters can go in pursuit of celebrities is a long-running one in star-laden Hollywood. In 1997, two photographers were arrested and charged with false imprisonment after trapping a vehicle driven by Arnold Schwarzenegger between their cars following a pursuit.

Hollywood celebrities Tom Cruise, Woody Harrelson, Alec Baldwin, Kim Basinger and Will Smith have all had high-profile run-ins with the paparazzi in recent years. When stars lash out at the photographers pursuing them, the picture becomes more valuable, and they welcome stiff legal action against what they see as a breach of privacy that has little to do with the freedom of expression.

Photographers argue that they are not causing physical harm to the stars, who should expect such intrusions as part of the price of their fame.

webTitle: Tide of oil pushes Brittany to edge of despair

fields.headline: Tide of oil pushes Brittany to edge of despair
fields.standfirst: A month after the Erika sank, volunteers fear its cargo will never go away
fields.trailText: Exactly a month ago today, 60 miles from the windswept dunes and white-painted, slate-roofed holiday villas of this neat Brittany village, a 24-year-old rusty Maltese oil tanker broke her back and sank in a midwinter gale.
fields.body:
Exactly a month ago today, 60 miles from the windswept dunes and white-painted, slate-roofed holiday villas of this neat Brittany village, a 24-year-old rusty Maltese oil tanker broke her back and sank in a midwinter gale.

Two weeks later, in thick, foul-smelling black slabs, the Erika's cargo began washing up on the long pristine ribbon of Les Moutiers beach. And every day since Boxing Day, Guy le Pavec has been cleaning it up.

The deputy mayor of Les Moutiers, grey-haired and crinkle-faced, looked at the scene with tired eyes. Four bulldozers were at work, digging out a fresh mountain of sludge that had arrived with the morning tide.

"It's desperate", Mr le Pavec said. "Every day we break our backs, and every morning we come back wondering how much of yesterday's work will have been undone. But you can't let it get you down. You just have to keep going."

It is revolting stuff, heavy fuel oil. It stinks and it sticks to you and it gets everywhere, and on a bright, sunny day the ugliness of it, splattered along a wild and beautiful coastline, turns your stomach.

On big expanses of flat sand, like up the coast at the chic La Baule resort, the oil spreads out like a pancake and can be shovelled up by machine. But on the narrower, pebble-strewn, less fashionable strands like this one, every rock has to be cleaned by hand.

That is what 350 figures in waterproofs, wellingtons and rubber gloves were doing yesterday - soldiers from nearby Saint Nazaire, firefighters from the far south and south-west, trainee policemen from Nantes, a class of young nurses from down near Valence, and a small group of pensioners.

"At least it's a fine day," said Jean-Paul, 66, crouched over the edge of the oil-encrusted promenade, chipping away at a congealed splash with a small trowel. "I can't come here when it's cold or raining."

Raynaldo, 24, graduated last month from police college and was waiting to be assigned his first job. He was wielding a heavy shovel, filling up his mate Gregory's wheelbarrow. This beach was harder than the last, he said.

"Apart from all the rocks here, oil has got in under the sand," he said. "You see what you think is a little pebble and it turns out to be the tip of a huge lump. You wonder whether it'll ever be gone."

Sophie, 20, volunteered for a week with the rest of her nursing class, driving 11 hours through the night to get here. She was trying hard not to get depressed.

"The worst is when you find a dead bird mixed up in it," she said. "But even when you don't, it's terribly hard. We don't seem to be making an impression at all."

Up and down 250 miles of the Brittany and Loire-Atlantique coast, similar groups are having similar doubts. The soldiers, police and firefighters will keep going - on a good day, they can clear two tonnes of sludge per person. The volunteers, though, are ebbing.

Still, Mr le Pavec thinks that with a bit of luck they might be done in a month. The tides are bringing in less and less new oil each day, and the 20,000 tonnes still in the Erika are not, apparently, escaping.

But if that is good news for most of the village's 923 inhabitants, who rely for their income on 10,000 tourists a week in summer, it is too late for the two dozen men and women in Les Moutiers and neighbouring La Bernerie who cultivate oysters for a living.

Their oyster beds, a mile or so out in the shallow expanse of Bourgneuf bay, produce 500 tonnes of shellfish a year. It takes three or four years for each new crop to mature. And last week a thin film of oil was floating inches over the beds. Some had already been coated.

"That's three seasons' work and three seasons' profits gone," spat one Les Moutiers grower, Virginie Girard. "Who will buy Bourgneuf bay oysters now? I've got 11 years of loan repayments ahead and I'm not going to sit around paying for the idiocy of an oil company that charters wrecks."

The bay's freelance shellfish fishermen, who collect cockles, mussels and clams at low tide and make a precarious living at the best of times, have also been banned from selling their produce until the necessary laboratory hygiene tests have been completed.

"Whether we survive depends on how quickly we get compensation," said Arnaud Roger, 24. "If it comes in two or three months, maybe we'll pull through. If not, that'll be another local job gone."

The government is doing what it can, they admit. The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, is touring Bourgneuf bay this week to discuss compensation. The secretary for tourism, Michelle Demessine, has said she will send a bill for the clean-up to TotalFina, the Franco-Belgian oil company which chartered the Erika.

But on Les Moutiers beach yesterday, the sweating line of oil-smeared workers was talking of only one thing. Three miles out, a coastguard helicopter had spotted a thick new half-mile slick. Where would that one land?
