webTitle: EU court grants German woman right to be soldier

fields.headline: EU court grants German woman right to be soldier
fields.trailText: Women must be allowed to carry arms in the German military, the European court of justice ruled yesterday in a landmark decision that said single-sex combat forces violated European Union equality regulations.
fields.body:
Women must be allowed to carry arms in the German military, the European court of justice ruled yesterday in a landmark decision that said single-sex combat forces violated European Union equality regulations.

The Luxembourg-based court upheld a complaint from a German woman, Tanja Kreil, whose efforts to join the Bundeswehr had been rejected because Germany's post-war constitution specifically bans women from using weapons.

"German legislation barring women outright from army jobs involving the use of arms is contrary to the [European] community principle of equal treatment for men and women," the court said.

Constitutional change could now follow, but women commandos and snipers are not yet heading for battle: the court said exceptions remain possible where sex constitutes "a determining factor for access to certain special combat units" - an easy get-out for generals and governments.

Ms Kreil, 23, who trained in electronics and now works at Siemens AG, applied to join up in 1996, but her application was rejected, though she still hopes to work with tanks.

"It is a tremendous relief to me," she said of the decision. "I am very proud that I accomplished this."

Ms Kreil said she was astonished three years ago when her application was rejected solely because she was a woman. "It made me feel like I was living in the Middle Ages," she told the newspaper Tageszeitung.

Germany's armed forces have fewer women than any other Nato member, with 4,340 medical staff and 60 musicians - the only jobs they are allowed to do.

All German men are required to serve 10 months in the armed forces after turning 18, athough conscientious objectors may do community service instead.

Yesterday's ruling has sweeping implications for Germany's conscript army, long battered by complaints of discrimination against women and gay men, but buoyed by its first overseas combat deployment in Kosovo last year.

Experts believe Germany may now have to change its constitution. Even during the desperate days of the second world war, when young teenagers and elderly men were pressed into service by the Nazis, women were exempted from combat duty.

Verena Wohlleben, a military expert with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder's Social Democrats, said the government would examine whether it could integrate women in the armed forces without changing the constitution, but she believed a change was desirable.

Germany's defence minister, Rudolf Scharping, said: "It is necessary to think carefully about these kinds of issues, generally, but this is my personal opinion: I think the decision is right and I will work on it.

"I know the decision was saying that the simple fact of being a woman is not a reason to be excluded from the army. The consequences of this decision are not just German; a similar decision was taken a few weeks ago in reference to the UK and the British army."

Arms and the woman in Europe Britain

Women re non-combative but can support frontline roles. Government retains right to exclude women soldiers from units, such as Royal Marines, likely to be involved in 'close and kill' actions. Women not allowed on submarines because of risk to foetuses from recycled air. Overall, 70% of positions in the army, 76% in the navy and 96% in the RAF are open to women. Women make up 6.5% of UK forces.

France

Not allowed in infantry but first female fighter pilot has just been appointed. Women make up only 2.5% of total military.

Italy

Women offered 250 out of a total of 750 places in army, navy and air force academies as part of a plan to turn the largely conscripted army into a professional one. Long-term aim is that women should form 10% of forces. Wives of officers to design women's uniforms.

webTitle: No clemency as boy killer pays ultimate price

fields.headline: No clemency as boy killer pays ultimate price
fields.standfirst: The Guardian this week profiled Chris Thomas. US justice has been done - now he's dead
fields.trailText: After turning a deaf ear to domestic and international protests, the United States yesterday executed Chris Thomas, who was a juvenile when he committed the crimes for which he was put to death.
fields.body:
After turning a deaf ear to domestic and international protests, the United States yesterday executed Chris Thomas, who was a juvenile when he committed the crimes for which he was put to death.

Thomas was executed by lethal injection at the Greensville Correctional Centre in Virginia on Monday night after a last-minute petition for a stay of execution was rejected by the state governor, Jim Gilmore.

The 26-year-old prisoner was pronounced dead at 9.03pm local time, less than an hour after Mr Gilmore had refused to commute his sentence to life imprisonment without parole. Earlier in the day, the US Supreme Court had also refused to grant a stay.

Thomas, who was 17 when he killed his girlfriend's parents in November 1990, was the first of three American prisoners due to die this month for crimes committed when they were juveniles. Only a handful of other nations allow capital punishment for juvenile crime.

A second man, Steve Roach, 23, is scheduled to be executed tomorrow, also in Virginia. Roach was 17 when he killed 70-year-old Mary Hughes, in her home in Stanardsville, Virginia, in December 1993.

In a third case, Texan Glen McGinnis, who was 27 yesterday, is due to be executed on January 25 for the 1990 killing of a laundry attendant. McGinnis was also 17 at the time of his offence.

The three executions will bring to 13 the number of juvenile criminals who have been executed in the past decade in the US, more than all other countries combined during the same period, according to Amnesty.

Aside from the US, only four other countries currently allow the execution of juvenile offenders - Iran, Nigeria, Pakistan and Saudi Arabia. Yemen, the only other nation to have carried out an execution of this type since 1990, has subsequently abolished the practice, as has China.

Thomas's execution came despite official pleas for clemency from the European Union and many US groups, including the American Bar Association and the Rutherford Institute, a conservative legal foundation.

The planned executions had been denounced by campaigners against capital punishment.

"To have three scheduled executions of juveniles in the first month of the new year is a morbid alert to the people of this country to re-examine the vengeful nature of our juvenile justice system," said Sam Jordan, who directs the death penalty abolition programme of Amnesty International USA.

"There should be a national alarm at the use of this desperate, ineffective and failed response," he said

In an unusually long statement which appeared to reflect the sensitive nature of the case, Mr Gilmore denied Thomas's request for last-minute clemency on the grounds that the prisoner's responsibility under the law was "not diminished because of legal protections afforded to his 14-year-old accomplice".

Mr Thomas's girlfriend, 14-year-old Jessica Wiseman, was also convicted as an accomplice in the killing of her parents, and was sentenced to imprisonment in a youth centre until she turned 21. She was released in 1997.

fields.headline: 15 trapped gold miners feared dead
fields.trailText: Hopes of saving 15 gold miners trapped three miles underground for nearly two days were fading last night after rescuers failed to make contact with the missing men.
fields.body:
Hopes of saving 15 gold miners trapped three miles underground for nearly two days were fading last night after rescuers failed to make contact with the missing men.

The accident is bound to attract fresh criticism of safety procedures in South Africa's mines, which claim an average of one life every day and are considered to be among the most dangerous in the world.

The 15 miners became stranded on Monday after an earth tremor caused a rock fall at the African Rainbow Minerals (ARM) gold shaft in Orkney, about 100 miles south-west of Johannesburg.

Rescue teams cut tunnels to ease the flow of air to the area where the men are trapped, but it was feared that temperatures the other side of the rock fall had risen to about 40C (104F). Attempts to contact the miners failed.

Andre Wilkens, the chief executive of ARM, which was recently bought by a "black empowerment" company, said the rescuers had dislodged 160 tons of rock but were making slow progress.

"Rescue workers have cleared the steep travelling way into the working area where the miners are trapped," he said. "They are now clearing down towards the miners and have progressed some three metres, but have encountered some difficulty in getting to them."

Another rescue team is attempting to reach the men by an alternative route beneath the rock fall.

Four of the trapped miners are South African. The others are from Swaziland, Lesotho and Mozambique.

Compared with other countries, safety procedures are poor in South African mines, a legacy of the apartheid era, when the loss of black lives mattered only because it hindered production.

More than 70,000 miners - almost all of them black - died and 1m were injured in accidents last century. It is estimated that one life was lost for every ton of gold extracted.

Five years ago, 104 miners died at Vaal Reefs mine when a locomotive used to haul coal fell down a mine shaft and crushed a cage carrying men about to start the night shift.

The industry claims its safety record has improved in recent years, but that is against a backdrop of a massive shrinkage in the workforce from 400,000 men five years ago to little more than half of that now.

Mine owners argue that because South Africa's gold is embedded deep in hard rock it more difficult and dangerous to extract than in other countries. Many shafts are also plagued by earth tremors brought on by mining itself.

But most mining companies claim they cannot afford early warning systems for rock falls - standard equipment in Australia and the United States.

The unions argue that the industry still puts profits ahead of lives, and many mines lack sufficient numbers of inspectors and training programmes.

South Africa signed an international mining safety convention two months ago.

webTitle: Judge in Cuban child case linked to exile activist

fields.headline: Judge in Cuban child case linked to exile activist
fields.trailText: The highly-politicised custody battle over a six-year-old Cuban boy took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the Miami judge who blocked the child's return to his father in Havana had business and political links with a Cuban exile activist who is leading the fight to keep him in the United States.
fields.body:
The highly-politicised custody battle over a six-year-old Cuban boy took another twist yesterday when it emerged that the Miami judge who blocked the child's return to his father in Havana had business and political links with a Cuban exile activist who is leading the fight to keep him in the United States.

Amando Gutierrez, who has acted as a spokesman for the campaign to prevent Elian Gonzalez's return to Cuba, admitted yesterday that he had worked as a paid political consultant for Judge Rosa Rodriguez when she was campaigning for her present post in 1998 elections.

Ms Rodriguez was not available for comment yesterday. Meanwhile her ruling on Monday that Elian could face "imminent and irreparable harm" if he returned to Cuba, was denounced by Havana as political manoeuvring, and severely criticised by US immigration lawyers as lacking a solid legal basis.

David Abraham, a University of Miami law professor, said: "If this is allowed to stand, then the entire structure of immigration law be comes captive to how much rabble-rousing a particular group can have."

Elian's fate yesterday rested with the US immigration and naturalisation service (INS) and the attorney-general, Janet Reno. The INS ruled last week that the boy - who was found clinging to a car tyre inner tube in the Florida Straits - should be returned to his father in Cuba by Friday. Elian's mother and 10 other fleeing Cubans drowned on the sea crossing to the US. Only Elian and two adults survived.

Elian's future has become the focus of a heated and multi-faceted political row at the start of a US presidential election year. It has set state judicial rights against federal law enforcement, the US against Cuba, and Republicans (who almost unanimously oppose Elian's immediate return) against Democrats (who mostly support it).

Maxine Waters, a Democratic congresswoman, said yesterday: "It's time for Janet Reno to wade in to this, and send the boy home."

An INS spokesman said that the agency had no immediate plans to repatriate the boy, but was examining its options in the light of yesterday's revelations. According to a Miami television report, Ms Rodriguez paid Mr Gutierrez $7,500 (£4,690) for help with her election campaign, and a further $1,000 to his wife for work on campaign ads.

Mr Gutierrez was unrepentant yesterday. "I do campaigns for a living. She paid me for a job. I did my job... I worked for plenty of judges and she was picked for this case at random," he told the Guardian.

He denied any contact with her immediately prior to Monday's ruling saying: "I haven't called her. I haven't sent her a telegram. I haven't sent her a smoke signal. I'm going to sleep very well tonight."

Ira Kurzban, an immigration lawyer, said: "I think it should have been disclosed, but I'm not sure it's necessarily fatal to the judgement. What state court judge is going to rule differently, given the political atmosphere in Miami and the fact that these are elected judges?"

"The question is, when is Ms Reno going to enforce federal law?" Mr Kurzban said, arguing that any ruling by a state family court could not override federal law.

"Either we have a rule of law or we have a rule of law except when Cubans demonstrate in the street," he said.

On Monday, Judge Rodriguez ordered that the child remain with his US relatives until March 6 so that the court could hear arguments from his great-uncle, who is seeking temporary custody. He claims he can give the boy a better life in the US.

Elian's father, Juan Miguel Gonzalez, has demanded that his son be returned to him in Cuba. Judge Rodriguez has ordered Mr Gonzalez to be at the March hearing, saying that his "failure to appear may result in a decision adverse to his interests". He has refused to come to the US.

webTitle: Court told design flaws led to Bhopal leak

fields.headline: Court told design flaws led to Bhopal leak
fields.trailText: Faulty design and poor maintenance caused a poisonous gas leak at a Union Carbide plant in 1984 that killed thousands of Indians in the world's worst industrial accident, a scientist testified yesterday.
fields.body:
Faulty design and poor maintenance caused a poisonous gas leak at a Union Carbide plant in 1984 that killed thousands of Indians in the world's worst industrial accident, a scientist testified yesterday.

The company also failed to notify the government and health officials that such large amounts of the toxic methyl isocyanate gas - used to make pesticides - was being stored underground at the site in Bhopal, said KS Vardharajan.

Mr Vardharajan was appearing as a witness in the trial of seven Indian employees of Union Carbide who face charges of negligence and of causing grievous injury in connection with the toxic leak.

At least 3,000 people were killed at the time. The government in Madhya Pradesh state, where Bhopal is located, says that nearly 11,000 more died in later years, due to ailments resulting from inhaling the gas.

Union Carbide's chairman at the time of the accident, Warren Anderson, has refused to appear in an Indian court on manslaughter charges and the authorities have been unable to extradite him from the United States.

Five years after the disaster, Union Carbide paid the government $470m (£294m) as part of an out-of-court settle ment. The company accepted moral responsibility for the disaster, but claimed at the time that the plant was sabotaged by a disgruntled employee.

Officials at the company's headquarters in Danbury, Connecticut, could not be reached for comment yesterday.

So far, 600,000 people have filed compensation claims with the Indian government. They say Union Carbide has done little to help the families of the victims.

Survivors still complain of ailments ranging from breathlessness, chronic fatigue and stomach pain to cardiac problems and tuberculosis.

Mr Vardharajan said that several factors made the accident inevitable. For example, the plant used carbon steel valves which corroded when they came in contact with acid, allowing the toxic gas to escape.

The cooling system that kept the gases at a low temperature also had not been working for a month when the leak occurred, he alleged.

He also claimed that information about the chemical properties of methyl isocyanate was not quickly made available by the company. As a result, he said, Indian health officials did not immediately know how to treat the victims of the poisoning.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: French truckers block routes
fields.body:
French truckers block routes

Hundreds of French lorry owners continued to block motorways, main roads and border posts yesterday as a national protest aimed at halting the introduction of a 35-hour week and at rising fuel costs showed no signs of ending.

About 70 roadblocks were reported at strategic points across the country, with major disruptions on the route to Alpine tunnels, forcing hundreds of British drivers to camp out in freezing conditions. Paul Webster, Paris

'Small Things' author held

Arundhati Roy, the prize-winning Indian author, was among 400 protesters arrested yesterday for "defying prohibitory orders" when they tried to picket a dam in the state of Madhya Pradesh, the Press Trust of India reported.

Ms Roy, whose first novel The God of Small Things won the Booker Prize in 1997, has been actively involved with environmentalists protesting against the construction of large dams in India. Reuters, New Delhi

Heavy-handed security at shop

Security guards at a large supermarket in south China chopped off a pregnant woman's fingers after accusing her of shoplifting.

Seamstress Lu Shanhui, who is seven months' pregnant, had denied stealing a packet of tea from the Aijia store in Dongguan city, in Guangdong.

After she was strip searched by a female worker, a senior official held down her hand and, backed by four or five other men, chopped off her fingers, kicked her and yelled at her to leave. Police were last night still hunting the store official. AP, Beijing

Three killed in gangster attack

Three men were killed and a fourth was injured yesterday when two gunmen fired Kalashnikovs at a car waiting at a traffic light in the centre of Tirana.

Police believe the attack, in a busy street not far from the Albanian capital's main boulevard, was sparked by an argument between two rival gangs.

Detectives believed they knew the names of the assailants, who fled leaving their weapons and vehicle behind. AP, Tirana

Algeria pardons rebel group

The Algerian president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, decreed a blanket pardon for members of the Islamic Salvation Army yesterday, two days before a deadline for all Islamic militants to lay down their arms.

The president said that the terrorist group had decided to "definitively dissolve itself". His decree "exonerates" AIS members, opening the way for a "complete and total reintegration into Algerian society".

The decree appears to open the way for AIS members to cooperate with security forces in tracking down Islamic extremists who refuse to end their battle for an Islamic state. AP, Algiers

Long haul into courts over ad

Cape Town council is threatening to sue Richard Branson's Virgin airlines for changing street signs while recording a television advertisement.

Virgin wanted to emphasise the extra leg room it claims to offer on flights to South Africa by changing the name of one of the city's most famous streets from "Long" to "Longer" for the recording.

The council refused, but Virgin pasted over the original signs anyway, and attached its logo. Chris McGreal, Johannesburg

fields.headline: Nicky Clarke
fields.body:
Age: 41.

Appearance: Cacophanously coiffeured, strawberry-blond member of a Bee Gees tribute band. He's cut it back in the past few years, though, and is said to hate papers using old photos of his once-flowing tresses.

Job description: Celebrity hairstylist - snipper to the stars and purveyor of barnstorming barnets to the masses, via his many TV appearances.

Current and former clients: Liz Hurley, George Michael, Jerry Hall, Isabella Rossellini, Julia Carling and Sarah Ferguson (whose custom first brought fame), who shell out £300 for an initial cut and £175 for a cut and blow dry thereafter. Princess Diana was a valued customer, too.

Enough of all this fancy stuff. I just want one of them Anthea Turner haircuts. Listen, this is the man who gave Anthea Turner her Anthea Turner haircut. So don't mess. And he's just made it into the first Who's Who of the new century, published today, making him the first hairdresser ever to gain an entry in the top people's tome.

But I thought Who's Who was reserved for cultural giants and captains of industry? You're forgetting, presumably, that Nicky is the author of the critically acclaimed literary megalith Hair Power, and presides over a range of haircare merchandise - amusingly entitled Hairomatherapy - which is rumoured to bring in more than £3m a year. Anyway, he's hardly the most radical name to be included in the new edition.

Who else made the grade? Well, there's Floella Benjamin (whose recreational interests include golf, cooking and running); Scotland coach Craig Brown (swimming in the sea, drinking and shopping); and Teletubbies creator Anne Wood (gurgling, cooking Tubbytoast and waving moronically at the sun).

A democratic revolution at Who's Who! Where can I get a copy? Not that democratic, I'm afraid: a hard copy costs £115. Why, you could get a Nicky Clarke trim for that. Almost.

Words Nicky Clarke may live to regret: "People would probably pay £400, but I couldn't do it," he said in 1996. "It's too much for a haircut."

Don't say: "I'd like to make a booking for the £2.50 OAP special on Thursday morning, please."

webTitle: Why York should be the capital of England

fields.headline: Why York should be the capital of England
fields.standfirst: As Jack Straw warns of the dark forces of nationalism, singer  Billy Bragg says it's high time England had its own devolved parliament - outside London. Below, his musical take on the subject
fields.trailText: As Jack Straw warns of the dark forces of nationalism, singer  Billy Bragg says it's high time England had its own devolved parliament - outside London. Below, his musical take on the subject
fields.body:
Jack Straw's comments on the potentially violent nature of English nationalism may come to be seen as a defining moment in the search for a modern sense of English identity. Speaking in a Radio 4 documentary about what it means to be British in the aftermath of devolution, the home secretary shied away from the subject of a separate English identity by suggesting that there is something dark and dangerous lurking in the heart of England.

This instinctive reaction, that Englishness is a stone best left unturned, is not uncommon among liberal-minded people, woolly or otherwise. Sadly it is our squeamishness on this subject that has allowed it to become the preserve of bigots and bootboys. Until the fair-minded majority of the English, who like to think of tolerance and a sense of fair play as national traits, can begin to evoke an inclusive identity for everyone who belongs to England, then it will be left to the Powellite right to declare who does and who does not belong here.

But as we peep through our fingers, fearful of seeing Jack Straw's scary monster, how do we begin to define this new England? This is where Straw's comments take on their importance. The Daily Telegraph pounced on his words, pointing out that the world came to know England through the martial feats of the British (never English) empire and that he was guilty of confusing the two. The newspaper's reaction suggests that it is no longer permissible to speak in an ambiguous manner about England when you mean Britain: from this seemingly cosmetic distinction, a new sense of who we are may yet emerge.

One of the difficulties in getting the English to discuss their own distinctiveness is that the agenda has been set and is driven by events outside of our country. All of the awkward questions that we are now having to address have been forced on us partly by Wales, but mostly by Scotland. Our Scottish neighbours have redefined themselves over the past 20 years and, by voting for their own parliament in the recent referendum, seem to have opted out of being British.

As we experience it now, Britishness is fundamentally a 19th-century concept based on an imperial world view. The British among us are a people who believe that there is only one culture in our society, a sense of tradition which can be summed up in the phrase Queen and Country. When I think of Britishness, I think of Jonathan Aitken and his trusty sword of truth. Perhaps, by beginning to create some clear blue water between the British and the English, we can start to evoke an inclusive identity that all our citizens can feel comfortable with.

Another effect of Jack Straw's comments was to raise once again the hoary old West Lothian Question. This is a game of charades that our parliamentarians play in the hope of undermining the devolution of power away from Westminster. Now that there is a Scottish parliament, the argument goes, English MPs no longer have a vote over a number of important Scottish issues; so why should Scottish MPs retain their voting rights on matters pertaining to England?

Although this is presented as the main argument against devolution, it is in fact an argument that calls for a greater devolving of power away from Westminster, which may explain why MPs find it so unpalatable. Our cousins in the United States would see it as a simple problem of states' rights. Britain is a unitary state which has its union parliament at Westminster. Scotland is a nation which has its national parliament in Edinburgh. The union parliament has representation from all of the nations that make up the UK and exercises power on that level. The national parliament in Edinburgh has members only from Scotland and debates Scottish issues. The answer to the West Lothian Question is simple: England must have its own national parliament.

That so many people are underwhelmed by that prospect may be partly due to the fact that we in England already feel that we have a parliament in our capital city, London. But London isn't just the capital of our nation, it is also the capital of the unitary British state. While the organisers of the millennium celebrations in Cardiff and Edinburgh felt free to use the symbols of Welsh and Scots identity, there was no singing of Blake's Jerusalem in the Millennium Dome because that was the venue not for England's national celebration, but for Britain's.

A devolved England cannot flourish in the hothouse atmosphere of Westminster. Everyone agrees that too much power is already centralised in London and the south. If we are serious about devolution, then a new city will have to be chosen to be the capital of England, where the old traditions and the new diversities can find common ground. As a Londoner and a southerner, I would like to nominate York, a city outside the major metropolitan centres yet with a strong multi-cultural tradition.

While we strive to be British, to include our neighbours in the scheme of things, so we English seem to be losing out. The reality is that we are comfortable with being both British and English, it suits our cosmopolitan nature. However, the dark forces that Jack Straw hinted at are out there, determined to make Englishness a matter of ethnicity rather than personal identity. Would devolution make the bigots go away? Of course not, but an English national parliament would offer the people of England a forum in which to debate these issues and to find out whether or not we are as tolerant and fair-minded as we like to think we are.

fields.headline: Ban on arms export credits
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000

Brown attempts to stop aid and debt relief being used for military spending
fields.trailText: Britain is to ban the use of export credits for arms sales to 63 of the world's poorest nations as part of an attempt to ensure aid and debt relief are channelled into poverty reduction rather than military spending, Gordon Brown announced last night.
fields.body:
Britain is to ban the use of export credits for arms sales to 63 of the world's poorest nations as part of an attempt to ensure aid and debt relief are channelled into poverty reduction rather than military spending, Gordon Brown announced last night.

The chancellor said the government was imposing an indefinite block on the export credit guarantee department underwriting unproductive expenditure in struggling developing nations, and called on other western nations to follow his lead.

Speaking in Oxford, Mr Brown said: "Britain's export credits will only support productive investment that assists social and economic development and reduce poverty. Britain's ban will only fully achieve its aim if it is applied by all exporting countries."

Treasury sources said the hard line on export credits would include not only military hardware but also luxury goods such as yachts for political leaders in impoverished nations.

It is intended to dovetail with the announcement made before Christmas that Britain is to write off all its official debt to the poorest nations.

The ban will cover the 41 states eligible for debt relief under the heavily indebted poor country initiative, HIPC, and a further 22 nations who can only obtain "soft loans" from the World Bank, and then only on a low-cost, concessionary basis.

The list of countries affected includes some ravaged by civil war in recent years such as Sierra Leone and Ethiopia, but it excludes some of the biggest markets for British arms sales in the past such as Indonesia, Pakistan and Nigeria.

However, the treasury said that it had been responsible for drawing up the list of 63 countries and insisted that there had been no attempt by other government departments to interfere.

For the past two years Britain has imposed a temporary bar on export credits for unproductive expenditure to the HIPC countries, but the government now intends to widen the ban and make it indefinite.

The export credit guarantee department acts as an insurance policy for British exporters which are involved in large-scale projects to countries where there is high political risk - picking up the bill if loans go sour.

Mr Brown said that debt reduction and aid were not enough on their own to spur growth and tackle poverty. "They could simply lead to millions of pounds flowing to prestige projects that do nothing to relieve poverty, or to corrupt regimes and to military excess that destroys rather than builds for a better future.

"Only when combined with the right economic and social policies, which are essential to sustainable economic development, can debt relief be the catalyst for the true release from poverty."

The chancellor stressed that there was a need for a strong link between debt relief and poverty reduction, and outlined four areas in which action was needed.

Mr Brown said there needed to be a change in the culture and operations of the World Bank and the IMF, measures to build skills in developing countries, partnerships between governments and non-governmental organisations on the ground, and vigilance in ensuring that resources were not wasted on unproductive spending.

"This would be one of the most worthwhile investments that can be made - not just ensuring the integrity of the poverty programmes in the short term, but also in empowering the poorest to to build a better future for themselves", Mr Brown said.

The last King Ethelred of England - Ethelred II "The Unready" - died in 1016. King Henry II was on the throne in 1164.

In our brief item, Villagers break away from UK, page 12, January 8, we said The People's Republic of Ashurst Wood Nation State justified its action in declaring independence because "King Ethelred granted the village immunity from taxation in 1164..." The last King Ethelred of England - Ethelred II "The Unready" - died in 1016. King Henry II was on the throne in 1164.

The author of The Legend of Sleepy Hollow, the book behind the film Sleepy Hollow, pages 12 and 13, G2 yesterday, was Washington Irving, not Irvine.

The hill in East Lothian referred to in our report about UFO activity, page 20, January 10, is North Berwick Law (rather than just Berwick Law). It stands above the coastal village of North Berwick.

The hotel mentioned in our report about Gibraltar's influx of bookmakers, page 27, January 6, is the Eliott (rather than Elliott). It is named after Lord Heathfield of Gibraltar (George Augustus Eliott) who became governor of Gibraltar in 1775 and defended it against Spain in the great siege of 1779-83. He was given his title in 1787 (Hutchinson Encyclopedia). The people of Gibraltar are known as Gibraltarians, not Gibraltans.

fields.headline: Devil in the detail
fields.standfirst: A Country Diary
fields.trailText: The Stiperstones
fields.body:
The Stiperstones

"Where's the Devil's Chair?" asked the man as we scrambled up the rocks into the throne-like tor of shattered quartzite. "This is it," I said, "you've found it." "But how do you know?" he asked incredulously. I tried to explain that it says so on the map and I'd been coming here for 30 years. There is something you just "know" about the Devil's Chair on the Stiperstones, which defies explanation.

Despite the maps, legends, folklore and literature, this remarkable place has a strange, compelling identity of its own. When you go there you know what it is. The man relayed what I'd said to the rest of his family and they repeated it. "But there's no sign saying this is the Devil's Chair, and anyway it doesn't look much like a chair," he insisted.

What did he expect, smouldering red draylon and sulphur candles? The man and his family didn't look convinced or particularly interested by this craggy phenomenon. We said it looked more like a chair from a distance, and they shuffled about in the heather, got fed up and moved on.

Perhaps they would have been more impressed if there had been a sign and an interpretation board - perhaps with a quote from the Shropshire novelist Mary Webb, who said of the Devil's Chair in her 1920s novel, The Golden Arrow, "Nothing ever altered its look. It remained inviolable, taciturn, evil. It glowered darkly on the dawn; it came through the snow like jagged bones through flesh . . . For miles around, in the plains, the valleys, the mountain dwellings, it was feared. It drew the thunder, people said."

Yes mate, you've found it, but it hasn't found you.

A grouse gave its wind-up call from out in the heather and winberry heath. The ravens were giving short fast calls as they rattled round the sky which glowed in oranges and browns beyond the western hills - illuminating a world with no tangible focus, which defied interpretation. The wind got up and began whistling through the Devil's Chair and dark clouds spitting rain came with it.

fields.headline: BT launches £1.5bn Esat rescue
fields.trailText: British Telecom yesterday staged a £1.5bn "white knight" rescue of Esat, Ireland's second largest telecommunications company.
fields.body:
British Telecom yesterday staged a £1.5bn "white knight" rescue of Esat, Ireland's second largest telecommunications company.

The agreed deal saw off the £1.2bn hostile bid made by Norwegian state-owned telecoms company Telenor in December. The BT offer was at a 17.6% premium, forcing Telenor to concede defeat.

BT chairman Sir Iain Vallance said the deal represented "a good price and a fair price well within the boundaries of comparable deals in Europe". For the year ending December 31 1998, Esat reported revenues of £25m and a loss of £18m.

BT is expected to roll Esat into its established Irish business, Ocean, a 50:50 joint venture with the Irish Electricity Supply Board, which serves corporate clients.

Esat has the largest fixed-line network in Ireland behind Eircom, the recently privatised state business. It has 46% of the mobile market and claims to be the largest corporate internet service provider.

"Ireland is an important and rapidly developing telecoms market where Esat has been successful in establishing itself as the leading competitor to Eircom," said BT chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield.

Esat's founder and chief executive, Denis O'Brien, who owns 14% of the four-year-old company, has already agreed to sell his stake, netting himself over £200m.

Fidelity investments, the American fund manager, has also committed its share, securing BT around a quarter of the company. Mr O'Brien will stay on for two years as non-executive chairman.

The City failed to warm to the deal. BT shares fell more than 3% to £11.78 due to disappointment that the company had engaged in a deal which would do little for shareholder value. BT is paying $50 per Esat share and $100 per American depository share.

The Norwegian bidder said: "This represents a price which Telenor does not believe it would be appropriate to pay."

BT paid an additional £16m for a 1% stake in mobile phone business Esat Digifone, adding it to the 49.5% controlled by the Irish company. Another 49.5% is held by Telenor, which said it was discussing the situation with BT.

The acquisition adds another asset to BT's growing portfolio in Europe, which covers 12 countries.

Its chief interests include a 26% stake in Cegetel in France, 45% in Viag Interkom in Germany and a share in Albacom in Italy.

In Spain and Belgium it has wholly owned subsidiaries offering fixed wire services.

fields.headline: Belgo
fields.trailText: Belgo, the restaurant group chaired by colourful entrepreneur Luke Johnson, hit the buffers with a jolt yesterday as it issued a warning that profits in the year to June are unlikely to meet expectations.
fields.body:
Belgo, the restaurant group chaired by colourful entrepreneur Luke Johnson, hit the buffers with a jolt yesterday as it issued a warning that profits in the year to June are unlikely to meet expectations.

Shares in the company, whose brands range from Belgos and Bierodromes to fashionable venues such as Pasha, Daphne's and The Collection, crashed more than 18%, or 1p, to hit 5p. That is nearly half their peak last spring and means they are lower than at any time during the past 18 months.

The group has been hit by the low sales which have afflicted other chains such as Chez Gerard; it is also suffering from over-rapid expansion.

Now, much slower sales in its new overseas restaurants have combined with a poor first quarter at many of its UK outlets to undermine profitability. A statement from the company suggested that the Caprice division, which runs London outlets The Ivy, Le Caprice and J Skeekey - is the only part of its business which is firing on all cylinders. Caprice was acquired for £13.14m in 1998.

Other "branded concepts", such as Signature, are clearly turning in unexciting earnings and the market is beginning to wonder whether Mr Johnson has it in him to recreate the success he managed with Pizza Express.

But Belgo has been here before. The full year profits of just £500,000 for the year to June undershot analysts' forecasts by about 12%, and promise of further disappointments saw the group heading yesterday's list of the small-cap losers.

Analysts are now criticising the group for a lack of focus and failure to prove long-term demand for its major brands.

fields.headline: Retailers face a deflating year
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Kingfisher shares were given a savage beating yesterday as chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy warned that despite decent Christmas sales volumes and margins were under pressure and costs had risen.
fields.body:
Kingfisher shares were given a savage beating yesterday as chief executive Sir Geoff Mulcahy warned that despite decent Christmas sales volumes and margins were under pressure and costs had risen.

But the City, which had marked up the stock 22% since mid-December, is likely to take the view that shooting the messenger and all who look like him is the best policy. New research from Commerzbank suggests a combination of price deflation and e-commerce will seriously damage a range of retailers this year.

Debenhams, Marks & Spencer, Somerfield and WH Smith are most exposed, says Savvas Savouri head of quantitative economics at Commerzbank. "Margin pressures and trading weakness could lead to dividend cuts [at those companies] this year."

The prices of books, toys and a range of other products sold on the high street are now lower than 12 months ago while government statistics underplay deflation because they have yet to incorporate internet pricing into their calculations. Input prices are falling while new heavyweight cost-cutters have hit the scene.

But these factors should not cloud the fact that Christmas has been a more uplifting period for many companies than anyone dared imagine. Jewellery group Goldsmiths reported a 26.3% rise in like-for-like sales, while clothing retailer Next saw an 18% rise and discount store Matalan was up 19.5%.

Today Dixons should report strong sales figures but M&S is likely to show it is still struggling.

The top and bottom ends of the retail market still seems to be performing well although the pre-Christmas profit warning from clothing group Arcadia and the troubles at M&S reflect ongoing difficulties for mid-market players. The British Retail Consortium noted that food and homewares were much stronger markets than clothing.

Kingfisher, which owns Woolworth, B&Q and Comet, yesterday saw its shares plunge 96p to 577p, its biggest one-day fall, though like-for-like sales rose 6%.

The sell-off was overdone but let's not forget retailers have still got to contend with a government price enquiry.

webTitle: Little gizmo maker offers big solutions

fields.headline: Little gizmo maker offers big solutions
fields.standfirst: Notebook Psion-Vodafone alliance weighs in
fields.trailText: One of the little twists accompanying Vodafone's vision of the new walkin', talkin', digital downloadin' world yesterday was the way in which the only other substantial British company on Vodafone's list of new era partners only saw its name added after the main news was formally released.
fields.body:
One of the little twists accompanying Vodafone's vision of the new walkin', talkin', digital downloadin' world yesterday was the way in which the only other substantial British company on Vodafone's list of new era partners only saw its name added after the main news was formally released.

A separate announcement was required to the stock exchange to declare that Psion, the electronic organiser manufacturer, is also a strategic partner in helping Vodafone deliver mobile internet services.

No particularly convincing explanation for this was offered yesterday. But it is probably fair to bet that the importance of Psion to Vodafone in terms of actually delivering its promises means that this particular alliance is rather more strategic than it sounds.

More than 18 months have passed since Psion stunned outsiders by hiving off the rights to its Epoc operating system into Symbian, a venture jointly owned with some of the world's biggest manufacturers of mobile phones - Nokia and Ericsson among them.

While the City was slow to realise as much, the initiative added form and substance to a broadly European move to rebuff Microsoft, which had been busy transposing a compact edition of its Windows operating system ready for the new generation of wireless devices. Firms such as Nokia never ruled out working with Microsoft; they just popped up one day and said they were backing what was then a £200m British business which appeared to have better technology on offer.

Yet until quite recently a cloud of resignation seemed to hang over Psion. This company had been around for years, always managing to fail to live up to its potential.

Its products looked over-engineered and overpriced, while its marketing effort and general corporate clout always appeared woefully inadequate.

It was just too much for many to believe that the innards of Psion's little gizmos might suddenly take over where Windows and its lumpen roots in the desktop PC left off. As far as the Symbian venture was concerned, cynics assumed the venture was simply a bargaining tool for the mobile manufacturers in a much bigger corporate play.

It might yet prove to be so. But the fact that Psion is sitting next to firms such as Sun Microsystems and IBM on Vodafone's bench of partners suggests something much more substantive is under way. In fact, it is promising to deliver the first products - sorry, solutions - for Vodafone by the autumn.

From the initial formation of Symbian it took a further 15 months before outsiders began to realise the potential value of the Epoc technology and Psion became a £1bn firm. The recent hi-tech frenzy has turned it, in the market's eyes, into a £2bn firm. Yet there is a real chance here that investors are still overlooking a spectacular upside in one of our most innovative businesses.

Sterling tones

For as long as we can remember Britain's manufacturing industry - and particularly the engineering sector - has whinged about the strength of sterling and high interest rates, laying all its woes at the feet of malign outside forces. Every quarter the Engineering Employers Federation produces a new survey among its members that prompts yet another litany of woe.

Yesterday, sure enough, the green shoots of recovery - seen in every other survey - were acknowledged. But EEF leaders still complained that they could swiftly be trampled under foot by the high pound and increased borrowing costs - the latter likely as early as tomorrow. At the same time, however, a more nuanced tone began to emerge from the chorus.

Confidence about export orders has been steadily rising ever since the third quarter of 1998 - despite sterling's strength. Several sectors such as electronics, electrical equipment, cars, aerospace, are doing well, thanks to global demand. More critically, the pound at three German marks or more has forced engineering companies to cut costs, largely by shedding an expected 100,000 jobs last year. Productivity growth, as a result, has topped 5% a year and has, for the first time in five years, overtaken that in the economy as a whole.

At the grassroots, managing directors such as Terry Scouler of Ferranti Technologies - based in Oldham, mark you - admit that blaming sterling for every woe is far too easy. The solution, he said at yesterday's EEF presentation, is competitiveness, innovation - and yes, quality of management.

Around him EEF leaders were still lamenting that sterling and interest rates were hammering investment. He disagrees, and ought not to be alone. Pay settlements in engineering are 2.4% and falling; costs are being squeezed out; companies are leaner and fitter; the overall economic climate is benign. All it takes to invest for the longer term, as Mr Scouler said, is a little boldness. But that, as in large swaths of manufacturing, remains in short supply.

webTitle: Job cuts point to engineering fragility

fields.headline: Job cuts point to engineering fragility
fields.trailText: Britain's engineering industry yesterday underlined the fragility of the recovery in manufacturing when it disclosed that hundreds of companies are still cutting investment and jobs.
fields.body:
Britain's engineering industry yesterday underlined the fragility of the recovery in manufacturing when it disclosed that hundreds of companies are still cutting investment and jobs.

The Engineering Employers' Federation called the sustainiability of the recent rise in output into question as its latest quarterly survey showed export orders continuing to decline and the rise in domestic orders concentrated in the south of England.

The industry shed 76,500 jobs in the 12 months to Sep tember and senior EEF officials said the sector was likely to have cut just under 100,000 in the whole of 1999.

Firms have greeted the millennium by announcing plans for further redundancies, though the pace will be slower than last year according to David Yeandle, the EEF's head of employment policy. Vacancies have halved to just 13,313; the industry employs 1.67m.

But pay settlements are running at 2.4%, below the Bank of England's target rate for inflation - and the gap with those in the service sector is at an historic high. The bank's monetary policy committee is expected to raise base rates by 0.25% tomorrow to take the heat out of services and the south-east housing boom.

EEF officials said uncertainty about demand coupled with the strength of sterling and the increase in interest rates was dampening investment and could damage the recovery.

Productivity growth in manufacturing as a whole, a fresh EEF analysis showed, is now more than 5%, and for the first time since 1994 has overtaken that in the general economy, where it has declined over the same period.

The EEF survey underscored the north-south divide with orders still falling in the north-east, Yorkshire and Humberside, Scotland, east Midlands and north west. Northern Ireland bucks the trend, largely thanks to the peace process.

The recovery is strongest in industries such as electronics, electrical equipment, motor vehicles, and aerospace and defence which tend to be based in the south. Overall, the EEF believes the strength of the pound could wipe out the recent productivity gains.

fields.headline: Baird launches £53m claim against M&S
fields.trailText: As it launched a £53m compensation claim William Baird, the clothing company axed by Marks & Spencer after supplying the retailer for more than 30 years, yesterday provided an insight into the way M&S does business.
fields.body:
As it launched a £53m compensation claim William Baird, the clothing company axed by Marks & Spencer after supplying the retailer for more than 30 years, yesterday provided an insight into the way M&S does business.

Baird claims that it was entitled to three years' notice from M&S and says the overnight termination last October means it faces costs of more than £50m.

These, said chief executive David Suddens, range from shutting down factories to redundancy payments for the 4,500 staff it will have to lay off by the end of April if it cannot replace the M&S business.

Baird's action comes even though - like all other M&S suppliers - it never had a written contract. But the textile company says it had a verbal contract with M&S and a long-term relationship that resulted in the retailer buying 40% of the company's output.

M&S has always boasted about the special relationship it had with its suppliers, but Mr Suddens claims M&S "encouraged" Baird to halt production of other retailers' own-label garments, and even told the company where it must buy all its fabric.

"We had to accept procedures and constraints that were not normal in a commercial relationship," he said.

"They encouraged us to make acquisitions.

"And when we wanted to merge with rival M&S supplier Coats Viyella they said that did not satisfy their requirements.

"The whole point of accepting such an unusual commercial relationship was that it was long term.

"It was close to a partnership," he added.

Last night a spokeswoman for M&S said its directors did not feel they had any responsibility towards Baird. "Our responsibility is towards our employees and our remaining suppliers," she said.

M&S also denied that it had expressed any opinion about Baird's proposed merger with Coats Viyella last year, and said it would contest Baird's action.

The retail store chain publishes its seasonal trading figures today, with analysts betting the results will be so poor that they will be accompanied by another profits warning.

fields.headline: Bank and utility join forces
fields.trailText: Royal Bank of Scotland and ScottishPower yesterday set up a new internet venture to unite the provision of financial products and utility services.
fields.body:
Royal Bank of Scotland and ScottishPower yesterday set up a new internet venture to unite the provision of financial products and utility services.

Through a new website customers will be able to arrange financial products such as mortgages and insurance as well set up their gas, electricity and water supplies.

The two Scottish companies will spend £70m over the next 18 months developing the project, which will be backed by Thus, the internet and telecoms firm in which ScottishPower has a 50.1% stake.

The companies, which claim to be able to reach one in five households, aim to offer a package tailored to the needs of their customers. For instance, customers moving house would be able to arrange their mortgage, insurance, utilities and pay their bills.

The service - to begin this summer - will also be available by calling one of Scottish Power's call centres or its retail stores.

Iain Robertson, chief executive of Royal Bank's UK operation, said the project aimed to be profitable within two years

The move continues the trend among companies to tie financial products with other services. Royal Bank, which is locked in a tussle to win control of NatWest, has a venture with supermarket chain Tesco, while Centrica is using the Goldfish credit card to reach its gas customers.

fields.headline: Kingfisher suffers seasonal squeeze
fields.standfirst: A shop-till-you-drop Christmas leaves shareholders nonplussed
fields.trailText: Christmas shoppers might have been clearing the shelves of the big retailers, as their figures showed yesterday, but they were not paying enough for their goods to make life happy for all the stores' shareholders.
fields.body:
Christmas shoppers might have been clearing the shelves of the big retailers, as their figures showed yesterday, but they were not paying enough for their goods to make life happy for all the stores' shareholders.

Shares in Kingfisher tumbled by more than 14% as the group, which owns Comet, B&Q, Superdrug and Woolworths, said that prices were under continuing pressure.

From one end of the price spectrum to the other - department store Selfridges, which bills itself as the "House of Brands" to out-of-town discount fashion specialists Matalan - yesterday's Christmas sales figures were better than had been predicted.

Seasonal sales figures were robust for Kingfisher's outlets too, but they were accompanied by a warning that profit margins were under pressure and that costs were increasing.

Kingfisher's chief executive, Sir Geoff Mulcahy, said that the group's like-for-like sales, which exclude the effect of new shopfloor space, were up 6% on 1998 levels in the last nine weeks of 1999. Total sales, which incorporate the impact of new selling space, were ahead by 30.8%.

He said that, while attempts to keep down prices had put profit margins under pressure, "we are pleased with our performance".

Kingfisher had incurred "additional significant costs" in the last few months connected with e-commerce developments, which were now expected to total £21m, compared to the £10 estimated previously.

Sir Geoff said: "Competition in the retail sector gets tougher year by year. Margins have been coming down for several years and that isn't going to change soon." He pinpointed Comet and Superdrug as having the toughest time on prices.

A spokeswoman for Kingfisher nevertheless insisted that the impact on margins had been small, and focused on a few products, such as mobile phones. She said: "We are not seeing anything here that is unexpected".

The warning was still unexpected, analysts claimed. They immediately recalculated their profit forecasts for the company, slashing some £50m off their expectations for the full year.

Kingfisher's shares fell 95p to close at 578p, their biggest ever one-day drop. "It came as a genuine surprise," said Robert Miller, retail analyst at Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. "They have lost around half a percentage point in gross margin in the second half."

Elsewhere, Matalan shares leaped after the company, which is still 60% owned by its founder, John Hargreaves, said its like-for-like sales in the five weeks to January 1 had been ahead 19.5% on last year and margins were also improving. Its shares, which came to the market only two years ago at 235p, are now changing hands at 1935, up 70p yesterday. One analyst said that despite the rapid ascent the shares remained "exciting".

Selfridges, which now trades from a Manchester outlet as well as its London store in Oxford Street, similarly reported better than expected sales, up 12.9% in the six weeks to January 8; most analysts had forecast growth of less than 10%. The shares rose 6p to a new high of 295p.

webTitle: Branson hopes to buy One2One out of mobile phone venture

fields.headline: Branson hopes to buy One2One out of mobile phone venture
fields.trailText: Richard Branson aims to buy joint venture partner One2One out of the company's mobile phone business if his Virgin empire wins a third generation mobile licence.
fields.body:
Richard Branson aims to buy joint venture partner One2One out of the company's mobile phone business if his Virgin empire wins a third generation mobile licence.

Virgin was last night trying to finalise details of its bid for a licence, which needs to be lodged with the radiocommunications agency by 3pm today.

The company is understood to have pulled together a consortium of around five investors for the bid, including a telecoms company and at least one financial backer.

Insiders said that the bid would be made separately to an application for one of the licences by One2One.

Mobile phones and the high speed access to the internet which third generation technology allows were identified by Mr Branson as key to the future of his group after selling a stake in Virgin Atlantic.

Virgin and One2One each invested an initial £50m into Virgin Mobile but, even before the launch, Chris Godsmark at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite put a valuation on the business of £1.4bn.

It is understood that no mechanism was established for agreeing a price should one of the Virgin Mobile partners decide to sell, which means that Mr Branson could face difficult negotiations.

In the six weeks between the service's introduction and Christmas, Virgin Mobile sold 100,000 handsets and analysts estimate that the year-end figure could reach 800,000.

The auction for the five available licences will take place in March and should attract keen interest from home and overseas.

The government has set a combined reserve price of £500m with the largest amount of spectrum set aside for a new entrant and costing at least £125m. Prices could go far higher if competition is fierce.

fields.body:
The government has re-opened a series of disputes in the rapidly changing pay-television market by announcing a competition review into BSkyB's position as the sector's dominant player.

The office of fair trading is to review the undertakings made by the satellite broadcaster in 1996 covering the sale of programmes and channels, mainly to cable operators, to meet competition concerns in the then fledgling market.

BSkyB claimed that the announcement by the director general of fair trading, John Bridgeman, was a precursor to relaxing regulation across the sector, but the satellite broadcaster's rivals said they would use the review as an opportunity to express the concerns they have over the way BSkyB sells its broadcasting rights.

"The UK has a unique position in digital broadcasting and the TV industry is rapidly evolving," Mr Bridgeman said.

"We have to be sure that competition is healthy and responsive to developments. Our approach is from the perspective that regulation should be kept to the minimum necessary to promote competition."

A BSkyB spokesman argued that the consolidation which has taken place in the cable sector since the guidelines were established - leaving it with three major players, NTL, Cable & Wireless Communications and Telewest - meant that its rivals no longer needed the protection of government regulation to compete.

At the same time ONdigital has emerged to provide competition to BSkyB's digital service, he added.

"They're big boys now," the BSkyB official said. "The cable operators are now backed by major international companies like Microsoft, AT&T and France Telecom. They don't need regulations to help them negotiate their carriage deals."

However, its rivals rejected the claims, saying BSkyB remained the UK's dominant pay-TV force by some distance. They added that the way in which BSkyB bundles the channels it sells to its rivals should also be examined.

An ONdigital spokesman said BSkyB was a dominant player with a customer base of millions and the majority of broadcasting rights and its position ought to be looked at.

A Telewest spokesman said: "We have consistently argued for a root and branch investigation of the way BSkyB conducts its wholesale business.

"We have written to the OFT to call for it to look at the broad issues of BSkyB's behaviour as a wholesaler and retailer of exclusive, premium pay TV content such as sports.

"We also rejected BSkyB's latest ratecard proposal, under which it has also made further significant increases to the wholesale price of its premium channels."

The OFT's inquiry follows a period during which Brussels has been reminding national regulators of rules concerning dominant parties in individual sectors. The OFT said full details of the terms of its own review will be published shortly.

BSkyB shares closed up 16p at £10.25 in a sector still excited by the $350bn AOL-Time Warner merger.

 The EU announced yesterday that it was seeking comments on BSkyB's acquisition of joint control in Germany's KirchPayTV.

fields.headline: ONdigital reports 34% rise in sales
fields.trailText: ONdigital, the terrestrial television broadcaster, yesterday reported a 34% increase over the past three months for subscriptions to its pay-television services but the rate of growth disappointed some analysts in the City.
fields.body:
ONdigital, the terrestrial television broadcaster, yesterday reported a 34% increase over the past three months for subscriptions to its pay-television services but the rate of growth disappointed some analysts in the City.

The company, owned by Carlton Communications and Granada, blamed a lack of integrated digital TV sets in the shops at Christmas for undermining further subscription sales. But it still described the period up to December 31 as "a tremendous quarter".

ONdigital, which has had 552,000 subscriptions in its first year, was pleased about the sale of the prepaid boxes which provide access to the company's programmes. They accounted for 50% of retail sales in December.

Stuart Prebble, ONdigital's chief executive said: "We are beginning to convert middle England to pay-television. These are people who have never paid for extra television before."

The company also announced it had agreed the joint pay-per-view venture ONrequest, which will be launched with five channels in the first half of this year. Its partner is SDN, a consortium comprising United News & Media, cable operator NTL and Welsh broadcaster S4C.

ONdigital is conducting trials for its ONmail email service, which it plans to launch in the next couple of months. Customers who buy a low-cost infrared keyboard will be able to send and receive emails from their televisions. There are also plans to provide customers with internet access to the set-top boxes.

Nick Ward, a media analyst with Commerzbank, said that ONdigital's rate of growth of new subscriptions was "a bit disappointing", despite the increase in September sales to 82,000.

Initial figures for the last quarter suggest an average of 47,000 new subscribers were added a month during what should have been the busiest time of the year, he said.

Mr Prebble said he was confident ONdigital would meet its target of 2m subscribers by 2002, which would allow it to break even. The company said 70% of its customers were pleased with the service. BSkyB's Sky Digital, ONdigital's satellite rival, had signed up 1.8m customers by October 14.

He revealed that ONdigital had made a pretax loss for the 12 months to end September of £148m - which was in line with expectations.

Although the ONdigital shareholders have considered plans for floating the company, Mr Prebble would not rule out a strategic alliance after being asked how the company might react to changes in the industry such as the AOL-Time Warner deal.

Granada announced in November that it would consider a stock market flotation for ONdigital this year, valuing the company at more than £1bn - a figure financial director Jeanette Wilkins described as "on the low side".

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Pay claim fuels inflation fears
Germany's powerful engineering union, IG Metall, yesterday lodged an inflation-busting pay claim of up to 5.5% in a move which reinforced expectations of higher interest rates in euroland.
fields.body:
Pay claim fuels inflation fears
Germany's powerful engineering union, IG Metall, yesterday lodged an inflation-busting pay claim of up to 5.5% in a move which reinforced expectations of higher interest rates in euroland.

"This will cause some nerves at the European Central Bank that the German pay round will have undesirable results," said Thomas Mayer, senior economist at Goldman Sachs in Frankfurt. "It makes our forecast more likely that the ECB will hike interest rates by 50 basis points toward the end of the first quarter."

IG Metall's pay claim is traditionally used as benchmark for the rest of German industry. ECB officials have warned that excessive pay rises could stoke inflation, already on the rise as a result of oil price increases and recent weakness in the euro.

Werner Stumpfe, president of Gesamtmetall, the German engineering employers' federation, said he expected a major dispute with IG Metall over the claim.

£400m facelift for Tube station
Railtrack yesterday announced a £400m plan to transform London Bridge station, the oldest in the capital and built in 1836, into an integrated transport hub designed to benefit the 75,000 passengers who use the station everyday. The scheme, to be completed from 2002 to 2006, will provide for an increase in passenger numbers from 27m to 38m a year expected over the next 10 years.

Michelin to cut 473 jobs in Stoke
French tyre-maker Michelin said yesterday it needed to cut 473 jobs to secure the long-term future of its plant at Stoke-on-Trent in Britain.

Michelin said the cuts would primarily affect the car tyre and tyre component production workshops. The plant, which employs 2,700 people, will receive an £11m investment to update its buildings and equipment.

More firms go broke in 1999
Company insolvencies jumped nearly 7% last year, despite the strong economic upturn, with London and the south-east showing particularly large increases, figures showed yesterday. A total of 1,480 receivership and administration orders were made during the year, compared with 1,384 in 1998.

The worst-hit sectors were manufacturing - where insolvencies went from 444 in 1998 to 496 last year - and so-called "other services" - including education, hairdressing, medical practice, sanitation and dry cleaning - where the total rose from 164 to 214.

Exhausted fund manager rests
The fund manager of Jupiter's top-rated Income unit trust, William Littlewood, yesterday shocked investors by stepping aside from day-to-day control of the £1.5bn fund. Mr Littlewood, 32, who has managed the fund since 1991 and is believed to be in line for a £10m bonus, says he is suffering from exhaustion.

webTitle: Newcastle Utd turns to headhunters for salvation

fields.headline: Newcastle Utd turns to headhunters for salvation
fields.trailText: Newcastle United yesterday launched an attempt to restore its battered reputation with plans for a series of new appointments to improve relations with both its supporters and its shareholders.
fields.body:
Newcastle United yesterday launched an attempt to restore its battered reputation with plans for a series of new appointments to improve relations with both its supporters and its shareholders.

Headhunters have been hired to find two independent directors and a managing director. The club intends to hire a communications supremo and a new executive to nurture the club's deteriorating relationship with its supporters - and has started contract negotiations to keep former England manager Bobby Robson at St James's Park.

A new "director of football" will also be appointed.

The club's image has been tarnished time and again since it floated in 1997, and its shares have come to be seen as only for the brave, the foolhardy or the most committed of fans.

City investors are rarely keen on companies where family shareholders retain control, and their worst fears about Newcastle were confirmed when Douglas Hall - who then spoke for 57% of the club - and 7% owner Freddy Shepherd were exposed by a Sunday newspaper bragging about how they "ripped off" supporters. They were pushed off the board but forced their way back in within months.

Meanwhile, Newcastle had worked its way through almost an entire squad of board directors and is now on its third chairman - and third team manager - in as many years. The shares, which came to the market in May 1997 at 140p, are presently languishing at just 71.5p.

The club's relationship with its fans has deteriorated further recently after a controversy over season ticket bondholders having their allocated seats withdrawn as a result of the redevelopment of the St James' Park stadium.

Legal action over the seating problem is continuing, but yesterday the club offered bondholders free cup tie tickets for a period of up to three years in an attempt to resolve the impasse.

The football club said that it also intends to establish an independently elected supporters' liaison committee in order to avoid any similar problems in the future.

fields.headline: Poetry, please
fields.standfirst: Back on terra firma,  Simon Reade, literary manager of the RSC, says there's still plenty of life in more traditional theatre
fields.trailText: Back on terra firma, Simon Reade, literary manager of the RSC, says there's still plenty of life in more traditional theatre
fields.body:
For the past few weeks, newspapers have been declaring 1999 a duff year in an otherwise great decade for new playwriting. Last week, Lyn Gardner asked if there was a crisis. Even the suggestion, I think, is short-sighted. We're guilty of misrepresenting what good writing was throughout the 90s, and this has blurred our judgment at their end.

We've got theatre companies dedicated exclusively to the production of new work: the Bush, the Traverse, Out of Joint, Paines Plough. There may be delays in the re-opening of the Royal Court in London, but the Manchester Royal Exchange and Birmingham Rep continue to produce new plays. The National may have had a few unfortunate experiences, but that's no reason to under-rate the popular Battle Royal. The Royal Shakespeare Company, for which I work, is sometimes criticised for not putting its big new plays on to its biggest stages - but think about the pragmatics of planning a largely classical repertoire, and you'll understand why we mainly perform Shakespeare in our huge auditoria, while deploying living writers right across all our venues. If there is going to be a crisis in new playwriting, then it will be caused by a lack of perspective.

As well as misreading the circumstances, I think we have a distorted view of what constituted successful new playwriting in the 90s. We tend to agree unthinkingly when we're told that the 90s was about sex and violence, shopping and fucking. When Sarah Kane's Blasted opened, it didn't matter that relatively few got to see it during its limited run at the Theatre Upstairs - its succès de scandale was welcomed with glee. Theatre was controversial, on the news-stands, fashionable, young - "nihilistic urban chic", the critic John Lahr dubbed it. In my view, however, this important yet narrow strand has not only clouded our overall view of British playwriting in the 90s, but is itself misrepresented.

At Kane's memorial service last summer, Harold Pinter concluded his address with the highest praise for a playwright: "She was a poet." The fact that Kane's and her contemporaries' work is chiefly remembered for its loud-mouthed aggression may have something to do with a wider, tabloid-titillating movement in the visual arts.

For many, self-loathing among the young British creative community defined the 90s. Mutilated paedophiliac fantasies, self-portraits made from greasy fried-egg breasts and rancid kebab vaginas - the Royal Academy called its retrospective of these Hackney horrors Sensation! However honest the intention of the artist, here was a commercial collection appropriated by the Establishment to shock effect. So when a play like Patrick Marber's brilliant Closer came along, it was seized upon as further evidence of solipsistic 90s nihilism. The seminal scene of viciously lonely sex-talk on the internet was crassly taken by some to epitomise a zeitgeist. At the same time, the works of other young male writers, such as Nick Grosso and Joe Penhall, were being marketed for the testosterone-fuelled lad-mags.

The glossy print has left a nasty smear. Now we're in danger of overlooking the sensitivity of the work we praised at the time - remember Billy Roche's Wexford Trilogy, remember The Herbal Bed? - and that should characterise the 90s. The most important perspective to have is of the humanity of the playwrights, the civilising force of their language, the poetic sensibility of those plays.

Marber's first play, the painfully funny Dealer's Choice, shows a sensitive yearning for father-son relationships precisely because of its Mametesque, gambling-table machismo. There were also the life-enhancing gay plays: the emotionally uplifting Beautiful Thing; Kevin Elyot's exquisitely structured, deeply moving My Night With Reg. At the same time, British playwrights rediscovered experimental theatre: Martin Crimp's deft Attempts on Her Life; Caryl Churchill's mischievous Blue Heart. Other senior playwrights continued to plough their own politically motivated, intellectually astute furrows - Wertenbaker, Edgar, Hare, Stoppard, Pinter - all passionate, poetic, consummate.

As ever, British theatre was also sustained by the Irish, from that great lyrical tradition: Sebastian Barry's symphonic poems to his ancestors; Conor McPherson's wonderful yarn spinning; Marina Carr's extraordinary women; Daragh Carville's exciting Belfast play Language Roulette. You could also look to Scotland for theatre poets: David Harrower's fine plays, or David Greig, whose large-scale new play Victoria opens at the Pit Theatre in April. In England, we're blessed by poetic voices arriving from abroad, such as Nigeria's Biyi Bandele (his verse reinvention of Aphra Behn's Restoration novella Oroonoko, currently at the Pit Theatre, is a marvel) and New York's Phyllis Nagy, and by other women's witty voices such as April de Angelis or Moira Buffini.

The new wave was a fierce wave, sure, but in a vaster, calmer ocean of poetic new writing. Too modest ever to be fashionable, too subtle ever to be headline-grabbing, this is the ongoing success story of British playwriting. Plays that do more than momentarily impress may not always win prizes, but they will endure.
