fields.headline: Love is in the air
fields.standfirst: First there was De La Guarda, then the Dome spectaculars, and now the beautiful Deadly. Suddenly the hottest shows are high above the ground, says  Lyn Gardner
fields.trailText: First there was De La Guarda, then the Dome spectaculars, and now the beautiful Deadly. Suddenly the hottest shows are high above the ground, says Lyn Gardner
fields.body:
A man and a woman stand back to back. The light shining on their heads gives a halo effect, but these are no angels. The woman licks the man's hand and, in turn, he tries to bite hers. Soon they are gobbling each other up, rolling fully clothed on the floor, consuming each other. You have never seen anything so erotic and so greedy - they cannot get enough of each other. Suddenly they both sit up and burp like two kids pigged out on cake.

This is the start of Deadly, a 60-minute piece of almost wordless physical theatre played out to a range of music that moves from classical to techno, as it whizzes through the seven deadly sins within the framework of a volatile, sometimes abusive relationship. The audience witnesses the highs and lows - literally - as Deborah Pope and Rodrigo Matheus swing through the air in ecstasy, their sometimes almost naked, muscular bodies entwined. At other times they trample upon each other in utter contempt. The two dancers combine the skill of aerialists with the expressiveness of actors.

Deadly is a rare and perfect union between circus and narrative, and after wowing audiences in Edinburgh last summer it arrives in London this week as part of the London International Mime Festival. It is perfect timing, just when the opening performance at the Dome has made audiences aware of aerial work. It is suddenly the art form of the moment.

Deborah Pope, a New Zealander, arrived in London as a medical student 20 years ago. She enrolled in an acrobatics workshop for fun, later learning most of her circus skills from ex-vaudeville star Eugene Balla, who at 89 is still teaching circus hopefuls in his Brixton living room. Pope was responsible for training the aerialists for the Dome, and believes that audiences can't fail to fall for their performances.

"There is something very sexy about aerial work," she says. "The air is omnipotent and anyone who can fly is powerful and dangerous. The moment you put a performance in the air you raise the stakes. Then, of course, there are all those muscled, androgynous bodies that are so fashionable at the moment."

Part of the appeal of Deadly is its mixture of confidence and eroticism. The way that Pope and Matheus interact with one another, their bodies almost becoming one, is enormously sensual, as is the way that the safety of each is so entirely dependent on the strength and skill of the other. In fact, the whole piece is startlingly beautiful: at one point shafts of golden glitter fall from the air and smother Pope's body in a kind of benediction.

But there is also something disturbing about the piece. It gets pretty near to the heart of the balance of power that exists in every relationship, and it explores how, in some relationships, particularly passionate sexual ones, love and hate can co-exist. The couple in Deadly remind you of Adam and Eve, but the apple here is rotten to the core.

Beyond the surface eroticism, something deeply painful is taking place. There is a troubling sadism in the way these two hurt each other - particularly in the way he hurts her. Unsurprisingly, some women who have experienced abusive relationships have found Deadly almost unbearable to watch.

Pope believes the piece "makes a bigger statement by making no statement", instead depicting the relationship as a never-ending circle. But Pope thinks this is wishful thinking and that Britain still has a lot of catching up to do in the field of aerial entertainment.

But the profile is changing and I think what we seeing at the Dome is a response to that."

fields.headline: Back to the Factory
fields.standfirst: Tony Wilson, the loud Mancunian behind Factory Records and the Hacienda club, once again has plenty to shout about, he tells  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Tony Wilson, the loud Mancunian behind Factory Records and the Hacienda club, once again has plenty to shout about, he tells Dave Simpson
fields.body:
When George Carman QC walked into Manchester's Hacienda in 1991 to sort out the famous club's image problem (a small matter of drugs and gangs) his advice was simple: "Gentlemen, shut that loudmouth up!"

The loudmouth was and is Tony Wilson. "Greater Manchester police had correctly identified me as the Timothy Leary of Ecstasy," sighs Wilson, practising his best "Who, me?" shrug. For anyone in the Manchester area, Wilson is that silly-suited man who pops up on the telly as a Granada TV presenter. But for most of us he will always be the face, suit and mouth behind Factory Records. Wilson brought the world three of the 30 or so major acts in pop history. Joy Division, New Order and Happy Mondays were a pop triple-whammy once compared to "winning the pools three times. Twice is a miracle, three times you call in the fraud squad."

Now he's trying for number four. Wilson has a new arts/pop/interview series called Content; more intriguingly, he is also planning to revive his record label. His re-emergence coincides with his theory that the UK is on the brink of another major pop revolution. This, he says, happens once every 13 years and he knows the next one is around the corner because "Top of the Pops looks like 1974 again, like it did in 1988.

"Sixty-three was the Beatles," he expands. "Seventy-six the Sex Pistols. 1989 Happy Mondays and the Stone Roses. I never realised until recently that if you go back even further, that's 1950, the dawn of the teddy boy," he smiles. There's a twinkle in his eye that says, "I am very clever." Then he actually says it. "I am very clever."

If Tony Wilson hadn't been such a clever so-and-so the entire course of British pop might not have been the same. A young Mancunian might never have gone up to him in 1977 and said "You bastard! You put the Sex Pistols on the telly - what about us?" Wilson was presenting a weekly arts programme then, So It Goes. The young man was Ian Curtis, and his band were Joy Division. Wilson used his savings to finance Joy Division's seminal debut album, Unknown Pleasures. From a tiny apartment in Didsbury, Manchester, Factory's bands changed the way pop sounded, while his label transformed the way it was sold.

Wilson was a Cambridge-educated trade unionist and keen Situationist. His initial - then revolutionary - philosophy was that a record company could actually be geared to serve the people that recorded for it. Thus, Wilson pioneered the now indie-standard 50/50 profits split between label and artists, and the far more bold (and certainly not copied) "non-contract contact", which gave the workers ownership of their own products. "That document that states 'We own nothing. The musicians own everything' in the end made Factory bankrupt, and resulted in my entire catalogue being owned by somebody else," says Wilson now. "But I can't regret it, because the idea was not to own the past but to present the future."

Wilson's equally crucial vision was that "the pop record was sacred, so why not make it beautiful?" Crafted by then unknown designer Peter Savile, Factory records boasted better-looking record sleeves than the wealthiest labels in the world. Factory refused to cheapen their immaculate products by conventional marketing, in the naive - but astonishingly successful - belief that "If the record's good, it sells."

Still, when Wilson finally used a radio plugger for New Order's 1983 Blue Monday, the result was the biggest-selling 12-inch of all time.

For over a decade, Factory's aesthetic, sense of mischief and bands ("lesser" Factory groups included early OMD and James) dominated British youth culture, culminating in the Hacienda club, home of UK house music. And then it all went wrong. The UK's first Ecstasy death in Wilson's club gave his Learyesque proselytising a nasty aftertaste. Factory made millions by being pranksters, but spent it quickly: a reported £250,000 on an album by New Order bass player Peter Hook ("It was £350,000"); a borrowed £700,000 on a Ben Kelly-designed super-building, its value wiped out by the property crash as loan rates soared. Wilson laughs about what he calls the edifice complex - "you make money, you build a new office, and you go bankrupt" - but that's effectively what happened.

"Although Factory was always a precarious pile of shite, everything had to go wrong," he sighs. "Happy Mondays had to discover crack cocaine in Barbados! New Order's album had to be two years late! Claire Leighton had to die, of a tablet bought in Stockport, but in the Hacienda! There had to be an international property collapse! Do you want me to go on?"

Factory went bankrupt on November 23, 1992. Since then, Wilson has been something of a lost soul. He struck a rescue deal with a major label, London Records, but the non-contract contract cut him off from his own bands. Both New Order and Happy Mondays now record for London. Wilson gets uncharacteristically emotional when talking about this - like a father who's lost his children - but insists he wouldn't change a thing.

Wilson's Content series restores him to his favoured role as an arbiter of taste. He gets to choose all the new bands and his heroes (Malcolm McLaren, Marianne Faithfull, Irvine Welsh) appear on the shows but equally important, the new lease of life has re-ignited his sense of mischief. Now he's planning revenge. For the past few months, Wilson has been looking into MP3 (internet-based music retail) with partners based in Manchester. Like Creation's Alan McGee, Wilson is convinced that by being a trailblazer in the new technology, independents can again beat the majors at selling music, but Wilson believes he can do it more cheaply than any of them. A Factory offshoot at www.Music33.com will remove 70% of the costs of selling music. According to Wilson, online retail will triple sales of music and benefit public and artists alike.

He says the public are tired of trawling around record shops to find albums "like the Verve's, who have three good tracks and they're all the singles anyway," and plans to sell individual songs, without B-sides. He claims he will undercut other operators by as much as 30p a tune, meaning "these shits charging 99p and then saying to the artists 'You can have so much per cent' can go screw themselves."

According to Wilson, MP3 is the way people will buy music in the future, but unlike McGee, he is under no illusion that MP3 will mean the end of record companies. So, Factory will also resume operating as a record company.

Typically, Wilson has had T-shirts printed with the words "Alan, you're up your arse". "McGee has some very good ideas but he's completely wrong on this," says Wilson. "It's like [Warner Brothers'] Rob Dickens said to me, 'MP3? It's just distribution. I've owned half a dozen warehouses in my life. Never visited one of them. Think they'll get rid of record companies? You know what the public wanna buy. They wanna buy songs. Guess who owns them. We do.' He's completely right." Unless, that is, the record company is Wilson's. But can the man who gave us those wonderful records all that time ago rediscover his Midas touch? Wilson stares me in the face and recalls a band whose tape he was particularly fond of playing in his car. They were perfect for Factory, all surly stares, damaged psyche and raging anthems. Sadly, Factory was going bankrupt and Wilson couldn't sign them. The band was Oasis.

"That was the summer of '92," he states, defiantly. "Alan [McGee] didn't see them until spring '93. So, personally, I never missed a single thing in my life."

 Content is on ITV on Wednesdays at 11.30pm.

Ten reasons to honour Factory Records (and the label's official catalogue numbers)

2 Technique by New Order (FACT 275)

3 "Lesser" Factory act A Certain Ratio, who influenced Talking Heads and Madonna

4 Menstrual egg timer (FAC 8)

5 New Order manager Rob Gretton's dental work (FAC 99)

6 LC by The Durutti Column (FACT 44)

7 WFL by Happy Mondays (FAC 232)

8 The Manchester bar Dry (FAC 201)

9 The Hacienda (FAC 51)

10 The Hacienda cat (FAC 191)

fields.headline: Waiting for weapons
fields.trailText: Taxpayers and MPs need only read the annual reports on major defence projects by the national audit office, and persistent criticisms by the Commons public accounts committee, to see that inefficiency, delays, and serious cost overruns in the MoD's multibillion pound procurement programme are systemic.
fields.body:
Taxpayers and MPs need only read the annual reports on major defence projects by the national audit office, and persistent criticisms by the Commons public accounts committee, to see that inefficiency, delays, and serious cost overruns in the MoD's multibillion pound procurement programme are systemic.

Not a year goes by without the audit office chastising the ministry for mismanaging its equipment budget. Equipment for all three services - guns, tanks, ships, aircraft, computer systems - has been subjected to expensive delays and, when delivered, is frequently inadequate. Cost overruns on 25 large defence projects now total over £3bn, reflecting a rising trend.

The MoD has not pursued its rights to £38m in potential damages from Vickers, makers of the Challenger 2 tank which was delivered more than two years late. The ministry had taken more than seven years to decide whether or not to order the tank, whose mechanical defects were highlighted during the 1991 Gulf war.

The army complained about its then brand-new SA 80 standard rifle, saying it was prone to jamming. In reports drawn up after the Kosovo conflict, army commanders described their rifles as "unreliable" and "insufficiently robust".

The audit office last year reported that major weapons systems were expected to cost £2.8bn more than originally forecast, and would enter service on average three-and-a-half years later than originally estimated. It added: "There is no sign of the trend in the department's performance stabilising or improving."

The office singled out plans for an air-launched antitank weapon (AAW) and a conventionally armed stand-off missile, both of which were first drawn up 16 years ago. The antitank weapon, called Brimstone, has been dogged by technical problems, design changes and delays when the MoD reviewed the need for it after the end of the cold war. This "smart bomb" would have enabled the RAF to carry out more effective bombing missions during the Kosovo conflict.

The stand-off missile has been delayed by disagreements between countries which originally supported the project. International projects delayed through technical problems include the Trigat antitank missile bought by Britain, France, and Germany. Other projects hit by cost overruns include the Eurofighter, and the Merlin maritime helicopter.

Past attempts at international collaboration do not augur well for plans for closer EU defence cooperation: but British decisions to go it alone - for example, on a standard gun for the army - have led to costly problems.

The public accounts committee also describe the way a computer system for the defence intelligence staff was abandoned without being used at a cost of £40m. The system, called Trawlerman, would have become rapidly obsolete even if delivered on time. It added that even if the computer had not been abandoned, the security specification was so high that there was probably nothing that could fulfil it, even now.

"Technology had moved on in terms of the end of the cold war, and there were different requirements for intelligence gathering," MoD officials said. The project was over-ambitious and the MoD relied too much on what industry said it could deliver. The recent history of British military procurement has been one of confused ambitions compounded by lack of oversight.

webTitle: White gets call-up from old guard

fields.headline: White gets call-up from old guard
fields.trailText: England abandoned all pretence that they intend immediately to arrest their decline by embarking on an obsessive push for youth, when the Yorkshire all-rounder Craig White was named yesterday to replace the injured Andrew Flintoff for the one-day series against South Africa.
fields.body:
England abandoned all pretence that they intend immediately to arrest their decline by embarking on an obsessive push for youth, when the Yorkshire all-rounder Craig White was named yesterday to replace the injured Andrew Flintoff for the one-day series against South Africa.

White, 30, the possessor of a modest international record and ignored for two years, is the sort of tried and untrusted player that many populists demanded must be forever banished after England's plunge to the bottom of the Test rankings last summer. But the coach Duncan Fletcher and the captain Nasser Hussain have persistently indicated in the past month that they are set upon evolution not revolution.

First there was Mark Ramprakash, called up as cover for the Cape Town Test when many wanted Worcestershire's young batsman Vikram Solanki to be rewarded for his success on the A tour in Bangladesh and New Zealand. Then Graeme Hick was asked to captain England on the conventional basis of seniority when Michael Vaughan, billed by some as a potential future England captain, might have relished the experience.

Now England have turned to White, with Fletcher's reign as England coach showing such an affinity towards Yorkshiremen that Raymond Illingworth, observing from his Spanish villa, might wonder whether his own devotion was too discreet. White is the fifth Yorkshire player called up by England this winter.

"We considered a number of possible alternatives, ranging from players who had performed well on the A tour to those still in South Africa," explained David Graveney, the chairman of selectors.

"Craig was our final choice because he had a good season for Yorkshire in one-day cricket last summer. He has been bowling well for Central Districts in New Zealand and also has experience of South African conditions."

That experience came in a hectic series in South Africa three years ago when he played seven of his 15 England one-day matches, all overseas. His record is modest - 187 runs at 14.38 and 15 wickets at 29.67 - but his potential has never been fully realised and a new management team cannot entirely be blamed for believing they can unlock it.

White's bowling will more than compensate for that of Flintoff, whose elephantine fast-medium has been overhyped and whose fractured left foot in the innings defeat in Cape Town, following quickly on his long-standing back ailment, was a predictable end to the tour for a talented batsman with a limited enthusiasm for bowling.

webTitle: Life after Lara might be a poor option

fields.headline: Life after Lara might be a poor option
fields.standfirst: Where does a team turn after a 7-0 whitewash by New Zealand?
fields.trailText: There are some phenomena too immense in scope for the human imagination: the first sight of the Grand Canyon, the smile of a new-born baby, and seven successive defeats by New Zealand's cricket team. If, this morning, most West Indians feel like hurling their first born into the Grand Canyon and jumping in after them, the cricket world will be full of admiration for their restraint.
fields.byline: BC Pires  in Port of Spain
fields.body:
There are some phenomena too immense in scope for the human imagination: the first sight of the Grand Canyon, the smile of a new-born baby, and seven successive defeats by New Zealand's cricket team. If, this morning, most West Indians feel like hurling their first born into the Grand Canyon and jumping in after them, the cricket world will be full of admiration for their restraint.

The feeling in the cricket-playing Caribbean - if that is not now an oxymoron, to be replaced by the cricket-mucking-about Caribbean - is one of abject helplessness. No one has any idea what to do. No amount of spin doctoring can help because you cannot put spin on a monolith. Nor can doctoring help because no one can make a reliable prognosis since no one can make an accurate diagnosis. Everyone is struggling simply to comprehend the symptoms: a whitewash by New Zealand? And by a New Zealand team of Chris Cairns and 10 robots?

If the West Indies Cricket Board saw fit to reduce Brian Lara's captaincy to a probationary two-game appointment after a much less disastrous showing against much tougher opposition in South Africa in 1998, it must now be looking for a way to take back the captaincy with retroactive effect. Many West Indians would be happy to see someone, anyone, given a beating like a Good Friday bobolee - Trinidad's equivalent of a Guy Fawkes guy.

There have been widespread public calls for Lara's sacking. On the day New Zealand won the third game and the one-day series, 46% of callers in a television station's phone-in survey in his native Trinidad said he should not continue. The analytical powers of the callers can be assessed when you consider that, next morning, nearly 90% of callers to the same station declared that what the team needed most was more prayer on their behalf; though it would not be inaccurate to observe that the team obviously hadn't a prayer beforehand.

A less emotional appraisal reveals something that most cricket writers in the region agree upon: that Lara is either the best or the only candidate for the post, on the assumption that he is still willing to carry the cross of responsibility. Courtney Walsh, until the one-day series a serious contender, at least as an interim captain against Zimbabwe and Pakistan, appears not only to have aged on this tour but to have slowed; Kapil Dev's record of 434 Test wickets may still elude him. Jimmy Adams cannot be sure of making the team, far less leading it in the short, medium or long term. Shivnarine Chanderpaul is almost certain to be dropped. Sherwin Campbell, who has captained Barbados and the West Indies A team, could not yet step into such large shoes. Carl Hooper has shot himself in both feet so effectively as to be incapable of stepping up to the crease, far less performing fancy footwork.

A greater horror lurks for West Indies cricket, though: Lara may no longer want the damned thing. He has looked increasingly depressed after each game and people close to him speculate that he may resign the captaincy or even retire from cricket in the next few days.

To finish off with a flurry of metaphors - the way a one-day team would finish off the overs with a flurry of boundaries, a principle inverted by West Indies who now begin their batting overs with a flurry of wickets - the Golden Boy must now understand the dark side of the Midas touch and move from the middle to the sidelines. If the Prince of Port of Spain puts aside his sceptre, however, it is not he, but West Indies cricket, which will become a pauper.

webTitle: Hick pursues dead duck into dead end

fields.headline: Hick pursues dead duck into dead end
fields.trailText: Tour match This game always promised to be a dead duck and it lived up to expectations yesterday by ending in a draw. As preparation for the final Test, starting at Centurion on Friday, it was a waste of space.
fields.body:
This game always promised to be a dead duck and, as it ran its course for three days, it lived up to expectations. As an exercise in giving the newly arrived one-day tourists a run-around in the sun, it succeeded admirably; better, said Graeme Hick, than days of nets. As preparation for the final Test, starting at Centurion on Friday, it was a waste of space.

Michael Vaughan, Darren Maddy, Gavin Hamilton and Alan Mullally might as well have joined the rest of the Test side on the beach or golf course. Only Alex Tudor, who found some proper pace yesterday, had anything of substance to show for the exercise but the probable need to play a spinner in Pretoria while bolstering the batting means his chances of a recall are slim.

As a contest England got the match they deserved, with Hick, as captain, demonstrating a lack of ambition worthy of Hansie Cronje at his most dour. The chance was there, once the Invitation XI captain Neil McKenzie had declared the first innings at 253 for seven half an hour before the close on the first day. But to make a game, despite the need for practice, both captains must contribute.

Hick may have taken the view that a declaration in McKenzie's position, with his side heading for a low total, was a ploy merely to ensure he was not batted right out of the game, and therefore that should be England's aim. More likely, though, was a genuine desire on the part of the home side to enjoy the match.

"It is very difficult to get a result in three days," said McKenzie, "and, when I declared, I thought England might follow suit at tea, by which time most of the main batsmen had had a hit." England at that stage were 242 for five. "If they had declared I'd have set them a nice total to chase," he continued. "But they killed the game by batting on."

England's reluctance to do anything other than serve their own needs - and it is doubtful whether they achieved even that - brought a wimpish concession to the light on the second evening and a continuation of the innings for the first 45 minutes yesterday, when they lost their last three wickets, all to the left-arm pace bowler Greg Smith, for the addition of only 19 runs.

During that time the pace bowlers were helped by the pitch, juiced up by a little overnight rain, and cloud cover. In not declaring overnight, an opportunity was missed to make inroads into the Invitation side's second innings.

What England got instead was a day in the field. Tudor did knock the top off the innings with two early wickets to go with one for Mullally, as well as sending James Bryant to hospital by striking him on the left arm. But by then the sun had returned and a fourth-wicket stand of 114 ensued between McKenzie and Justin Ontong, ending only when the captain was bowled by Vaughan's off-spin for 80. Ontong followed in the next over for 34 and Wendell Bossenger three overs later right on the tea interval.

With the home side's lead only 63 at that stage, England still nursed hopes of saving face by squeezing a win. But they failed to take another wicket, the draw was conceded with Roger Telemachus's half-century - his unbroken seventh-wicket partnership with Smith worth 82 - and a match to forget was forgotten.

 England began their Under-19 World Cup defence with an eight-wicket win over the Americas in Colombo. The Americas, composed of players from the US, Bermuda, Canada and Argentina, made 105 in 33.1 overs and England were never in trouble after an opening stand of 68 between Warwickshire's Ian Bell, first out for 41, and Surrey's Michael Carberry. England next play West Indies tomorrow.

webTitle: Lib Dems reveal unease over Kennedy

fields.headline: Lib Dems reveal unease over Kennedy
fields.standfirst: Leader's warning that Lib-Lab links may have to be severed infuriates senior colleagues and activists as doubts grow over his performance
fields.trailText: Paddy Ashdown's closest ally at Westminster yesterday set himself at odds with Charles Kennedy, lifting the lid on a simmering row among senior Liberal Democrats over the performance of the party's new leader. Days after Mr Kennedy threatened to pull the plug on his links with Labour, the party's foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, insisted that Lib-Lab discusssions should be maintained.
fields.body:
Paddy Ashdown's closest ally at Westminster yesterday set himself at odds with Charles Kennedy, lifting the lid on a simmering row among senior Liberal Democrats over the performance of the party's new leader. Days after Mr Kennedy threatened to pull the plug on his links with Labour, the party's foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, insisted that Lib-Lab discusssions should be maintained.

The Lib Dem leader infuriated supporters of Mr Ashdown over the weekend when he warned that there would be no "concrete grounds for further co-operation" if Tony Blair reneges on his commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform. Mr Campbell responded yesterday by calling on Mr Kennedy to maintain the links with Labour regardless of whether the prime minister lives up to his commitment to hold a referendum.

The senior Lib Dem politician spoke out after a poll for the Today programme found that a majority of the party's constituency chairmen want Mr Kennedy to maintain the links with Labour even if Mr Blair breaks his referendum pledge. In the poll of constituency chairs in Lib Dem-held seats and targets seats, 37 called for the links to continue, while 30 called for them to end.

Mr Campbell said that the poll vindicated his view that the party was overwhelmingly in favour of Lib-Lab links. "I am not surprised by the result of this opinion poll," Mr Campbell said. "As you go round the country you get a very strong feeling among many of our activists that, so long as co-operation does not involve abandoning Liberal Democrat beliefs, it is worthwhile."

His remarks contrasted with Mr Kennedy who dismissed the poll as a "hypothetical situation".

"If Labour breaks its manifesto pledge co-operation will be very difficult," Mr Kennedy's spokeswoman said. "But we do not believe they will break their pledge."

Mr Campbell was careful not to criticise Mr Kennedy. However, their different responses to the BBC poll highlighted the tensions between Mr Kennedy's friends and supporters of Mr Ashdown who believe the party's new leader is squandering his legacy.

Don Foster, another Lib Dem frontbencher, admitted that Mr Kennedy had yet to make his mark. Saying that he would give Mr Kennedy another six months before making a final judgment on his performance, Mr Foster added: "Anyone expecting an instantaneous miracle, with Charles hitting the stage with great fanfare, is crazy."

Supporters of Mr Ashdown - the former party leader remains studiously silent - believe that Mr Kennedy should embrace the links with Labour more enthusiastically. One well-placed Lib Dem said: "Charles is finding it difficult because he is still in the groove of his leadership campaign in which he had to distance himself from Ashdown. He now has to find a way out - but who knows whether he wants to?"

Mr Kennedy's supporters insist that he cannot slavishly follow Mr Ashdown's strategy of "constructive opposition" because the next general election will be completely different to 1997.

At the last general election, the Kennedy camp argues, Labour and the Lib Dems were seen by voters to be on the same side of the fence taking on a deeply unpopular Tory government. Next time round the Lib Dems hope to win votes from Labour voters dis illusioned with the government's performance and Tory voters angry at William Hague's lurch to the right.

But one senior Lib Dem said that Mr Kennedy could face a catastrophic result if he tries to reach both ways. Any lurch to the left could frighten Tory voters whose support was instrumental in the Lib Dems' success in 1997. Equally, leftwing attacks on the government would win barely any Labour seats.

"There is only one game in town," one source said. "We should hold on to as many seats as possible and use our strong presence in the Commons to influence a smaller Labour majority. In a third Labour term, with Blair's majority cut even more, we should look towards greater co-operation, possibly including a coalition."

fields.headline: Jobless forced to take lessons
fields.standfirst: Compulsory dress code and tests for jobseekers
fields.trailText: Unemployed people facing job interviews will be forced to take lessons on how to present themselves under an overhaul of the government's flagship New Deal employment programme.
fields.body:
Unemployed people facing job interviews will be forced to take lessons on how to present themselves under an overhaul of the government's flagship New Deal employment programme.

A strict dress code will be introduced, with special funds available to help applicants buy suits to impress potential employers. Smart clothing will also be available on loan.

The measures were unveiled yesterday as part of a clampdown on a hard core of the long-term unemployed who refuse work or who lack any of the basic skills that are demanded by companies.

Job seekers who decline to take the lessons will have their £40 a week benefit stopped for 14 days, rising to a month if they continue to turn down a place, employment minister Tessa Jowell said.

Revealing a 10-point plan, including literacy and numeracy tests, self-presentation lessons, and job coaches, she said a significant number of people were still held back by a poor education.

Appalled by figures which showed that 40% of young people on the ground-breaking programme lacked basic skills, ministers have decided that every person taking part will be screened for learning problems.

But they will also be told to dress more snappily. "First impressions count and the standard dress for interviews is a suit for men and something equally smart for women," a spokesman at the employment department said. "We will make funds available for people who have no smart clothes, although it might be possible to get them on loan."

The overhaul, on the second anniversary of the scheme, follows complaints from employers that a lack of basic skills, and a negative attitude in job interviews, are holding job seekers back.

Special "outreach" programmes will also be developed to help people in areas of high unemployment, deprived neighbourhoods and from ethnic minorities.

Mrs Jowell said the New Deal had helped almost 170,000 people from long-term unemployment into work. But there were still significant numbers on the programme whose lack of basic skills was preventing them finding a job.

"Four out of 10 people cannot even read instructions on a medicine bottle ... helping them is part of the plan to build on the progress of New Deal," she said.

The employment department acknowledged it was dealing with people with serious skill shortages, some of whom "cannot read or write ... they will need a lot of help before they even start applying for jobs."

One criticism of the programme is that many of those placed in employment would have found jobs anyway. As a result, critics said, the New Deal had failed to help the most disadvantaged.

Paul Convery, director of the independent Unemployment Unit, said that while the programme had been largely successful, it had failed to put 40% of participants into lasting jobs.

"As unemployment is falling, you are ending up not with an easier target but with a tougher challenge: the people now left unemployed are the harder to get into work," he said.

Mrs Jowell, who presented people from 12 New Deal pilot areas to the prime minister, said some young people had gone from unemployment to management in less than two years and been placed on a "ladder of opportunity".

One of those meeting ministers was Daniel Roper, who joined a printing company at Newquay, Cornwall, two years ago, aged 19, after being unemployed for a year. He now manages one of the firm's three shops. John Jay, his employer, immediately bought him smart business clothes.

"Appearances count a lot," said John's wife, Chrissie, who helps run the business, which has taken on two more New Dealers. "He's a very dependable lad. We've been very fortunate."
fields.bodyText: Unemployed people facing job interviews will be forced to take lessons on how to present themselves under an overhaul of the government's flagship New Deal employment programme. A strict dress code will be introduced, with special funds available to help applicants buy suits to impress potential employers. Smart clothing will also be available on loan. The measures were unveiled yesterday as part of a clampdown on a hard core of the long-term unemployed who refuse work or who lack any of the basic skills that are demanded by companies. Job seekers who decline to take the lessons will have their £40 a week benefit stopped for 14 days, rising to a month if they continue to turn down a place, employment minister Tessa Jowell said. Revealing a 10-point plan, including literacy and numeracy tests, self-presentation lessons, and job coaches, she said a significant number of people were still held back by a poor education. Appalled by figures which showed that 40% of young people on the ground-breaking programme lacked basic skills, ministers have decided that every person taking part will be screened for learning problems. But they will also be told to dress more snappily. "First impressions count and the standard dress for interviews is a suit for men and something equally smart for women," a spokesman at the employment department said. "We will make funds available for people who have no smart clothes, although it might be possible to get them on loan." The overhaul, on the second anniversary of the scheme, follows complaints from employers that a lack of basic skills, and a negative attitude in job interviews, are holding job seekers back. Special "outreach" programmes will also be developed to help people in areas of high unemployment, deprived neighbourhoods and from ethnic minorities. Mrs Jowell said the New Deal had helped almost 170,000 people from long-term unemployment into work. But there were still significant numbers on the programme whose lack of basic skills was preventing them finding a job. "Four out of 10 people cannot even read instructions on a medicine bottle ... helping them is part of the plan to build on the progress of New Deal," she said. The employment department acknowledged it was dealing with people with serious skill shortages, some of whom "cannot read or write ... they will need a lot of help before they even start applying for jobs." One criticism of the programme is that many of those placed in employment would have found jobs anyway. As a result, critics said, the New Deal had failed to help the most disadvantaged. Paul Convery, director of the independent Unemployment Unit, said that while the programme had been largely successful, it had failed to put 40% of participants into lasting jobs. "As unemployment is falling, you are ending up not with an easier target but with a tougher challenge: the people now left unemployed are the harder to get into work," he said. Mrs Jowell, who presented people from 12 New Deal pilot areas to the prime minister, said some young people had gone from unemployment to management in less than two years and been placed on a "ladder of opportunity". One of those meeting ministers was Daniel Roper, who joined a printing company at Newquay, Cornwall, two years ago, aged 19, after being unemployed for a year. He now manages one of the firm's three shops. John Jay, his employer, immediately bought him smart business clothes. "Appearances count a lot," said John's wife, Chrissie, who helps run the business, which has taken on two more New Dealers. "He's a very dependable lad. We've been very fortunate."

fields.headline: Performers for the 21st century
fields.standfirst:
PLG Young Artists
Purcell Room, London
Rating: ****/***
fields.trailText: The Park Lane Group has been showcasing young musical talent in its New Year series for more than 40 years now. With its insistence that the singers and instrumentalists confine their programmes to 20th- (and now 21st-) century repertory, the concerts fulfil a variety of functions, as well as giving a helpful push up the ladder to many of those selected.
fields.body:
The Park Lane Group has been showcasing young musical talent in its New Year series for more than 40 years now. With its insistence that the singers and instrumentalists confine their programmes to 20th- (and now 21st-) century repertory, the concerts fulfil a variety of functions, as well as giving a helpful push up the ladder to many of those selected.

Much of the music included in the programmes rarely gets an airing in the normal run of recitals, for their standard combination of solo instrument with piano - in Monday's opening two programmes, viola, violin and clarinet - implies a specific kind of 20th-century repertoire, music in which foreground and background, melody and harmony, still exert their authority.

So the composers for these PLG concerts are self-selecting to a certain extent, especially where British music is concerned, though by making a special feature of the works of Colin Matthews this year the organisers have selected someone who works within that mainstream tradition yet consistently produces fresh and distinctive results. Matthews had composed a new piece for the opening concert - Calmo for viola and piano is a rapt little birthday tribute (to the Dutch conductor Reinbert de Leeuw) which was superbly played by Lawrence Power and pianist Simon Crawford-Philips. At the age of 22 Power is already a remarkably mature viola player of big, rich tone and cool musical command. He couldn't do much with Errollyn Wallen's rambling Rapture, but made light of the unflashy difficulties of Ligeti's solo Viola Sonata.

If Power was the name to file away from Monday's concerts, the clarinettist Sarah Thurlow, who played more Matthews, as well as Martin Butler, Jonathan Harvey and the first performance of a beautifully judged new piece, Chorale, by her pianist Huw Watkins, is mightily accomplished too. It was hard to know what to make of the violinist Roman Mints, except that his taste in new music is pretty suspect - Sofia Gubaidulina's Der Seiltänzer is the kind of piece that everyone left behind 20 years ago and should never have been resurrected, while Artem Vassiliev's Story 1 for violin and tape is just a bundle of electronic cliches. And when he got down to something more substantial, in miniatures by Matthews and Lutoslawski, Mints' rhythmic control was not all it should have been either.

The PLG Young Artists Concerts continue at the Purcell Room, London SE1 (0171-960 4242), until Friday

fields.headline: Mojo's mix and match
fields.standfirst:
Geno Washington
Jazz Cafe, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: The Jazz Cafe is half full, with a yawning chasm of a dance floor. Even though soulman Geno Washington will have to work some wild alchemy to get this lot going, he jumps on stage unperturbed. A group of girls at the back start up a chant: "Geno! Geno!" He leans on the microphone and says in a deadpan Louisiana drawl: "Ye-e-ah. Baby, I love you crazy people."
fields.body:
The Jazz Cafe is half full, with a yawning chasm of a dance floor. Even though soulman Geno Washington will have to work some wild alchemy to get this lot going, he jumps on stage unperturbed. A group of girls at the back start up a chant: "Geno! Geno!" He leans on the microphone and says in a deadpan Louisiana drawl: "Ye-e-ah. Baby, I love you crazy people."

Accompanied by young, punchy trio The Purple Aces, he launches into an anarchic, beat-driven amalgam of blues and hardcore R&B. Immortalised in Dexy's Midnight Runners's 1980 hit Geno Washington has been performing his soul roadshow since the early 60s when he was a US airman based in East Anglia. His style is unique, his attitude irreverent. As he announces at regular intervals: "It's my shit, and I'll shake it where I want it." Van Morrison, for instance, gets short shrift. Just before they begin a version of Gloria, Washington says with a grin, "We're gonna play the shit sideways just to piss him off." He then turns the song into a funky work-out, complete with snatches of manic laughter and lines from Wild Thing. The spirit of James Brown is then resurrected in a robust, tightly played Papa's Got a Brand-new Bag.

By now the whooping girls are on the floor, along with couples doing rock'n'roll swing and ex-Rude Boys executing Motown moves. With his earthy delivery and ribald asides, Washington keeps stoking the energy level. He banters with the band - "What's in the damn pot, motherfucker?" he barks at his bassist between songs. Guitarist "Wolf Man", drummer "Pinocchio" and bass player "Catfish" remain resolutely good-natured, their line-up augmented every so often by a harmonica and a horn player. Their forceful pace matches Washington's powerful vocal style. Tonight the focus is not on original material - Washington plays to his strengths, mixing 50s grooves with 60s soul, dropping lines from one song into another. Nothing is sacred. The high point of the show comes towards the end when he sings a raw, intensely soulful version of I Put a Spell on You. "I fooled around and fell in love," he ad libs, and the crowd urges him on, ecstatic. This is one man who knows how to keep his mojo working.

At Clare Hall, Haywards Heath (01444 455440), January 28; Stafford Gatehouse (01785 253595), January 29; then touring

fields.headline: Song of the dinosaur
fields.standfirst:
Kenny Davern
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Kenny Davern, the acerbic and lugubrious Long Island clarinettist, gently mocked the audience for being the dinosaurs of the jazz circuit. "You like songs ?" he asked incredulously. He then proceeded to deliver the classy mainstreamer's best rejoinder: that lyrical pre-bop improvising on old Broadway show tunes may be historically interesting but can't be played with an edge.
fields.body:
Kenny Davern, the acerbic and lugubrious Long Island clarinettist, gently mocked the audience for being the dinosaurs of the jazz circuit. "You like songs ?" he asked incredulously. He then proceeded to deliver the classy mainstreamer's best rejoinder: that lyrical pre-bop improvising on old Broadway show tunes may be historically interesting but can't be played with an edge.

Davern makes you forget both how long ago the material he likes was written and that rhythm sections should not sound as comfortably four-square as this any more. He achieves this with phenomenal technique and mesmerisingly beautiful sound, but also provides an unpredictable and wayward improviser's imagination, which sporadically (and with a canny economy) veers away from familiar tracks. Davern is currently touring the UK (one of last week's gigs was also his 65th birthday celebration) and this week played a short season at Pizza Express with Brian Lemon on piano, Dave Green on bass and Allan Ganley on drums.

If a big part of Davern's deceptively easygoing skill is technical, the conceptual element of it is just as crucial. He builds a solo with a composer's foresight, often opening in the gurgly, vibrato- quivering murmur of the early New Orleans clarinettists. He then intensifies it into wails, yearning high notes, sly slurs. Occasionally he will wind pieces up by sidestepping their neat, top-and-tail resolutions and throwing in a banshee whoop instead, followed by a high trill, ending on a couple of spookily irresolute notes like the sinister whistle from a Morricone score.

The audience requested I Found a New Baby, which rattled past like a speeding train and brought an engaging bustle and clatter from Ganley's drums, and Davern unfolded a gracefully balanced solo of soft, smoky notes on a Hoagy Carmichael ballad that also confirmed the rhythmic sophistication and telling reserve of Brian Lemon as an accompanist.

After such an elegant set of variations, Davern typically signed off with a series of preoccupied murmurs and then, out of the blue, three abrupt yelps, like ships talking in the fog. It was a telling dramatic stroke, at the end of an improvisation that had been developed with all of Davern's rare mix of unflappable patience and communicative warmth - and it reminded his admirers of how eclectic his sound palette is. Brian Lemon was at his most poetically astute on the Carmichael feature, and at his most propulsive on the up-tempo follow-up, Lena. This piece also exercised all of the leader's skills, from hurtling but pristine double-time playing, to long, smeary sounds and the dolorous squall of bagpipes. Davern may be a dinosaur, but he is very much alive.

webTitle: New media money is looking for a place in the country

fields.headline: New media money is looking for a place in the country
fields.trailText: Demand from the nouveau riche in the media and technology industries is stoking a boom in the price of stately homes and large country houses on the fringes of London, according to estate agency Savills.
fields.body:
Demand from the nouveau riche in the media and technology industries is stoking a boom in the price of stately homes and large country houses on the fringes of London, according to estate agency Savills.

The boost to London house prices generated by the City's annual bonus round is now beginning to spread out of town to areas such as the M40 corridor.

Aubrey Adams, the chief executive of Savills, said: "City bonuses always knock straight through to property inquiries in London.

"But we are beginning to see a new impact on out of town property, which is partly the well-off looking for country homes but also a surge in demand from people working in the new media sectors just outside London."

He said that the price of the most popular country houses now ranged between £600,000 and £2m. He predicted that prices in this sector would soar by 18% this year. That compares with the 13.5% rise in the price of mainstream and central London houses which Savills sees for 2000.

Mr Adams said that the increasing trend towards internet and tele-working was likely to deflect some of the house price pressure away from London and towards the regions.

He expects local "hot spots" to be created throughout the country with hugely expensive houses standing cheek by jowl with much poorer housing, although the shortage of space in the south east is expected to ensure there is no let up in de mand and no long-term decrease in prices.

Savills, which yesterday unveiled a 69% rise in interim profits to £8.8m, is now in talks with more than 20 other central London estate agencies to set up a jointly owned website to ensure their business is not poached by internet newcomers. Mr Adams said there are plans for the big property-owning institutions in London to pool their property and market it on the web.

The boom means Savills is now likely to top last year's £18.5m bonus payment to staff, which meant windfalls of between £1,000 and £600,000 a head for its 1,200 employees.

Even its agricultural business division, which is one of the largest land managers in the country, is managing to stave off the threat of collapsing prices thanks to demand from City and internet millionaires.

Mr Adams said that although farm incomes have been "massacred", the impact on land values has been only slight.

"New wealth is buying land because these people want land for leisure purposes or to have around their large country homes," he said. "So although people are pulling out of farming and there is little volume of land sales, the prices are holding up."

fields.headline: A bridge too far
fields.standfirst: Frank lost his job after a Christmas party. But it wasn't the cross dressing or semi-naked conga - it was what he did in the punchbowl
fields.trailText: "Oh look, Catherine Zeta Jones is actually going to marry that horrid old sex addict," I say pointing to the article in the newspaper. It is lunchtime at the tribunal and I'm trying to cheer Frank, my client, up a bit.
fields.body:
"Oh look, Catherine Zeta Jones is actually going to marry that horrid old sex addict," I say pointing to the article in the newspaper. It is lunchtime at the tribunal and I'm trying to cheer Frank, my client, up a bit.

Any interest Frank has in celebrity gossip seems to have been extinguished by his general gloom about the way his case is going.

I'm a bit pushed for other small talk because we've already bored each other senseless with the universal post-millennial repertoire of "that river of fire, wotta swizz","that London Eye, what, no passengers", "this awful flu everyone's had".

Frank hardly stirs. Frank is a party animal who went into sudden retirement after his work Christmas party in 1998. The hangover endures. Frank's performance at that event, which we have been rehashing as part of the evidence, was, well, spectacular. Frank, who is an ample bloke, arrived in drag. "Looked like Pat Butcher," he says proudly in one of his rare, cheerful moments. That was OK, though, because it was a fancy dress party.

Somewhat less acceptable was his subsequent removal of said frock, followed by dancing around in his thong underwear while singing Celine Dion hits to the karaoke machine. Sliding further down the scale of OKness, was Frank's ill-advised decision to put a selection of mini onion bhajis and pesto toasts in his boss's intray. But I don't suppose he'd have been sacked if he hadn't pissed in the punch bowl.

Frank hasn't managed to find another job since.

The tribunal is being a bit stuffy about the punch bowl activity and seems unimpressed by my argument that the punishment was disproportionate to the crime.

I quiz the bossman about the general debauchery Frank insists was going on at the Christmas do.

Me: "And it's true that other employees stripped to their underwear during the course of the evening to perform the conga?"

Bossman: "No one overstepped the limits of decency."

Me: "And it's true that the party favours for the women were penis-shaped keyrings?"

Bossman: "Yes."

Me: "And that you and your secretary entertained the company with a display of what you called "dirty dancing"?"

Bossman: "It was perfectly tasteful."

During the afternoon I find myself afflicted by a dose of Frank's morose indignation, which spills over into my closing submission: "This was, after all, a party, sir. The employers provided the drink and the karaoke machine and the "saucy" party favours. They encouraged the employees to let their hair down, have some fun. Is it really reasonable for them to turn around and dismiss an employee who goes a little too far?"

The answer to that is "yes" according to the tribunal. So Frank faces the new millennium without the support of that old toad; work.

A number of gin and tonics fail to dispell my vicarious gloom. When I get home and turn on the TV, some bloke is telling Denise van Outen (wearing a miniature nurse's outfit) about the time he lost his dental bridge whilst performing cunnilingus.

Happy New Year.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
6. How I dealt with stress
Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: How I dealt with stress
fields.body:
Kate Alexander, 32 Press officer

I work for Care International UK, a charity involved in the Kosovo crisis, and last April three of our aid workers were taken prisoner in Belgrade. I provided media support for the negotiators, which was a 24-hour job; I literally slept with my mobile phone on my pillow. Rather than be a martyr I asked my manager for a back-up team, called in favours and accepted all offers of help. I didn't feel inadequate because I recognised the workload was too much for one. If you're stressed and overworked, let everyone know, so they can help.

Michael Stowe, 55 Management consultant

I used to get really stressed at work until three years ago, when a psychologist friend suggested meditation. I went to classes and now I meditate for at least an hour in the morning before I go to work. Zen Buddhism has completely changed my attitude - I don't hang on to issues or conflicts any more. I realised how effective this was when a former boss tried to discredit me. It was a personality clash rather than anything to do with my performance; in the past I would have got even with her, but now I simply didn't react. I prayed for her instead. She eventually grew to respect me because I couldn't be riled, and in the end she left me alone.

Guy Fisher, 35 Systems manager

The only way I can deal with stress is to make sure I don't take my work problems home with me. I keep my suit in the office and if I have to work out of office hours I go to the local library. I go to work in jeans and a sweatshirt and change when I get to the office. webTitle: Now, I don't like having to do this...

fields.headline: Now, I don't like having to do this...
fields.standfirst:
Emma Brockes meets the managers whose job is telling others they've lost theirs - and almost feels sorry for them

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Emma Brockes meets the managers whose job is telling others they've lost theirs - and almost feels sorry for them
fields.body:
If there is an art to firing people, it lies in the pencil-thin margin between sympathy and sentiment. The sympathetic manager, if he's lucky, gets off with the minimum of fuss and a grazed conscience. The sentimental one, when he has the stomach to face the dismissal at all, is more likely to find himself addressing his regrets to a tribunal court. But what the blood-hungry outsider wants to know is: what's it like to give someone the boot?

"I would get such a sinking feeling whenever a dismissal was coming up," says Nick Leach, former personnel manager at Allied Domecq and Marks & Spencer and a manager whose sacking style combines elements of dismay and detachment. "I tried to make it as civilised as I possibly could by relating to the facts rather than the individual; talking about performance rather than personal issues."

Of course the success of this approach relies on a level of cooperation that the sacked employee is justifiably disinclined to give. Several years ago, at the behest of his bosses, Leach fired a pub manager whose takings were consistently down. "He was of the old school who thought all you had to do to be a good landlord was sit at the end of the bar and chat with your customers," he says. "He took the dismissal as a personal attack and became very angry."

Leach assumed the brace position, a retreat into legalese which well-trained managers are advised to take when the safety of the teacups is threatened. "You try to help and support them, but it is always at the back of your mind that unless you follow the exact letter of the law you could lose your case in a tribunal." The landlord took Leach's firm to court and lost.

The sentimental approach is far more dangerous than the sympathetic one, since it tends towards evasion. "It is incredibly difficult to face somebody you've worked with for many years and say, 'I'm afraid we are no longer going to allow you to feed your children and pay for a roof over your head,'" says Daniel Barnett, a barrister in employment law and the author of Avoiding Unfair Dismissal. "That's why a lot of people dodge it: they don't jump through the hoops, they don't call a meeting. They find it so embarrassing that they stick their head in the sand and then write a letter on Friday saying don't bother turning up to work on Monday. And that's an unfair dismissal."

Managers say it's unfair, too - to them, that is. Like eating wheatgerm, dismissing someone is a matter of health over taste: doing the right thing for the department despite one's personal loyalty. The encounters can reach epic scales of awkwardness. "I hated doing it," says Bernard Smithers (not his real name), a former newspaper executive who was charged with the task of firing 12 people in the space of 24 hours. "A lot of them were colleagues I'd known for a long time. Most were extraordinarily nice about it. I can only think of one instance when somebody burst into tears and I had to rush out in the classic manner and find a tissue. But I did need a stiff drink afterwards."

Hospitality is another industry with a high turnover of staff and Peter Antenen, as a former manager at Allied Lyon pubs during the 80s, was called upon to oversee many dismissals. He knew the drill: "Keep it clean, keep it short, and don't personalise it." But the frequency of his staff's transgressions didn't numb him to the dismissal process: his nerves were tested every time he fired someone. "I did a lot of mental preparation. You have to go into the room absolutely focused. It can be very tough, though, because at the same time you have to think what the employee is going through."

As employment law becomes tougher on employers (the ceiling for unfair dismissal claims was increased in October from £12,000 to £50,000), companies try to lessen the scope for improvisation - those nasty scenes that open the door to tribunals - by getting managers to stick very firmly to a company line.

"Several employers have standard transcripts for every scenario their personnel manager might face," says Barnett. "He just reads them out verbatim - which must be awkward for the person being dismissed."

How different from those companies with directors who instruct their managers to fire staff as speedily as possible. "You couldn't just call people into the office and say, 'You're fired,'" says Smithers. "But time was short, so in some cases I would tap people on the shoulder and tell them I had to discuss a matter of 'continuation of employment' with them, and would they like to make an appointment or get it over with then and there? Most opted for the former."

Employers have an incentive for keeping the dismissal sweet. "Bosses know that the sacked employee will leave the room and tell colleagues exactly what went on," says Ros Jay, author of Seven Deadly Skills of Management. "If he doesn't want a mutiny, he has to keep it fairly civil."

By the time it comes to the actual sacking - which can follow months of warnings - anger is rarely still an issue for the manager. "The temper tends to come at the point at which an offence is discovered," says Antenen. "Managers working long hours take it personally when someone threatens the results. The actual process itself is fairly mechanical." If there are fireworks, they are more likely to come from the sacked employee. "I had a situation where a bartender was caught red-handed giving free drinks to his friends," says Antenen. "Even though we had three independent witnesses, he blatantly pleaded his innocence. When I put the evidence in front of him he capitulated. He was in tears by the end, and was thoroughly traumatised."

The manager's anger is more often directed towards his seniors than towards the person he is firing. Leach has fired people he felt didn't deserve it. "The boss sits in an office in the City saying, 'Why are these pubs not performing?' There can be all sorts of reasons. The publican says 'I'm doing my best', but there was nothing I could do. Those were the cases that stayed with you. I think it's as difficult for those doing the deed as for those having it done to them."

It is a maxim he has had the misfortune of understanding through experience. Like Smithers, Leach received instructions on how to fire people. Shortly after their stints as arch-dismissers, both men were themselves let go.

fields.headline: Desk therapist
fields.standfirst:
We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Sadler's Wells chief exec and Dick Whittington producer Ian Albery

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: We showed desk therapist Donna Dawson the desk of Sadler's Wells chief exec and Dick Whittington producer Ian Albery
fields.body:
This desktop is highly organised: the decks are cleared for action and there are no drawers so nothing appears to be hidden away. This person comes into work and puts on a work persona; he has created enough space in which to think.

I suspect he deals more with facts and figures than with creative ideas: see how far the pen pot is from the centre of the action! The only spot of colour is the calendar - this is a thrifty individual, who may have trouble splashing out; he may also feel fantasising is a waste of time. Although modest, he needs to be appreciated by others.

He also needs a bit of inspiration from time to time, though he is self-reliant and practical. The dark colours of the computer and keyboard seem to suck you into a secret world; does this person wait for others to discover his hidden depths? There may be an ongoing struggle between his need to be independent and his need to belong. He may need to let himself lighten up a bit, especially with workmates - I suspect he is less reserved away from the office.

Did our expert get it right? Ian Albery responds:

I wish the decks were cleared for action - there are, in fact, hidden drawers. The distance of the pen pot is because I'm mostly on the phone. I am shy, unless it is professionally necessary not to be. Mine is a high-risk business, and keeping a thinking distance is important. But it's true - on holiday my staff wouldn't recognise me!

webTitle: The future is fast and mobile

fields.headline: The future is fast and mobile
fields.standfirst: A seat at the auction costs £50m. The prize? Licences to change the way we communicate
fields.trailText: The day will come when, as you weave through the post theatre crowds in London's West End in search of somewhere to eat, all you need do is look at your mobile phone.
fields.body:
The day will come when, as you weave through the post theatre crowds in London's West End in search of somewhere to eat, all you need do is look at your mobile phone.

Localised advertising and menus will reach the handset via the internet and the user will be able to check availability and reserve a table. Maps which pinpoint where you are will act as a guide.

Another scenario might see you choosing the film you want to watch on the way to the cinema by looking at the trailers on the way, and then booking online.

The futurologists are having fun with mobile phones. The convergence of the two fastest growing methods of communication - mobiles and the net - have produced endless theoretical applications.

Cheque

But by 3.00pm today an important step will be taken toward that much-hyped future as the deadline passes for companies to make an initial application for one of the five licences available in the next generation of mobile phones, otherwise known as UMTS. The new wave follows analogue (the first generation) and the existing digital technology.

Advisers to some of the world's most powerful telecoms companies are expected to make the journey to the radiocommunciations agency in London's Marsh Wall with a cheque for £50m a piece to reserve their places in the auction. The department of trade and industry is expected to make an announcement on participants after the close of the stock market.

Third generation will see data transferred at rates 200 times that of existing GSM phones - up to 2 megabytes a second. As well as higher quality voice, high bandwidth multimedia internet access and audio clips, UMTS will make video phones a commercial reality. Games, e-commerce and sophisticated online banking should also be available.

Given the extraordinary growth of mobile phone use which last week saw Britain reach four in 10 people carrying handsets, the potential for mobile e-commerce far outstrips the PC, which is why the likes of Microsoft have been working with British Telecom on software applications.

The four existing networks, Vodafone, BT Cellnet, Orange and One2One have all made their intention clear to bid in the auction. Others who have put their hands up include Spanish telecoms group Telefonica, France Télécom - through its interest in cable company NTL - and Virgin, which has been in talks with various institutional backers. OneTel, the Australian reseller has also been named as a possible bidder as have Energis and Telecom Italia Mobile.

Other than the costly exercise of buying either BT or Vodafone, this will be arguably the last chance for an overseas buyer to make an inroad to the lucrative British market. There are no technical or financial pre-qualification requirements and the information memorandum issued by investment bank NM Rothschild also states that a bidder need not be a telecommunications company, opening the field to newcomers.

The DTI hopes to raise around £1.5bn from the auction - suggesting that each licence will go under the hammer for between £400m and £500m. One part of the spectrum will be reserved for a new entrant and they can also bid alongside the existing operators for the other four licences. That may be unadvisable, however, as the existing four are likely to pay whatever it takes to win."The potential downside for one of the four existing networks not winning a licence is too strong," says one insider. Analysts estimate the cost of upgrading an existing network to UMTS at about £2bn apiece. To build a new network from scratch for the fifth operator will cost £5bn though the new entrant will be able to roam on the existing four networks while building its own.

The high price has been enough to deter some. United News & Media, owner of the Express newspapers and online service LineOne hired former telecoms regulator Don Cruickshank to act as a consultant but yesterday ruled out any frontline investment. "We think it's exciting technology and are keen to be involved as a content provider but will not be involved in a bidding consortium," a spokesman said.

Before the arrival of UMTS, stepping stone technologies - often referred to as 2.5 generation - will open the way for internet access. Wireless application protocol (WAP) phones enabling web access will become widely available in the summer while another technology called GPRS is likely to launch at the end of the year with speeds similar to existing modems.

Changing

There is some debate about just how much advantage UMTS will have over GPRS. One of the biggest changes brought by GPRS is that there will be no need to log on and off to the internet every time it is used. Instead, handsets will simply sit on standby with users paying for bytes downloaded rather than time spent online. "There will be a huge explosion of web content aimed at mobiles," says Greg Ellard, applications director of Lucent Technology which is developing platforms for 2.5 generation phones.

Higher speeds and the ability to cope with TV quality video should ensure continued interest in UMTS, however. Internet access through UMTS will also be closer to the experience of PCs as the smaller screens of WAP phones means web content needs to be reconfigured. As the number of people going online via phones increases, so more websites will be available in WAP format. but in the meantime access will be limited.

BT Cellnet already has a limited internet access product called Genie while Vodafone launched a basic service at the end of last year, offering services such as news, sports, and share prices.

webTitle: Banks accused of euro zone price fix

fields.headline: Banks accused of euro zone price fix
fields.trailText: Europe's competition authority will next month accuse some of Europe's leading banks of agreeing to fix the price at which they exchange foreign currencies for tourists and businesses in the euro zone.
fields.body:
Europe's competition authority will next month accuse some of Europe's leading banks of agreeing to fix the price at which they exchange foreign currencies for tourists and businesses in the euro zone.

The European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, will write to banks spelling out his suspicions next month, giving them one month to respond to his accusations. If his suspicions prove correct, the banks face large fines.

Mr Monti told the European parliament's economic and monetary affairs committee yesterday that his suspicions that banks had formed "cartels" appeared to have been proved correct in some countries.

Consumers and politicians have complained that the fees have increased although the rates for exchanging French francs into German marks and other euro-zone currencies were locked a year ago, eliminating foreign exchange risk.

The commission raided banks in Germany, France, Italy and Spain early last year, followed three months ago of investigations in Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands.

The banks under investigation include Germany's Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, Société Générale and Crédit Agricole of France, Italian savings bank Cariplo and Banco Commerciale Italiana, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya and Argentaria of Spain, Dutch bank ABN Amro, Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Bank.

An EC spokesman stressed last night that the investigation was continuing and covered all 11 countries which joined the euro a year ago.

The investigation was prompted by complaints in the early days of the euro that banks were still charging fees for exchanging bank notes between countries which had joined the euro, even though the rates of exchange had been officially pegged to each other.

The EU suspects that any cartels that have formed have done so within countries rather than across the entire euro zone.

The banks may have taken the action to fix the price at which they exchange, say, French francs for German marks, to protect their revenues which stand to be eradicated entirely once euro notes and coins begin to circulate.

The European competition commissioner, Mario Monti, will write to banks spelling out his suspicions next month, giving them one month to respond to his accusations. If his suspicions prove correct, the banks face large fines. Mr Monti told the European parliament's economic and monetary affairs committee yesterday that his suspicions that banks had formed "cartels" appeared to have been proved correct in some countries. Consumers and politicians have complained that the fees have increased although the rates for exchanging French francs into German marks and other euro-zone currencies were locked a year ago, eliminating foreign exchange risk. The commission raided banks in Germany, France, Italy and Spain early last year, followed three months ago of investigations in Ireland, Belgium and the Netherlands. The banks under investigation include Germany's Deutsche Bank and Dresdner Bank, Société Générale and Crédit Agricole of France, Italian savings bank Cariplo and Banco Commerciale Italiana, Banco Bilbao Vizcaya and Argentaria of Spain, Dutch bank ABN Amro, Bank of Ireland and Allied Irish Bank. An EC spokesman stressed last night that the investigation was continuing and covered all 11 countries which joined the euro a year ago. The investigation was prompted by complaints in the early days of the euro that banks were still charging fees for exchanging bank notes between countries which had joined the euro, even though the rates of exchange had been officially pegged to each other. The EU suspects that any cartels that have formed have done so within countries rather than across the entire euro zone. The banks may have taken the action to fix the price at which they exchange, say, French francs for German marks, to protect their revenues which stand to be eradicated entirely once euro notes and coins begin to circulate.
